('80', 0, 1, 2, 46) 1. LETTER TO ARTHUR MOORE
('80', 0, 2, 3, 72) December 28, 1940
('80', 0, 3, 4, 90) DEAR MR. MOORE 1, Many thanks for your reasoned letter.
('80', 0, 3, 5, 146) I see that we cannot agree as to facts and, where we agree, we view them from different angles of vision.
('80', 0, 3, 6, 252) Therefore we must for the time being agree to differ.
('80', 0, 3, 7, 306) ‘We shall know each other better when the mists have rolled away.’ I know that our friendship can easily bear the strain of our differences.
('80', 0, 3, 8, 447) With compliments of the season.
('80', 0, 4, 9, 479) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('80', 0, 5, 10, 509) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.
('80', 0, 5, 11, 539) Courtesy: Pyarelal
('80', 0, 6, 12, 558) 2. LETTER TO K. SURYAPRAKASA RAO
('80', 0, 7, 13, 591) SEVAGRAM, December 28, 1940
('80', 0, 8, 14, 619) DEAR SHRI SURYAPRAKASA RAO, Your postcard dated 24th instant.
('80', 0, 8, 15, 681) You must spin, wear khadi, learn Hindi and do some constructive work while retaining your present job.
('80', 0, 9, 16, 784) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('80', 0, 10, 17, 814) From a copy: C.W. 10275. Courtesy: K. Suryaprakasa Rao
('80', 0, 11, 18, 869) 3. LETTER TO S. RADHAKRISHNAN
('80', 0, 12, 19, 899) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, December 28, 1940
('80', 0, 13, 20, 935) DEAR SIR RADHAKRISHNAN, I have just finished your convocation address which you so kindly sent me.
('80', 0, 13, 21, 1034) I liked it very much.
('80', 0, 13, 22, 1056) Your language is all your own.
('80', 0, 14, 23, 1087) 1 Editor, The Statesman
('80', 1, 0, 1, 1111) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 1, 1, 2, 1151) You will, however, let me say that I miss the strength which I would expect from your pen or speech.
('80', 1, 1, 3, 1252) The message of non violence demands the utmost strength without sting behind it.
('80', 1, 2, 4, 1333) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('80', 1, 4, 7, 1454) 4. LETTER TO J. B. KRIPALANI
('80', 1, 5, 8, 1483) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, December 28, 1940
('80', 1, 6, 9, 1519) MY DEAR PROFESSOR,
('80', 1, 7, 10, 1538) Why do you complain about my dealing directly with the Presidents and issuing Press notes?
('80', 1, 7, 11, 1629) There is nothing irregular in this.
('80', 1, 7, 12, 1665) And how cumbersome to do all these things through you?
('80', 1, 7, 13, 1720) Mahadev might have sent you copies.
('80', 1, 7, 14, 1756) But you will pity him if you saw him at work.
('80', 1, 7, 15, 1802) And if and when he too goes!
('80', 1, 7, 16, 1831) You are overdue.
('80', 1, 7, 17, 1848) I sent you a wire in reply to your letter.
('80', 1, 7, 18, 1891) No reply and no Kripalani!
('80', 1, 7, 19, 1918) I hope you found Sucheta 1 in g[ood] he[alth].
('80', 1, 9, 20, 1965) From the original: C.W. 10877. Courtesy: Girdhari Kripalani

('80', 2, 1, 4, 2400) Bhagavat 2 also had written to me.
('80', 2, 1, 5, 2435) Sarojinidevi 3 also had told me that spinning, prayers and so on were going on regularly.

('80', 2, 1, 11, 2806) She has benefited by your teaching and your guidance.

('80', 2, 1, 13, 2943) Don’t be guided by newspaper reports about my health.
('80', 2, 1, 14, 2997) I am quite all right.

('80', 2, 4, 23, 3336) 6. LETTER TO SUBHAS CHANDRA BOSE 4
('80', 2, 5, 24, 3371) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, December 29, 1940
('80', 2, 6, 25, 3407) MY DEAR SUBHAS, You are irrepressible whether ill or well.
('80', 2, 6, 26, 3466) Do get well before going in for fireworks.
('80', 2, 6, 27, 3509) I have not been in consultation with Maulana Saheb.
('80', 2, 6, 28, 3561) But, when I read in the papers about the decision, I could not help approving of it.
('80', 2, 6, 29, 3646) I am surprised that you won’t distinguish between discipline and indiscipline.
('80', 2, 7, 30, 3725) 1 Sushila Pai 2 Manager, Saswad Ashram 3 Sarojini Naidu 4 This was in reply to the addressee’s letter dated December 23; vide “Letter From Subhas Chandra Bose”, 23 12 1940 Mukundlal Sircar, with Gandhiji’s approval, released the correspondence to the Press.
('80', 3, 0, 1, 3983) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 3, 1, 2, 4023) But I quite agree with you that either of you is more than a match for the Maulana Saheb as far as popularity is concerned.
('80', 3, 1, 3, 4147) But a man has to put conscience before popularity.
('80', 3, 1, 4, 4198) I know that in Bengal it is difficult to function effectively without you two.
('80', 3, 1, 5, 4277) I know, too, that you can carry on even without the Congress.
('80', 3, 1, 6, 4339) But the Congress has to manage somehow under the severe handicap.
('80', 3, 1, 7, 4405) Suresh 1 wrote to me that Sarat was coming.
('80', 3, 1, 8, 4449) I have been waiting.
('80', 3, 1, 9, 4470) He can come any time he chooses, and so can you too.
('80', 3, 1, 10, 4523) You know, you will be well looked after here.
('80', 3, 1, 11, 4569) As for your Bloc 2 joining civil disobedience, I think, with the fundamental differences between you and me, it is not possible.
('80', 3, 1, 12, 4698) Till one of us is converted to the other’s view, we must sail in different boats, though their destination may appear, only appear, to be the same.
('80', 3, 1, 13, 4846) Meanwhile let us love one another, remaining members of the same family that we are.
('80', 3, 2, 14, 4931) Yours, BAPU The Hindu, 24 2 1941

('80', 4, 4, 34, 7489) 8. LETTER TO SIR J. G. LAITHWAITE
('80', 4, 5, 35, 7523) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, December 30, 1940
('80', 4, 6, 36, 7559) DEAR MR. LAITHWAITE, I thank you for your letter 3 of 27th instant, received yesterday.
('80', 4, 6, 37, 7647) Your letter raises a fundamental question.
('80', 4, 6, 38, 7690) I can fully appreciate the fact that His Excellency could only hold the view he does.
('80', 4, 7, 39, 7776) 1 Vide “Letter to Adolf Hitler”, 24 10 1940 2 Vide footnote 2, “Telegram to Sir J. G. Laithwaite; also the following item.
('80', 4, 7, 40, 7899) 3 Vide footnote 2, “Telegram to Sir J. G. Laithwaite”, 24 10 1940
('80', 5, 0, 1, 7965) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 5, 1, 2, 8005) despair of Indian nationalists like me has been that British functionaries could not be persuaded to see the other side of the shield.
('80', 5, 1, 3, 8140) And so the distance between them and nationalists is growing in spite of all efforts to the contrary.
('80', 5, 1, 4, 8242) The present struggle is the latest attempt among many to induce the makers of the British Empire to see things through nationalist eyes.
('80', 5, 1, 5, 8379) Such attempt must be continued till the truth is brought home to them.
('80', 5, 1, 6, 8450) Why should they constitute themselves the judges of their work among and on us?
('80', 5, 1, 7, 8530) The ordinary rule is that those should be the final judges who are the beneficiaries and not the self styled benefactors.But I must not enter into the interminable discussion of a question on which the British rulers and we must for the present differ.
('80', 5, 1, 8, 8783) But that difference can be no reason for gagging me.
('80', 5, 1, 9, 8836) I sought for the assistance because all the means of communication are under the Government control.
('80', 5, 1, 10, 8937) I was unprepared for the prohibition against the Indian Press.
('80', 5, 1, 11, 9000) I was prepared for the gag outside.
('80', 5, 1, 12, 9036) His Excellency must be the sole judge of the effect on the bona fide war effort of my letter to Herr Hitler being published in the world in the manner I had intended.
('80', 5, 1, 13, 9203) But I observe from your letter that the gag has been placed not for reasons of high policy but because, in His Excellency’s opinion, my characterization of British rule is not true to facts.
('80', 5, 1, 14, 9394) This is a dangerous doctrine of which the logical result would be suppression of all honest opinion except at the will of the executive head of the State or his deputy or deputies.
('80', 5, 1, 15, 9575) This has evidently no bearing on the war issue.
('80', 5, 1, 16, 9623) I may draw His Excellency’s attention to the fact that the sentiments expressed by me in the open letter to Herr Hitler are those I have expressed often enough in the columns of Harijan and elsewhere.
('80', 5, 1, 17, 9824) My booklet called Hind Swaraj 1 or Indian Home Rule contains similar sentiments.
('80', 5, 1, 18, 9905) I should like to know, if I may, whether my interpretation of your letter is correct.
('80', 5, 1, 19, 9991) I may mention that I had copies of the letter prepared for distribution to the Press.
('80', 5, 1, 20, 10077) But owing to the Press Adviser’s note I refrained from distributing the copies.
('80', 5, 1, 21, 10157) I have sent a copy only to my son forbidding its publication for the time being.
('80', 5, 1, 22, 10238) I do not want surreptitious publication, nor do I want to resort to open defiance, so
('80', 5, 2, 23, 10324) 1Vide “Hind Swaraj”, 22 11 1909
('80', 6, 0, 1, 10356) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 7
('80', 6, 1, 2, 10402) long as it is at all possible consistently with the interests of the national cause as I conceive it.
('80', 6, 1, 3, 10504) I shall, therefore, anxiously await a line from you.
('80', 6, 2, 4, 10557) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('80', 6, 3, 5, 10587) From a microfilm: Lord Linlithgow Papers.
('80', 6, 3, 6, 10629) Courtesy: National Archives of India

('80', 8, 1, 2, 12743) 14. LETTER TO KRISHNA CHANDRA
('80', 8, 2, 3, 12773) [1940] 1
('80', 8, 3, 4, 12782) KRISHNACHANDRA, A measuring tape is a good thing.
('80', 8, 3, 5, 12832) We do not want to give up everything modern.
('80', 8, 3, 6, 12877) The tape needs some improvement.
('80', 8, 3, 7, 12910) Assign the work to Bharatanandji 2 [for making] improvements in order to facilitate its use by the rural folk.
('80', 8, 3, 8, 13021) The rest will be done by Sushilabehn.
('80', 8, 3, 9, 13059) If it is possible it might perhaps be better to have all water boiled.
('80', 8, 3, 10, 13130) It is good to follow the rule to the extent possible.
('80', 8, 3, 11, 13184) According to the analysis of the experts the wells here remain polluted throughout the year.
('80', 8, 3, 12, 13277) That is another reason why there has been no case of typhoid ever since boiled water began to be used.
('80', 8, 4, 13, 13380) From a photostat of the Hindi : G.N. 4409

('80', 10, 1, 2, 15622) 19. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI
('80', 10, 2, 3, 15663) January 2, 1941
('80', 10, 3, 4, 15679) MANILAL AND SUSHILA, I got your two quite lengthy letters together.
('80', 10, 3, 5, 15747) It is of course commendable that you two are holding out by yourselves.
('80', 10, 3, 6, 15819) He who is on the side of truth, though alone, is in company, and those who oppose truth, though millions in number, count for little.
('80', 10, 3, 7, 15953) Tari is with me for the last three days.
('80', 10, 3, 8, 15994) She is pretty ill.
('80', 10, 3, 9, 16013) She will leave for Delhi on the 5th, the fourth day from now.
('80', 10, 3, 10, 16075) She will go with Dr. Sushila, who is here.
('80', 10, 3, 11, 16118) Most probably Tara’s friend will also go with her.
('80', 10, 3, 12, 16169) Manudi is still here.
('80', 10, 3, 13, 16191) Her daughter 1 is a very active and playful child.
('80', 10, 3, 14, 16242) With Sharda’s son and Nirmala’s daughter, thus there are three children.
('80', 10, 3, 15, 16315) Ba is fairly well.
('80', 10, 3, 16, 16334) She keeps on working.
('80', 10, 3, 17, 16356) There is hardly standing room in the Ashram, so to say.
('80', 10, 3, 18, 16412) It remains overcrowded.

('80', 12, 1, 2, 18686) 23. INSTRUCTIONS TO SATYAGRAHIS 1
('80', 12, 2, 3, 18720) [On or after January 5, 1941] 2
('80', 12, 3, 4, 18752) A satyagrahi, man or woman, once started on satyagraha, if unarrested, shall not return home but shall go from village to village reciting anti war slogans and addressing anti war meetings where necessary and doing constructive propaganda.
('80', 12, 3, 5, 18992) If, on any account, he feels obliged to return home, he must seek special permission for offering satyagraha again.
('80', 12, 3, 6, 19108) Satyagrahi once unarrested need not issue a fresh notice to the District Magistrate.
('80', 12, 3, 7, 19193) Satyagrahi shall not use any conveyance on his campaign.
('80', 12, 3, 8, 19250) He need not be in a hurry.
('80', 12, 3, 9, 19277) He may proceed slowly and travel a short distance.
('80', 12, 3, 10, 19328) He may, if necessary, stay more than one day at one place.
('80', 12, 3, 11, 19387) Satyagrahi must not stop any person or conveyance against their wishes nor must he enter anyone’s compound to recite slogans unless invited to do so.
('80', 12, 3, 12, 19537) A satyagrahi shall not recite slogans in an authoritative tone but in a persuasive way.
('80', 12, 3, 13, 19625) The Bombay Chronicle, 8 1 1941

('80', 15, 4, 7, 23299) 29. INSTRUCTIONS TO SATYAGRAHIS
('80', 15, 5, 8, 23331) SEVAGRAM, January 10, 1941
('80', 15, 6, 9, 23358) A very serious question confronts me in connection with the struggle.
('80', 15, 6, 10, 23428) In many places magistrates; have been imposing heavy fines on civil resisters, in some cases without option of imprisonment.
('80', 15, 6, 11, 23553) Civil resisters must not and cannot complain of whatever penalty is imposed on them, and Government will always take advantage of weaknesses of human nature.
('80', 15, 6, 12, 23711) Hitherto I have advised that fines should not be voluntarily paid but that authorities must be left to collect fines by distraint.
('80', 15, 6, 13, 23842) The result during the last struggle was a great deal of heart burning and bitterness.
('80', 15, 6, 14, 23928) Those who bought movables or immovables for a song incurred popular ill will.
('80', 15, 6, 15, 24006) I hope that if Government wish to touch immovable property, they will not sell but confiscate it.
('80', 15, 6, 16, 24104) For, whenever the struggle ends, immovable property is bound to be restored to the original owners—the resisters.
('80', 15, 6, 17, 24218) The late Bombay Government knew how difficult it was for them to restore to the resisters the immovable properties that had changed hands.
('80', 15, 6, 18, 24357) I have, however, discovered what may be termed a flaw in the reasoning that I had applied to the infliction of fines.
('80', 15, 6, 19, 24475) I now feel that even as a resister courts imprisonment, he is expected to court any other form of punishment, i.e., fines.
('80', 15, 6, 20, 24598) Punishment courted has to be joyfully suffered.
('80', 15, 6, 21, 24646) Therefore when fines are imposed and the person fined is able to pay he must do so willingly.
('80', 15, 6, 22, 24740) The result may naturally be that such a person will be fined again and again.
('80', 15, 6, 23, 24818) If he persists in his resistance, he may have no property left.
('80', 15, 6, 24, 24882) This is nothing to be wondered at.
('80', 15, 6, 25, 24917) As a matter of fact it is the essence of civil disobedience that the resister becomes indifferent whether the authorities take away all his property or not.
('80', 15, 6, 26, 25074) Therefore all propertied persons who wish to join the struggle should do so well knowing that the whole of their property may be taken up by the Government.
('80', 15, 6, 27, 25231) This is a struggle which has no ending except in success.
('80', 15, 6, 28, 25289) Therefore those who may be
('80', 16, 0, 1, 25316) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 17
('80', 16, 1, 2, 25363) fined should pay cash if they have it.
('80', 16, 1, 3, 25402) If they have no cash and the Government attach their property, it should be open to their friends to buy the same.
('80', 16, 1, 4, 25517) This will be an effective check on the cupidity of those who would profit by exploiting others’ loss and there will be no bad blood.
('80', 16, 1, 5, 25650) One corrollary to this reasoning is that even as I had declared that every inch of immovable property sold or confiscated by the Government would have to be returned to the resisters, so will every rupee taken in fines have to be returned to them on the struggle ending.
('80', 16, 1, 6, 25921) It follows of course that those who pay the fines will have to offer civil disobedience till they are safely lodged in jail.
('80', 16, 1, 7, 26046) It follows also that those propertied persons who do not wish to run the risk of losing their property must not join this struggle.
('80', 16, 1, 8, 26178) I hope however that patriotic people who believe in the efficacy of civil resistance will not fight shy of losing all their possessions.
('80', 16, 1, 9, 26315) Let them remember the words of Sheth Jamnalal:
('80', 16, 2, 10, 26362) I have long since come to realize that much too heavy a price has been and is being paid by the few for the enjoyment of wealth and for the apparent safety of life.
('80', 16, 2, 11, 26527) The price paid is the blood of the famishing millions and the manliness of those who should be ready to shed their blood for the defence of themselves, their families and their country.
('80', 16, 3, 12, 26713) Congress Bulletin, No.
('80', 16, 3, 13, 26736) 6, 1942. Pile No.
('80', 16, 3, 14, 26754) 3/42/41 Poll.
('80', 16, 3, 15, 26768) Courtesy: National Archives of India

('80', 17, 2, 3, 27302) [On or after January 10, 1941] 2
('80', 17, 3, 4, 27335) Surely there is no cause for depression.
('80', 17, 3, 5, 27376) I have never condemned Punjab Congressmen.
('80', 17, 3, 6, 27419) I have faith that the average Congressman in the Punjab is as good as the average in the other provinces.
('80', 17, 3, 7, 27525) Let the Punjab Congressmen take heart and qualify themselves by spinning, and regarding Harijans and other Hindus, Muslims, Sikhs, etc., as blood brothers.

('80', 17, 6, 10, 27841) 32. INSTRUCTIONS FOR INDEPENDENCE DAY 3
('80', 17, 7, 11, 27881) January 11, 1941
('80', 17, 8, 12, 27898) I hope that every man and woman in India, whether Congressman or other, will realize the gravity of the struggle and will resolve on the forthcoming Independence Day upon dedicating himself or herself to the service of the country in terms of the millions.
('80', 17, 8, 13, 28155) Swaraj based on non violence does not mean mere transfer of power.
('80', 17, 8, 14, 28222) It should mean complete deliverance of the toiling yet starving millions from the dreadful evil of economic serfdom.
('80', 17, 8, 15, 28339) This can only be attained by the propertied few identifying themselves with the millions and by their readiness to sacrifice their all for the latter’s sake.
('80', 17, 8, 16, 28497) It must be a day of fraternization, abolition of untouchability from our hearts, giving up spirituous liquors, self spinning, and sale and spread of khadi and village industries.
('80', 17, 8, 17, 28676) There is to be no civil disobedience that day.
('80', 17, 8, 18, 28723) For, we must not invite disturbance of our
('80', 17, 9, 19, 28766) 1 The message was sent through Jagannath who, in his letter dated January 10, requested: “A friend from Lahore who is a responsible and well informed Congress worker and who is in constant touch with Congressmen all over the Punjab writes to me that the recent occurrences in the Punjab have depressed the hearts of Congressmen there and have created confusion in their minds and they are feeling that they may have fallen in your estimation and you may have despaired of them.
('80', 17, 9, 20, 29244) A word from you will cheer them up.
('80', 17, 9, 21, 29280) .” 2 ibid 3 Celebrated on January 26
('80', 18, 0, 1, 29317) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 19
('80', 18, 1, 2, 29364) meetings, processions and prabhat pheries 1 on that day.
('80', 18, 1, 3, 29421) The day may begin with prabhat pheries, followed by flag hoisting and flag salutation.
('80', 18, 1, 4, 29508) In the evening there may be processions terminating in public meetings where the pledge 2 may be explained clause by clause and administered by the Chairman and solemnly accepted by the audience.
('80', 18, 1, 5, 29704) Where there are already restrictions they must be obeyed.
('80', 18, 1, 6, 29762) From such voluntary obedience comes the strength for the right of civil resistance.
('80', 18, 2, 7, 29846) PLEDGE 3
('80', 18, 3, 8, 29855) In view of the fact that individual civil disobedience has already commenced and that a large number of Congressmen have already been imprisoned all over India, it becomes the special duty of every Indian to concentrate with redoubled zeal on the constructive programme, without the fulfilment of which no civil disobedience, mass or individual, can help us to win and retain swaraj.
('80', 18, 3, 9, 30239) Concretely expressed, constructive programme means the universalization of hand spinning and khadi and popularization of village industries and village products.
('80', 18, 3, 10, 30401) We recognize that effective spread of non violence must bring communal harmony and complete eradication of untouchability in every shape and form.

('80', 19, 4, 20, 32137) 34. INSTRUCTIONS TO SATYAGRAHIS
('80', 19, 5, 21, 32169) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, January 12, 1941
('80', 19, 6, 22, 32204) Long before his unexpected arrest 3 Maulana Saheb had announced that before offering civil disobedience he would visit Sevagram and discuss with me important matters affecting the communal questions as also such other matters.
('80', 19, 6, 23, 32431) But it was not to be.
('80', 19, 6, 24, 32453) Non popular rulers do not disclose their intentions to the people.
('80', 19, 6, 25, 32520) They allow them to be inferred from their acts.
('80', 19, 6, 26, 32568) Perhaps it is a legitimate inference to draw from Maulana Saheb’s premature (from the Congress standpoint) arrest that they did not want him to meet me.
('80', 19, 6, 27, 32721) There can be no cause for complaint in this.
('80', 19, 6, 28, 32766) They may not be expected to consult Congress convenience.
('80', 19, 6, 29, 32824) But it is proper for Congressmen to realize that the rulers have no faith in Congress non violence.
('80', 19, 6, 30, 32924) Probably they do not consider me to be a knave, but they do consider me to be a fool.
('80', 19, 6, 31, 33010) In so doing they only follow many others who think that Congressmen fool me and that the latter’s
('80', 19, 7, 32, 33108) 1 In Madras 2 Vide the preceding item.
('80', 19, 7, 33, 33147) 3 On January 3
('80', 20, 0, 1, 33162) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 21
('80', 20, 1, 2, 33209) non violence is but a cloak for hiding their violence, if it is not a preparation for it.
('80', 20, 1, 3, 33299) Our struggle, therefore, consists in showing that our non violence is neither a cloak to hide our violence or hatred, nor a preparation for violence in the near or distant future.
('80', 20, 1, 4, 33479) Therefore our success depends not upon numbers going to jail but on the sum total of the purity and non violence we are able to show in all our activities.
('80', 20, 1, 5, 33635) Numbers can count only when they are of the right type.
('80', 20, 1, 6, 33691) They will positively harm the movement, if they are of the wrong type.
('80', 20, 1, 7, 33762) For me there is no turning back, whether I have many or very few satyagrahis.
('80', 20, 1, 8, 33840) I would far rather be regarded as a fool but strong, than as a knave and a coward.
('80', 20, 1, 9, 33923) Though the whole world may repudiate my claim, I must repeat that the struggle is God guided.
('80', 20, 1, 10, 34017) I am but a humble instrument in His hand.
('80', 20, 1, 11, 34059) Without His guidance, real or imaginary, I should feel utterly impotent to shoulder the burden I am supposed to be carrying.
('80', 20, 1, 12, 34184) Let me now say how I visualize the struggle.
('80', 20, 1, 13, 34229) Maulana Saheb having gone, there is to be no successor appointed.
('80', 20, 1, 14, 34295) Every acting President in a province must be approved by me.
('80', 20, 1, 15, 34356) It is not necessary that there should be one.
('80', 20, 1, 16, 34402) All representative Congressmen from members of village to provincial Committees are expected to be in jail if they are fit and approved by me.
('80', 20, 1, 17, 34545) If they are not, by reason of health or otherwise, they cannot be expected to function except in rare cases and that too under my approval.
('80', 20, 1, 18, 34685) No fresh elections are to take place to replace those who will have gone.
('80', 20, 1, 19, 34759) The idea is ultimately for every Congressman to act on his own and be his own president but nobody else’s.
('80', 20, 1, 20, 34866) That is the conception of a completely non violent institution or society.
('80', 20, 1, 21, 34941) Not much direction is required by those who have learnt the art of suffering.
('80', 20, 1, 22, 35019) Everybody knows the conditions he has to fulfil for acquiring fitness for offering civil disobedience.
('80', 20, 1, 23, 35122) They can be easily complied with by any adult who is sound in body and mind.
('80', 20, 1, 24, 35199) No difficulty as to action arises so long as I am left free.
('80', 20, 1, 25, 35260) For nobody can resort to direct action without my consent.
('80', 20, 1, 26, 35319) My intention not to court arrest abides, but the rulers may have a different plan.
('80', 20, 1, 27, 35402) If it comes, it will be the real time of freedom from external control be it ever so non violent as also of true test for everyone.
('80', 20, 1, 28, 35534) I am not to appoint a successor.
('80', 20, 1, 29, 35567) Thus if I am arrested, everyone will be under the discipline of his or her own conscience.
('80', 20, 1, 30, 35658) In theory, therefore, a time may come when millions will be judges of their own fitness to offer civil disobedience.
('80', 21, 0, 1, 35775) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 21, 1, 2, 35816) This is not a struggle which can be ended quickly.
('80', 21, 1, 3, 35867) We are resisting an authority that is in itself struggling to fight for life against a stubborn foe.
('80', 21, 1, 4, 35968) The authority is related to a nation which knows no defeat.
('80', 21, 1, 5, 36028) Those whose life is in danger either readily yield on what they regard as non essential, or fight to the end on what they regard as essential.
('80', 21, 1, 6, 36171) Its refusal to concede our demand shows that they think that our struggle comes under the latter category.
('80', 21, 1, 7, 36278) Therefore our struggle must be coterminous at least with the European.
('80', 21, 1, 8, 36349) Hence everyone who offers civil disobedience and gets a short term should know that on every release he has to repeat civil disobedience till the end of the struggle.
('80', 21, 1, 9, 36516) There are two tactics demanding attention.
('80', 21, 1, 10, 36559) I have already issued a note 1 about fines without the option of imprisonment.
('80', 21, 1, 11, 36638) The other is that of not arresting civil resisters at all.
('80', 21, 1, 12, 36697) In each case the resisters should march on foot in easy stages in the direction of Delhi.
('80', 21, 1, 13, 36787) It may be even two or three miles per day.
('80', 21, 1, 14, 36830) The resister will march taking such food as the villagers may provide.
('80', 21, 2, 15, 36901) Congress Bulletin, No.

('80', 25, 1, 2, 42826) 42. LETTER TO SIR J. G. LAITHWAITE
('80', 25, 2, 3, 42861) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, January 16, 1941
('80', 25, 3, 4, 42896) DEAR SIR GILBERT,
('80', 25, 4, 5, 42914) Many thanks for your letter 1 of the 4th instant.
('80', 25, 4, 6, 42964) I am not going to write a serious reply to your extra serious letter.
('80', 25, 4, 7, 43034) My letters are not written either for publication or for propaganda, They are written in pursuance of the effort to act non violently.
('80', 25, 4, 8, 43169) Nor are they written to a stranger.
('80', 25, 4, 9, 43205) So much by way of preface.
('80', 25, 4, 10, 43232) The language of officialdom is evidently a thing to be learnt specially.
('80', 25, 4, 11, 43305) Your letter is an instance in point.
('80', 25, 4, 12, 43342) In my own plain English I resolve your language thus: I forgot to tell you that His Excellency’s disagreement with you as to the estimate of the British connection was not the only reason for not complying with your request.
('80', 25, 4, 13, 43567) It is inconvenient to give you the real or the whole reason.
('80', 25, 4, 14, 43628) So please regard this correspondence as closed.
('80', 25, 4, 15, 43676) Putting this interpretation upon your letter and reading it together with the last paragraph in it, I have finally decided not to contrive to secure publicity of the open letter 2 to Herr Hitler.
('80', 25, 4, 16, 43872) I have accordingly asked my son not to make any use of the letter but to destroy it.
('80', 25, 4, 17, 43957) I had told 3 you that I had not shown the letter to anyone else except my son.
('80', 25, 4, 18, 44036) I have since shown it to an English friend 4 who believes in my method.
('80', 25, 4, 19, 44108) She is not to make use of her knowledge except among friends such as the Bishop of Calcutta.
('80', 25, 4, 20, 44201) My hearty co operation with His Excellency in preventing publication does not mean admission of the validity of the prohibition It is an earnest of my desire not to embarrass authority wherever it is possible for me to avoid embarrassment.
('80', 25, 5, 21, 44441) 1 Vide “Statement made by the Viceroy on August 8, 1940 2 Vide “Is Islam Inspired” 3 Vide “Letter to Manilal Gandhi”, 11 7 1940 4 Agatha Harrison; vide the following item

('80', 26, 1, 3, 44740) I entertain the fond hope that His Excellency knows nothing of the Censor’s action.
('80', 26, 1, 4, 44824) I would like you very kindly to let me know whether it commands His Excellency’s approval.
('80', 26, 1, 5, 44915) If it does and if I am to fall in with it, it will stop all open communication with the public.

('80', 34, 1, 4, 56728) God between us all.

('80', 34, 1, 7, 56811) The Congress attitude has reference to a big organization.
('80', 34, 1, 8, 56870) The Congress, as an institution based on non violence, cannot distinguish between one species of violence and another.
('80', 34, 1, 9, 56989) I do not think that the world will be any better if British arms are victorious over the German through the means employed by the latter.
('80', 34, 1, 10, 57127) In the ultimate, the question before the Congress is how to do away with the use of arms as between man and man or nation and nation for the vindication of justice.

('80', 34, 1, 12, 57381) You have rightly detected the flaw in the Congress attitude as reflected in the Poona resolution.

('80', 34, 1, 15, 57673) In my opinion it reflects no discredit on the Congress that it could not abide by non violence in all circumstances.
('80', 34, 1, 16, 57790) Its policy is truth and non violence.
('80', 34, 1, 17, 57828) Above all else, therefore, it must be honest.
('80', 34, 1, 18, 57874) When, therefore, it found the Poona demand flouted, it came round to its original position and invited me to lead the battle of civil disobedience.
('80', 34, 1, 19, 58022) I had no hesitation in responding as I knew that the mass mind in India was by instinct non violent.
('80', 34, 1, 20, 58123) You seem also to have missed the fact that the Poona resolution would not have been passed at all but for my weakness of which I made ample confession 1 in the pages of Harijan.
('80', 34, 1, 21, 58301) My experience is that the Congress has grown progressively, though slowly, in non violence.
('80', 34, 1, 22, 58393) And I would have proved an unworthy exponent of non violence if I had failed at the right moment to express it through the Congress.
('80', 34, 1, 23, 58526) The Congress is as much anti Nazism as anti imperialism.
('80', 34, 1, 24, 58583) If the Government had not thoughtlessly forbidden the anti war activity of the Congress and had not proclaimed it as pro Nazi, they could easily have claimed the whole of India as anti Nazi—both that part which followed the Congress non violence and the other which believed in the use of violence.
('80', 34, 1, 25, 58882) Had it not done so, much bitterness would have

('80', 42, 0, 1, 71348) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 43
('80', 42, 1, 2, 71395) 70. LETTER TO NEWSPAPER EDITORS
('80', 42, 2, 3, 71427) SEVAGRAM, January 28, 1941
('80', 42, 3, 4, 71454) DEAR EDITOR, We have become so used to the Press gag that we hardly know that there is a partial paralysis of the Press.
('80', 42, 3, 5, 71575) In the name of “war effort” all honest expression of opinion, if it is opposed to war effort as conceived by the official world, is effectively suppressed, unless an enterprising editor or publisher risks the loss of his Press.
('80', 42, 3, 6, 71803) Thus my own effort, if my honesty be not questioned, is the true effort to end all war and therefore in no way anti British or pro German.
('80', 42, 3, 7, 71942) If public opinion desired suppression, the Press would on its own initiative exclude news and opinions disliked by the public.
('80', 42, 3, 8, 72069) But in India the majority of Indian Editors would gladly publish all the news about satyagraha if there was no gag.
('80', 42, 3, 9, 72185) I wish to use my case by way of illustration.
('80', 42, 3, 10, 72231) For the conduct of the campaign and for the sake even of keeping it within restraint, I have to issue statements from time to time.
('80', 42, 3, 11, 72363) During four days two out of three such statements were suppressed.
('80', 42, 3, 12, 72430) The reason assigned was as follows:
('80', 42, 4, 13, 72466) 1. January 16, 1941. I am writing this to inform you that Mahatma Gandhi’s statement of January 12 1 regarding continuance of the Civil Disobedience Movement was submitted for Press advice by two of the Press agencies but was not passed for publication.
('80', 42, 4, 14, 72720) I am accordingly bringing the above fact to your notice.
('80', 42, 5, 15, 72777) 2. January 28, 1941. I am writing this to inform you that Mahatma Gandhi’s statement of January 10 2 regarding payment of fines by satyagrahis, which was submitted for Press advice by two of the Press agencies, was not passed for publication, as being a prejudicial report containing incitement to carry on anti war civil disobedience.
('80', 42, 5, 16, 73113) I am accordingly bringing the above fact to your notice.
('80', 42, 6, 17, 73170) 1 Vide “Instructions to Satyagrahis”, 12 1 1941; the source, however, has “January 13”.
('80', 42, 6, 18, 73258) 2 Vide “Instructions to Satyagrahis”, 10 1 1941; the source, however, has “January 9”.
('80', 43, 0, 1, 73345) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 43, 1, 2, 73386) I used to send my statements through the usual news agencies.
('80', 43, 1, 3, 73448) But when I found that they were censored, I had to send my statements to selected newspapers and so they found place in some of them.
('80', 43, 1, 4, 73582) You can judge for yourself whether they were objectionable news.
('80', 43, 1, 5, 73647) This method of sending statements on chance publication is precarious.
('80', 43, 1, 6, 73718) As I had no intention of extending civil disobedience to the special Press laws and ordinances, I stopped 1 the three Harijan weeklies whose chief aim was to propagate non violence and what is known as the constructive programme.
('80', 43, 1, 7, 73948) I do not want so far as possible to extend the scope of civil disobedience beyond the present limit.
('80', 43, 1, 8, 74049) But I do not know that I can exercise that restraint if the Press abdicates its function of publishing relevant news.
('80', 43, 1, 9, 74167) I therefore appeal to the Press not to succumb to the gag but to assert its independence by publish ing all the satyagraha news in its fullness.
('80', 43, 1, 10, 74312) Of course it is open to the Editors to criticize and condemn the movement or the statements that may be issued.
('80', 43, 1, 11, 74424) Editors can signify their disapproval of the gag by either publishing the offending statements and risking prose cution or even confiscation of the Press or by stopping publication of their papers altogether by way of protest.
('80', 43, 1, 12, 74651) These are only two out of many ways for signifying your disapproval.
('80', 43, 1, 13, 74720) I observe that the Standing Committee of Editors is meeting on the 1st proximo 2. The Committee is expected fearlessly to vindicate the liberty of the Press.
('80', 43, 1, 14, 74878) It must cease to be the power it should be, if it submits to suppression of free public opinion.
('80', 43, 1, 15, 74975) I need hardly draw attention to the fact that in a subject country like India, the liberty of the Press is doubly precious.
('80', 43, 1, 16, 75099) And your responsibility, if you represent British owned Press, is very great at the present critical moment in the history of this country.
('80', 43, 1, 17, 75239) I need hardly also draw attention to the fact that I represent unadulterated non violence whose spread can do nobody any harm.
('80', 43, 1, 18, 75366) It is false and cruel to suggest that I could have anything in common with Nazism or Fascism because I happen to oppose imperialism.
('80', 43, 2, 19, 75499) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('80', 43, 3, 20, 75529) A.I.C.C. File No.
('80', 43, 3, 21, 75547) 1362, 1941. Courtesy: Nehru Memorial Museum and Library
('80', 43, 4, 22, 75603) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 24 10 1940, “To the Reader”, 31 10 1940 and ; 2 11 1940 2 The Standing Committee of the All India Newspaper Editors’ Conference met on February 1, 1941, in the premises of “The Hindustan Times”.
('80', 43, 4, 23, 75831) K. Srinivasan, Editor, The Hindu, presided.

('80', 57, 6, 8, 94394) 101. LETTER TO “THE TIMES OF INDIA”
('80', 57, 7, 9, 94430) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, February 10, 1941
('80', 57, 8, 10, 94466) SIR, Your word to me written so earnestly in your issue of February 7, demands a reply.
('80', 57, 8, 11, 94554) In spite of your disbelief, I must adhere to my faith in the possibility of the most debased human nature to respond to non violence.
('80', 57, 8, 12, 94688) It is the essence of non violence that it conquers all opposition.
('80', 57, 8, 13, 94755) That I may not express myself that measure of non violence, and the rest may express less is highly probable.
('80', 57, 8, 14, 94865) But I will not belittle the power of non violence or distrust the Fuhrer’s capacity to respond to true non violence.
('80', 57, 8, 15, 94982) The illustrations you have cited in support of your disbelief are all unhappy because wholly inapplicable.
('80', 57, 8, 16, 95089) A man is not necessarily non violent because he lays down his arms.
('80', 57, 8, 17, 95157) The Czechs, the Danes, the Austrians, and the Poles may have all acted most wisely, but certainly not non violently.
('80', 57, 8, 18, 95274) If they could have put up successful armed resistance, they would have done so and would have deserved well of their countrymen.
('80', 57, 8, 19, 95403) Nor is it for me to blame them for submission when resistance became vain.
('80', 57, 8, 20, 95478) It was, however, order to meet such contingen cies and in order to enable even the physically weakest persons not to feel powerless against physically strong persons fully armed with
('80', 57, 9, 21, 95661) 1 Rustomji Khurshedji Sidhwa; leader of the Congress party in the Sind Legislative Assembly 2 The reference is to by election in the Rohri Division of Sukkur District in Sind.
('80', 58, 0, 1, 95837) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 59
('80', 58, 1, 2, 95884) modern weapons of destruction that satyagraha was discovered and applied in South Africa in 1907 1. And it has since been successfully applied under varying and even baffling circumstances.
('80', 58, 1, 3, 96074) You will please excuse me for refusing to draw a distinction in kind between the forces I have had to cope with hitherto and what I may have to cope with if the Fuhrer attacked India.
('80', 58, 1, 4, 96258) The prospect of his killing every satyagrahi causes neither terror nor despair.
('80', 58, 1, 5, 96338) If India has to go through such a purgatory and if a fair number of satyagrahis face the Fuhrer’s army and die without malice in their breasts, it would be a new experience for him.
('80', 58, 1, 6, 96520) Whether he responds or not, I am quite clear that these satyagrahis facing the army will go down in history as heroes and heroines at least equal to those of whom we learn in fables or cold history.
('80', 58, 2, 7, 96719) You are, however, on less weak ground when you doubt the honesty or non violence of my companions.
('80', 58, 2, 8, 96818) You are entitled to throw the Poona resolution in my face.
('80', 58, 2, 9, 96877) I have already confessed 2 that the Poona resolution would not have been passed but for my momentary weakness.
('80', 58, 2, 10, 96988) As to the want of honesty or defective non violence, I can only say that the future alone will show whether satyagrahis were only so called or as honest and true as human beings can be.
('80', 58, 2, 11, 97174) I can only assert that every care has been taken in making the selection to ensure a fair standard of non violence.
('80', 58, 2, 12, 97290) I admit, however, that hypocrites have undoubtedly crept in.
('80', 58, 2, 13, 97351) But I entertain the belief that the vast majority will be found to be true.
('80', 58, 2, 14, 97427) The Congress President has been frank enough to define the limitations of his non violence.
('80', 58, 2, 15, 97519) 3 But so far as I know his mind—and nobody does if I do not—his non violence will be proof against any temptation within the limits defined by him.
('80', 58, 2, 16, 97667) I should undertake to engage in non violent resistance to the Fuhrer if I had companions with the Maulana Saheb’s circumscribed belief.
('80', 58, 2, 17, 97803) Whether such non violence can stand the test or not, is a moot question.
('80', 58, 2, 18, 97876) I have achieved success till now with such material.
('80', 58, 2, 19, 97929) You are incorrect in attributing to me a demand for unfettered
('80', 58, 3, 20, 97992) 1 In protest against the Transvaal Asiatic Registration Act passed on March 22, 1907 2 Vide “Letter to Carl Heath”, 25 1 1941 3 According to The Indian Annual Register, 1940, Vol. II, p.
('80', 58, 3, 21, 98179) 56, Abul Kalam Azad, in the course of an interview at Lahore on December 30, 1940, said: “If India is invaded tomorrow and there is no other alternative to defend my country, I will not hesitate to take up arms and fight.”
('80', 59, 0, 1, 98402) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 59, 1, 2, 98443) liberty of the Press or speech.
('80', 59, 1, 3, 98475) 1 What I have said 2 is that there should be unfettered liberty provided that it is not inconsistent with non violence.
('80', 59, 1, 4, 98595) I am not aware that Congress Ministers’ restrictive action went beyond the proviso.
('80', 59, 1, 5, 98679) If it did, it was certainly against the declared Congress policy and can be no guide or criterion for me.
('80', 59, 1, 6, 98785) The unkindest cut is contained in the insinuation that my demand for free speech, subject to the proviso mentioned, was “a device for squeezing political concessions from the British”.
('80', 59, 1, 7, 98970) There would be nothing politically wrong if political concessions were demanded even at the point of civil disobedience.
('80', 59, 1, 8, 99091) But it is a matter of public knowledge that the Poona resolution has lapsed.
('80', 59, 1, 9, 99168) And in so far as I am concerned, it remains lapsed so long as the war lasts.
('80', 59, 1, 10, 99245) Civil disobedience would certainly be withdrawn if free speech is genuinely recognized and the status quo restored.
('80', 59, 1, 11, 99361) I have never stated during previous movements that they were likely to be long drawn out.
('80', 59, 1, 12, 99451) But I have done so this time because I believe that there can be no settlement with the Congress, short of complete independence during the pendency of the war, for the simple reason that the Congress cannot commit itself to active help in war with men and money.
('80', 59, 1, 13, 99715) That would mean a reversal of the policy of non violence which the Congress has pursued for the last 20 years.
('80', 59, 1, 14, 99826) And independence cannot come through any settlement while the war lasts.
('80', 59, 1, 15, 99899) Therefore so far as I know, the Congress will be satisfied with the fullest freedom to grow in non violence.
('80', 59, 1, 16, 100008) The Congress demand concerns all persons and parties.
('80', 59, 1, 17, 100062) You ask me in the face of all these facts whether it is “fair or morally right to pursue his (my) present campaign”.
('80', 59, 1, 18, 100179) You have answered the question yourself in the negative.
('80', 59, 1, 19, 100236) But I may not accept your answer.
('80', 59, 1, 20, 100270) In the first place, as shown above, I do not subscribe to your facts.
('80', 59, 1, 21, 100340) Secondly, to accept your answer will be to declare my utter insolvency.
('80', 59, 1, 22, 100412) I would be untrue to the faith I have unwaveringly held now for nearly half a century in the efficacy of non violence.
('80', 59, 1, 23, 100531) I may seemingly fail, but even at the risk of being completely misunderstood I must live and act according to my faith and belief that I am serving
('80', 59, 2, 24, 100679) 1 The Times of India had argued: “He demands the unfettered liberty of the Press and the right of the individual to say what he likes.
('80', 59, 2, 25, 100814) These so called rights do not exist anywhere in the world; they did not prevail when Mr. Gandhi’s Congress Governments were in office in the Indian provinces.
('80', 59, 2, 26, 100973) Bombay and Madras bear witness to that fact.
('80', 59, 2, 27, 101018) Is Mr. Gandhi justified in demanding for himself and others a privilege which even Congress Ministers denied to the public?” 2 Vide “letter to Newspaper Editors”, 28 1 1941
('80', 60, 0, 1, 101191) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 61
('80', 60, 1, 2, 101238) India, Britain and humanity.
('80', 60, 1, 3, 101267) I do not wish well to India at the expense of Britain as I do not wish well to Britain at the expense of Germany.
('80', 60, 1, 4, 101381) Hitlers will come and go.
('80', 60, 1, 5, 101407) Those who believe that when the Fuhrer dies or is defeated his spirit will die, err grievously.
('80', 60, 1, 6, 101503) What matters is how we react to such a spirit, violently or non violently.
('80', 60, 1, 7, 101578) If we react violently, we feed that evil spirit.
('80', 60, 1, 8, 101627) If we act non violently, we sterilize it.
('80', 60, 1, 9, 101669) You ask me to devote myself to internal unity.
('80', 60, 1, 10, 101716) Well, my passion for it is as old as that for non violence.
('80', 60, 1, 11, 101776) Indeed, my first non violent experiment outside the domestic circle was to promote that unity.
('80', 60, 1, 12, 101871) And I had considerable success.
('80', 60, 1, 13, 101903) I ask you, therefore, to believe me that my effort for unity is not suspended but intensified by the present movement.
('80', 60, 1, 14, 102022) The great beauty of non violent effort lies in the fact that its failure can only harm those who are in it, while its success is sure to promote all round good.
('80', 60, 1, 15, 102183) M. K. GANDHI The Times of India, 15 2 1941

('80', 67, 7, 16, 111107) 118. INTERVIEW TO VAMANRAO JOSHI
('80', 67, 8, 17, 111140) [Before February 13, 1941] 1
('80', 67, 9, 18, 111169) I want quality and not number.
('80', 67, 9, 19, 111200) I may get a few satyagrahis today but their number is bound to increase.
('80', 67, 9, 20, 111273) I prefer five satyagrahis of quality to hundreds because these five will fight till the last.
('80', 67, 9, 21, 111367) There should be no competition between provinces for number.
('80', 67, 10, 22, 111428) It is understood that Mahatma Gandhi has disapproved of the proposal of the Berar Provincial Congress Committee to start training camps for satyagrahis.
('80', 67, 10, 23, 111581) Mahatma Gandhi is reported to have told Mr. Vamanrao Joshi, President of the Berar Provincial Gongress Committee, when he interviewed him recently, not to start such training camps as it might be banned by the Government and that he did not want to embarrass the Government.
('80', 67, 10, 24, 111856) Mahatma Gandhi had no objection for starting centres for training purely constructive workers.
('80', 67, 10, 25, 111951) The Bombay Chronicle, 14 2 1941 and 15 2 1941
('80', 67, 11, 26, 111997) 1 The first report of the interview had appeared under the date line “Nagpur, February 13”.
('80', 67, 11, 27, 112089) 2 This paragraph appeared in The Bombay Chronicle, 14 2 1941; which re ported that Gandhiji gave this answer in reply to “a question whether the province should give the best possible satyagrahis or should go without any if none came up to the prescribed standard”.

('80', 71, 6, 24, 117204) 126. LETTER TO MUKUNDALAL SIRCAR
('80', 71, 7, 25, 117237) SEVAGRAM, February 16, 1941
('80', 71, 8, 26, 117265) DEAR MUKUNDALAL, I have your letter 2. I had to delay replying to you because I got your copy of Subhas Babu’s letter first and then his own letter.
('80', 71, 9, 27, 117414) 1 The Foreword did appear as facsimile block on all cover jackets of the titles under “Gandhi Series”.
('80', 71, 9, 28, 117517) To the Students and To the Women were the first two books published under the series on October 2, 1941. 2 According to the source, “the letter of Mr. Bose dated January 10 [vide footnote 4, “Letter to Jamnalal Bajaj”] having remained unanswered, Mr. Mukundalal Sircar sent a telegram to Mahatma Gandhi on January 28, asking for a reply.
('80', 71, 9, 29, 117855) When he learnt from Sevagram that Mahatma Gandhi did not receive the letter in question, Mr. Sircar sent a copy of the same on February 8 for ready reference.”
('80', 72, 0, 1, 118015) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 73
('80', 72, 1, 2, 118062) The differences in our case are vital and fundamental.
('80', 72, 1, 3, 118117) Subhas Babu knows them, and I expect you too know them.
('80', 72, 1, 4, 118173) Independence secured through violence would have contents different from that secured through non violent means.
('80', 72, 1, 5, 118286) My notion of independence is independence of the poorest and the lowliest in the land.
('80', 72, 1, 6, 118373) But in political language, all of us—Communists, Socialists, Kisan Sabhaites, Labourites and others must think of independence though all will have different meanings for the same word.
('80', 72, 1, 7, 118559) So far as I am concerned, I have no objection to the whole of the correspondence being published.
('80', 72, 1, 8, 118657) You will please let me know as soon as news about Subhas Babu’s whereabouts is known.
('80', 72, 2, 9, 118743) The Hindu, 24 2 1941

('80', 79, 5, 6, 130313) I showed your letter to the General Secretary dated the 16th February, 1941, to Gandhiji who has asked me to reply to you as follows:
('80', 79, 6, 7, 130447) He sees no objection whatsoever to Congressmen helping in the prohibition campaign started by the present Government, provided it does not affect the satyagraha campaign.
('80', 79, 6, 8, 130618) That is to say, those who have signed the satyagraha pledge and are due to offer satyagraha on the dates given to them may not allow their decision to be affected by the campaign.
('80', 79, 6, 9, 130798) You say: “Some Congressmen, mostly active satyagrahis, have been enrolled as members of prohibition committees and, in some cases, they have assumed responsible roles.” But Shri Chaliha in his letter to Gandhiji dated 15th February, 1941, writes: “Congressmen who are offering services for this work are almost (all?) non satyagrahis, and out of 150 members there are only a few satyagrahis.” What is the truth?
('80', 79, 6, 10, 131210) However, our duty is clear.
('80', 79, 6, 11, 131238) Those who have not signed the satyagraha pledge may offer full co operation to Government, and those who have, may do so until the date on which they are offering satyagraha.
('80', 79, 7, 12, 131413) Yours sincerely,

('80', 82, 5, 11, 135057) 144. FOREWORD TO “STATUS OF INDIAN PRINCES”
('80', 82, 6, 12, 135101) The following seven chapters are a result of Pyarelal’s deep study of the status of the Princes of India.
('80', 82, 6, 13, 135207) They should have been published in pamphlet form long ago, and would have been, but for my pre occupation.
('80', 82, 6, 14, 135314) The writer is himself behind jail walls.
('80', 82, 6, 15, 135355) Therefore they are being published as they were written.
('80', 82, 6, 16, 135412) They are an evergreen.
('80', 82, 6, 17, 135435) They give to the busy public worker or student, in a compact form, an idea of the status of the Princes of whom there are nearly six hundred.
('80', 82, 6, 18, 135577) The chief merit of the pamphlet is that it contains nothing but what is taken from authentic records.
('80', 82, 6, 19, 135679) The existence of this gigantic autocracy is the greatest dis proof of British democracy and is a credit neither to the Princes nor to the unhappy people who have to live under this undiluted autocracy.
('80', 82, 6, 20, 135881) It is no credit to the Princes that they allow themselves powers which no human being, conscious of his dignity, should possess.
('80', 82, 6, 21, 136010) It is no credit to the people who have mutely suffered the loss of elementary human freedom.
('80', 82, 6, 22, 136103) And it is perhaps the greatest blot on British rule in India.
('80', 82, 6, 23, 136165) But we are too near the event to realize the falsity called “Princes’ India” or “Indian India”.
('80', 82, 6, 24, 136261) The system will break under its own intolerable weight.
('80', 82, 6, 25, 136317) My humble non violent effort is to induce all the three parties to wash the triple sin.
('80', 82, 6, 26, 136405) Even one of them can take the decisive step and it will affect all.
('80', 82, 6, 27, 136473) But it will be glorious if the three together realize the enormity of the sin and by a combined effort wash it.
('80', 82, 6, 28, 136585) M. K. GANDHI SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, February 23, 1941

('80', 83, 1, 2, 136700) 145. ADVICE TO CALCUTTA SATYAGRAHIS 1
('80', 83, 2, 3, 136738) [On or before February 24, 1941] 2
('80', 83, 3, 4, 136773) It would not be wrong if non arrested satyagrahis tour the whole district for a month or two and then proceed to Delhi.
('80', 83, 3, 5, 136893) Some may tour in the district and some may go to Delhi.
('80', 83, 4, 6, 136949) Referring to illiterate Harijan satyagrahis, Mahatma Gandhi says that if they do not march to Delhi or return after going half way, they should do constructive work and may also learn reading and writing.
('80', 83, 5, 7, 137154) Mahatma Gandhi does not approve of the idea of batches of two, three or four satyagrahis proceeding to Delhi but wants everyone to go singly.
('80', 83, 6, 8, 137296) Answering another question, Mahatma Gandhi says that those not proceeding to Delhi should offer satyagraha in their provinces.
('80', 83, 7, 9, 137423) To another query, “When people are told not to give food to satyagrahis, what should they do?”, Mahatma Gandhi replied that they should buy food if they have money or starve or proceed further; no hard and fast rule can be laid down.

('80', 87, 1, 2, 143124) 152. SPEECH AT OPENING OF KAMALA NEHRU HOSPITAL, ALLAHABAD
('80', 87, 2, 3, 143183) February 28, 1941
('80', 87, 3, 4, 143201) Mahatma Gandhi, while expressing his delight at the completion of a great project 1 which was the fulfilment of the last wish of the late Mrs. Kamala Nehru, pointed out that the Kamala Nehru Hospital was one of the first of its kind from the point of view of architectural beauty, and the comforts provided for the patients might attract even maharanis.
('80', 87, 3, 5, 143555) He, however, hoped that those responsible for running the day to day administration of the institution would not forget that the hospital was primarily intended for the poor whose interests should not be neglected, and service to the poor patients should be the motto of those in charge of the administration.

('80', 88, 6, 15, 145397) Mahatma Gandhi added that those who could not go to that length might do constructive work, specially the promotion of khadi and communal unity.

('80', 88, 7, 17, 145623) Gandhiji also emphasised the need for discipline, which was necessary in any organization.
('80', 88, 7, 18, 145714) Even violence, he remarked, needed discipline as was obvious from the example of Hitler.
('80', 88, 8, 19, 145803) Regarding the strikes, Gandhiji reiterated his previous statements 2 and warned the students against entering into party politics prematurely.
('80', 88, 8, 20, 145946) He urged that the students should keep an open mind and study ideologies.
('80', 88, 8, 21, 146020) He stressed that the students could play an important part in bringing about communal unity.

('80', 92, 6, 10, 152136) 163. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('80', 92, 7, 11, 152167) SEVAGRAM, March 5, 1941
('80', 92, 8, 12, 152191) NARANDAS, I liked your letter very much.
('80', 92, 8, 13, 152232) Your ideal is fine indeed; but Kanaiyo will not be able to reach it.
('80', 92, 8, 14, 152301) His mind was firm before Abha came into the picture.
('80', 92, 8, 15, 152354) People have noticed that since then he has been unconsciously letting himself be drawn towards her.
('80', 92, 8, 16, 152454) When I asked him, he felt that it was true.
('80', 92, 8, 17, 152498) We can put off the engagement for the present, but that would only be like deceiving the people.
('80', 92, 8, 18, 152595) The condition of Kanaiyo’s mind, so far as I can see, is as follows: ‘If I marry, it will be Abha, and if I cannot get Abha, I would prefer to remain unmarried.’ My view is that Abha should wait for three or four years.
('80', 92, 8, 19, 152815) Abha is of course growing fast.
('80', 92, 8, 20, 152847) Even after my death, he will marry nobody but Abha.
('80', 92, 8, 21, 152899) He is not of such an unsteady mind that he may change it any time.
('80', 92, 8, 22, 152966) Besides, Abha seems to me to be a noble type of girl.

('80', 93, 4, 8, 153746) 164. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('80', 93, 5, 9, 153774) SEVAGRAM, March 6, 1941
('80', 93, 6, 10, 153798) I must warn the public against journalistic flights of imagi nation.
('80', 93, 6, 11, 153867) No importance need be attached to my visits to Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and there meeting quite accidentally Kunver Sir Jagdishprasad, then Pandit Malaviyaji and the morning following Shri Vijayalakshmi Pandit and finally Maulana Saheb Abul Kalam Azad.
('80', 93, 6, 12, 154117) They were all of them friendly visits wholly unarranged when I left Sevagram for Allahabad.
('80', 93, 6, 13, 154209) I had gone for one mission and that alone.
('80', 93, 6, 14, 154252) What little other work I did was purely accidental.
('80', 93, 6, 15, 154304) I refer to my meeting some students and Garhwali workers.
('80', 93, 6, 16, 154362) Sir Tej Bahadur I went to see because he was ailing.
('80', 93, 6, 17, 154415) We are old friends.
('80', 93, 6, 18, 154435) He was to have come to see me but when I heard that he was ill I insisted on going to him.
('80', 93, 6, 19, 154526) No doubt, we talked about the political situation and even more about the Hindu Muslim problem.
('80', 93, 6, 20, 154622) Sir Jagdish who dropped in and who was to dine at Sir Tej Bahadur’s joined the conversation.
('80', 93, 6, 21, 154715) But not the slightest political importance attaches to these conversations.
('80', 93, 6, 22, 154791) We talked as individuals and not with regard to any mission.
('80', 93, 6, 23, 154852) Sir Tej Bahadur is anxious (who is not?) to end the present deadlock.
('80', 93, 6, 24, 154922) He would give anything to bring about Hindu Muslim unity.
('80', 93, 6, 25, 154980) He ascribes to me overmuch capacity for bringing about unity.
('80', 93, 6, 26, 155042) Sir Jagdish is no less anxious.
('80', 93, 6, 27, 155074) But the talks were no more than a friendly interchange of views.
('80', 93, 6, 28, 155139) As to the visits to Malaviyaji Maharaj, the same thing happened.
('80', 93, 6, 29, 155204) He has aged.
('80', 93, 6, 30, 155217) He ought not to talk about current events.
('80', 93, 6, 31, 155260) He is too weak.
('80', 93, 6, 32, 155276) But the country’s affairs are his daily food.
('80', 93, 6, 33, 155322) He will cease to think about them when he ceases to read and think of the Bhagvata
('80', 93, 7, 34, 155405) 1 Addressee’s wife 2 Vide also “Letter to Amrita Lal Chatterjee”, 15 1 1941
('80', 94, 0, 1, 155481) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 95
('80', 94, 1, 2, 155528) and the Gita.
('80', 94, 1, 3, 155542) These things are the breath of his life and they will stop with the stoppage of his last breath.
('80', 94, 1, 4, 155639) Who knows but that he will take them where the disembodied spirit goes.
('80', 94, 1, 5, 155711) It was a privilege to meet these friends but our talks have no bearing on the political situation in the country.
('80', 94, 1, 6, 155825) And there could be none in the purely prison visits to the Maulana and Shri Vijayalakshmi Pandit.
('80', 94, 1, 7, 155923) I know that the imaginary descriptions of such visits and the eagerness with which the public devour them show their desire for communal unity and a solution of the political deadlock.
('80', 94, 1, 8, 156108) But mere desire will take us no nearer its fulfilment.
('80', 94, 1, 9, 156163) For fulfilment can only come through common action on the part of those who share the desire.
('80', 94, 1, 10, 156257) All are searching for common action.
('80', 94, 1, 11, 156294) Speculation interferes with the search.
('80', 94, 1, 12, 156334) So far as the Congress is concerned, its policy and action based thereon are well known.
('80', 94, 1, 13, 156423) It is gross misrepresentation to suggest that the Congress is out for securing terms for itself.
('80', 94, 1, 14, 156520) Freedom of speech is for all even as independence will be for all.
('80', 94, 1, 15, 156587) The contents of the latter will be decided not by the Congress but by the vote of all.
('80', 94, 1, 16, 156674) And if it is to be achieved non violently it follows that the mere vote of the majority will have little play.
('80', 94, 1, 17, 156785) The charter of independence must be the product of the willing consent of the minorities and other relevant interests which are not in conflict with the interests of the vast mass of Indian humanity.
('80', 94, 1, 18, 156985) Be this as it may, in order that all the units may have full freedom of expression even against the war itself, the Congress has embarked upon civil disobedience.
('80', 94, 1, 19, 157148) That is the contribution of the Congress to the fulfilment of the common desire.
('80', 94, 1, 20, 157229) As an effort in direct action it must hold the field till a better is found.
('80', 94, 1, 21, 157306) Strong objection has been raised against my interpretation of the Bombay resolution.
('80', 94, 1, 22, 157391) I regard it as a true interpretation.
('80', 94, 1, 23, 157429) But it is that of an individual.
('80', 94, 1, 24, 157462) I have no authority from the Congress to interpret or vary the Congress resolutions.
('80', 94, 1, 25, 157547) That is essentially the function of the President, the Working Committee and finally the A.I.C.C. The.
('80', 94, 1, 26, 157650) only authority I have is to conduct the campaign of civil disobedience.
('80', 94, 1, 27, 157722) But when the time for settlement comes it will be for the Working Committee to decide what the terms shall be.
('80', 94, 1, 28, 157833) My contribution will be confined to advising the Committee.
('80', 94, 1, 29, 157893) The Working Committee may reject the interpretation I have given.
('80', 94, 1, 30, 157959) It or the A.I.C.C, may even alter the resolutions they have passed.
('80', 94, 1, 31, 158027) Meanwhile let everyone whether Congressmen or others be guided by the Bombay resolution and not
('80', 95, 0, 1, 158123) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 95, 1, 2, 158164) by my interpretation.
('80', 95, 1, 3, 158186) I have, therefore, failed to understand the consternation created by my statement 1 that there can be no settlement short of independence during the pendency of the war.
('80', 95, 2, 4, 158356) Congress Bulletin, No.

('80', 109, 6, 10, 178054) 195. FOREWORD TO “THE PARTING OF THE WAYS” 1
('80', 109, 7, 11, 178099) The Parting of the Ways should have appeared when it was finished, i.e., immediately after August 10. By some mischance it has escaped publication till now.
('80', 109, 7, 12, 178256) It has just come into my possession.
('80', 109, 7, 13, 178293) I understand that some portions of the article have already appeared in Asia.
('80', 109, 7, 14, 178371) I think it is too precious a document to be withheld from the public.
('80', 109, 7, 15, 178441) I have shown it to Dr. Rajendra Prasad and Acharya Kripalani who are in Wardha.
('80', 109, 7, 16, 178521) They agree with me that it should be published on behalf of the A.I.C.C. I know that Sarojini Devi, if she was here, would also agree.
('80', 109, 7, 17, 178656) I believe that it correctly represents in moderate, though forcible language, the Congress position.
('80', 109, 7, 18, 178757) The passages quoted above 2 are key paragraphs.
('80', 109, 7, 19, 178805) The first extract shows what might have been.
('80', 109, 7, 20, 178851) The second declares the author’s love for the British people.
('80', 109, 7, 21, 178913) The third shows in the fewest possible words how the British Government in India is sustained by coercion pure and simple.
('80', 109, 7, 22, 179036) The fourth paragraph shows that the independence India wants is neither exclusive nor antagonistic to any nation.
('80', 109, 8, 23, 179150) 1 Written by Jawaharlal Nehru, this article dated August 10, 1940, was published by the A.I.C.C. on March 18, 1941. 2 Vide “Extracts from “Parting of the ways”.
('80', 110, 0, 1, 179311) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 111
('80', 110, 1, 2, 179359) Though the author has said not one word about non violence, he has led the reader to the inevitable conclusion that the independence of Jawaharlal’s conception, nay, Congress conception cannot be won except through unadulterated non violence, and the present struggle is an attempt to keep the spirit of non violence alive in the midst of the fratricidal inhuman carnage.
('80', 110, 1, 3, 179731) If it is a contribution to India’s freedom it is no less contribution to world peace.
('80', 110, 2, 4, 179817) M. K. GANDHI SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, March 16, 1941
('80', 110, 3, 5, 179863) The Parting of the Ways

('80', 111, 3, 12, 181470) 198. INSTRUCTIONS TO SATYAGRAHIS 1
('80', 111, 4, 13, 181505) [Before March 17, 1941]
('80', 111, 5, 14, 181529) Don’t bring persons from villages into towns for offering satyagraha.
('80', 111, 6, 15, 181599) Satyagrahis, if not arrested, may do house to house propaganda but it should not take the form of picketing.
('80', 111, 6, 16, 181708) Satyagrahis should not enter the houses where they are not welcome.
('80', 111, 7, 17, 181776) Persons serving in local bodies should resign from the services before offering satyagraha.
('80', 111, 8, 18, 181868) When a Congress Committee is suspended, its work should be entrusted to an approved satyagrahi.
('80', 111, 9, 19, 181964) Lady satyagrahis, if unable to march to Delhi, may tour in their own districts and province.
('80', 111, 10, 20, 182057) Satyagrahis marching to Delhi should obtain a working knowledge of Hindustani.
('80', 111, 11, 21, 182136) Satyagrahis charged under the Nuisance Act may not offer any defence.
('80', 111, 11, 22, 182206) They may make it clear that their sole intention was to carry on anti war propaganda, and plead not guilty to the nuisance charge.
('80', 111, 12, 23, 182337) Harijan Congress workers should devote themselves to constructive work.
('80', 111, 13, 24, 182409) Satyagrahi prisoners may refuse food only if it is unwholesome and uneatable.
('80', 111, 14, 25, 182487) Satyagrahis who are let off with fines should continue the satyagraha without giving a fresh notice.
('80', 111, 15, 26, 182588) Satyagrahis able to pay the fine may not evade payment, but are not bound to
('80', 111, 16, 27, 182665) 1 Issued by A.I.C.C. as “instructions given by Mahatma Gandhi for the guidance of satyagrahis”
('80', 112, 0, 1, 182760) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 113
('80', 112, 1, 2, 182808) sell their property to pay it.
('80', 112, 2, 3, 182839) For the facility and convenience of village folk, non arrested satyagrahis should be provided with a certificate or a badge on the authority of the Provincial Congress Committee, testifying to his being an approved satyagrahi.
('80', 112, 2, 4, 183066) The badge may differ from province to province.
('80', 112, 3, 5, 183114) Satyagraha may not be offered in a place where Section 144 is in force.
('80', 112, 4, 6, 183186) Fetters and handcuffs, etc., should be borne cheerfully when being transferred from one jail to another.
('80', 112, 4, 7, 183291) Non arrested satyagrahis marching to Delhi should, besides raising anti war slogans and otherwise carrying on anti war propaganda, propagate the constructive programme of the Congress.
('80', 112, 4, 8, 183476) It must be explained to the masses that the best and most effective as also the easiest way in which they can help forward the struggle is by carrying out the constructive programme laid before the country by our leader.
('80', 112, 4, 9, 183697) The Bombay Chronicle, 17 3 1941

('80', 120, 7, 26, 197311) 213. APPEAL TO CONGRESS WORKERS
('80', 120, 8, 27, 197343) March 21, 1941
('80', 120, 9, 28, 197358) The National Week 2 will be soon upon us.
('80', 120, 9, 29, 197400) Its observance has a double purpose: (1) to achieve self purification through fasting on the 6th and 13th April, and (2) to increase mass consciousness by greater concentration on constructive work.
('80', 120, 9, 30, 197599) The 6th of April 1919 saw exhibition of a sudden and unexpectedly high spirit of swadeshi and mass manifestation of communal unity and a determination on the
('80', 120, 10, 31, 197757) 1 Manu J. Gandhi, addressee’s daughter 2 Observed in commemoration of the total hartal on April 6, 1919, in protest against the Rowlatt Act (Bill No.
('80', 120, 10, 32, 197907) 29, 1919) and the Jallianwala Bagh massacre on April 13 of the same year
('80', 121, 0, 1, 197980) 122 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 121, 1, 2, 198022) part of Congress Hindus to get rid of the canker of untouchability from Hinduism.
('80', 121, 1, 3, 198104) The spirit of swadeshi centred itself on khadi as it was the central village industry of a universal character.
('80', 121, 1, 4, 198216) During the twenty years since 1919 the constructive programme has widened.
('80', 121, 1, 5, 198291) The other village industries have found expression through the A.I.V.I.A. 1. Education has been linked with the villagers through Hindustani Talimi Sangh.
('80', 121, 1, 6, 198446) There has been greater concentration on impressing women in the national service and, therefore, regarding them as valued co workers on a par with men.
('80', 121, 1, 7, 198598) The widening and working of the constructive programme is the only way in which active non violence can express itself.
('80', 121, 1, 8, 198718) Civil disobedience comes, if it must, at the end of the constructive programme, never in the beginning.
('80', 121, 1, 9, 198822) We saw through experience that we had to retrace our steps in 1919 as civil resistance had been resorted to without preparation through constructive service.
('80', 121, 1, 10, 198980) Disobedience of laws can never be civil unless the resisters have learnt the art of voluntary obedience.
('80', 121, 1, 11, 199085) This is impossible without tangible co operative work requiring exact discipline and voluntary and whole hearted obedience to rules and regulations.
('80', 121, 1, 12, 199234) Civil resistance is merely lawful and obligatory only in some cases, whereas constructive work is obligatory on all who belong to a non violent organization.
('80', 121, 1, 13, 199392) And civil resistance can be effective only when it is backed by constructive effort on a mass scale.
('80', 121, 1, 14, 199493) Success of civil resistance can be measured by the success of constructive effort.
('80', 121, 1, 15, 199576) Therefore, I hope that all Congress workers will, during the National Week from 6th to 13th April, devote their time to the constructive programme.
('80', 121, 1, 16, 199724) Khadi and other village industries have always played a prominent part in the programme.
('80', 121, 1, 17, 199813) For, all young and old, men and women can take part in it and the work can be measured in arithmetical terms.
('80', 121, 1, 18, 199923) It is to be hoped that the response will be much greater than ever before.

('80', 125, 0, 1, 204544) 126 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 125, 1, 2, 204586) 219. LETTER TO KRISHNACHANDRA
('80', 125, 2, 3, 204616) SEVAGRAM, March 22, 1941
('80', 125, 3, 4, 204641) KRISHNACHANDRA, What you said yesterday was correct, and was timely.
('80', 125, 3, 5, 204710) If you are still not satisfied, ask again and again.
('80', 125, 3, 6, 204763) The matter is important.
('80', 125, 3, 7, 204788) Therein lies the test of ahimsa.
('80', 125, 3, 8, 204821) Both were attracted towards each other.
('80', 125, 3, 9, 204861) If this is considered a defect and they are turned out, their lives can be embittered.
('80', 125, 3, 10, 204948) If we tolerate them, their self control can increase, and they can progress step by step.
('80', 125, 3, 11, 205038) Their progress depends on us.
('80', 125, 3, 12, 205068) This line of thought is in favour of their staying [in the Ashram], and this should be sufficient.
('80', 125, 3, 13, 205167) We should put up with the temper of others to the extent that we ourselves are not weighed down by it.
('80', 125, 3, 14, 205270) A proof of this is that others are influenced by us.
('80', 125, 3, 15, 205323) This is an outward proof.
('80', 125, 3, 16, 205349) Inner proof is the testimony of the soul.
('80', 125, 3, 17, 205391) If our fearlessness goes on increasing, it is ahimsa, otherwise it is cowardice.
('80', 125, 3, 18, 205472) It may be said that in Kocharab [Ashram] 1 the whole work was in order.
('80', 125, 3, 19, 205544) The other things were subject to it.
('80', 125, 3, 20, 205581) In outward work there was there the same discipline that I had in South Africa.
('80', 125, 3, 21, 205661) I used to engage the visitors in the Ashram work or they left soon after they came.
('80', 125, 3, 22, 205745) My physique could bear the strain of laborious work, so I could take part in every activity; and it may be said that I was in constant touch with all.
('80', 125, 3, 23, 205896) There was one big living room.
('80', 125, 3, 24, 205927) So it was easy to come in touch with others.
('80', 125, 3, 25, 205972) This is about the early stage.
('80', 125, 3, 26, 206003) Whole work means to fill water early in the morning, to wash clothes, to cook food, to clean grains and vegetables, to serve food, to teach, and so on.
('80', 125, 3, 27, 206155) These things being one after the other were not troublesome.
('80', 125, 3, 28, 206216) The rest of the questions were answered yesterday.
('80', 125, 3, 29, 206267) Your letter is enclosed.
('80', 125, 3, 30, 206292) Ask, if anything still remains.
('80', 125, 3, 31, 206324) Blessings from BAPU
('80', 125, 4, 32, 206344) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 4379
('80', 125, 5, 33, 206385) 1 Started by Gandhiji on May 25, 1915, it was housed in Jeevanlal Vrajrai Desai’s bungalow in Ahmedabad, where it continued till Sabarmati Ashram was founded in 1917.

('80', 126, 7, 8, 206833) SEVAGRAM, via WARDHA, [Before March 23, 1941] 2
('80', 126, 8, 9, 206881) Tell Mr. Jayakar that I should always be delighted to meet old friends.
('80', 126, 8, 10, 206953) But while I may personally discuss every aspect with them, I could not, without consultation with the members of the Working Committee, give them any assurance, armed with which they might go to the Viceroy.
('80', 126, 8, 11, 207161) For they would need the assurance on behalf of the Congress Working Committee and I have no authority to give it.

('80', 126, 8, 14, 207436) Otherwise of course I could not have the slightest objection to meeting them.

('80', 140, 8, 19, 226074) 251. THE ONLY WAY TOWARDS WORLD PEACE
('80', 140, 9, 20, 226112) Deep inside me I have an ever growing faith that in the midst of this universal destruction due to bloodshed, I am carrying on an absolutely innocuous struggle which, however, is pregnant with great potentialities.
('80', 140, 10, 21, 226327) The movement, for the conduct of which I am responsible, may prove a vain effort, if I represent no one but myself; and if I remain true to my faith, I may be satisfied, but so far as world peace is concerned, the effort will prove inadequate in terms of the present.
('80', 140, 10, 22, 226595) For producing the desired result during the lifetime of the present generation, it will be necessary to give an unmistakable demonstration that a substantial part of the nation is behind the effort.
('80', 140, 10, 23, 226794) Much more
('80', 140, 11, 24, 226804) 1 The following two paragraphs are reproduced from The Hindu, 6 5 1941.
('80', 141, 0, 1, 226876) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDH
('80', 141, 1, 2, 226917) has to hope before such a demonstration becomes possible.
('80', 141, 1, 3, 226975) The present movement is a humble attempt in that direction.
('80', 141, 1, 4, 227035) Man can only make an honest attempt.
('80', 141, 1, 5, 227072) In a satyagraha movement, the saying that God is the giver of the result is literally true.
('80', 141, 1, 6, 227164) Therefore, it is faith that sustains me and it is faith that must sustain the other satyagrahis.
('80', 141, 1, 7, 227261) We have only begun the battle.
('80', 141, 1, 8, 227292) The real test, the real suffering, has yet to come.
('80', 141, 1, 9, 227344) Let me repeat for the thousandth time that, in this long and arduous struggle, quality alone will count, never quantity.
('80', 141, 1, 10, 227465) In this there is no room for hatred, certainly not for camouflage.
('80', 141, 1, 11, 227532) Despite my being the originator of this struggle, I venture to say that only through it can we hope for permanent world peace.
('80', 141, 1, 12, 227659) Peace can never come through war.
