('80', 153, 1, 2, 244140) 276. LETTER TO MUNNALAL G. SHAH
('80', 153, 2, 3, 244172) SEVAGRAM, April 4, 1941
('80', 153, 3, 4, 244196) MUNNALAL, Better is death in the discharge of one’s duty; another’s duty is frought with danger.
('80', 153, 4, 5, 244293) You must, therefore, concentrate at present on your examinations.
('80', 153, 4, 6, 244359) They will prove to be kamadhenu 2 for you.
('80', 153, 4, 7, 244402) There are bound to be some defects in the examinations.
('80', 153, 4, 8, 244458) Even to have these reformed, you have to appear for them.
('80', 153, 4, 9, 244516) I see much good in your doing so.
('80', 153, 4, 10, 244550) That village may be regarded as reformed, where everybody wears khadi, which produces all the khadi it needs, in which every inhabitant spends some of his time in one or more processes relating to cotton, which uses only oil produced in indigenous oil presses, which consumes only jaggery manufactured in the village itself or in its neighbourhood and only hand milled flour and hand pounded rice; the village, in other words, where the largest possible number of village industries are flourishing, in which nobody is illiterate, where the roads are clean, there is a fixed place for evacuation, the wells are clean, there is harmony among the different communities, and untouchability is completely absent, in which everybody gets cow’s milk, ghee, etc., in moderate quantities, in which nobody is without work, and which is free from quarrels and thefts, and in which the people abide by the sevak’s advice in all matters.
('80', 153, 4, 11, 245476) This is possible in the existing conditions.
('80', 153, 4, 12, 245521) I cannot of course say about the time required.
('80', 153, 4, 13, 245569) Blessings from BAPU

('80', 163, 1, 2, 258382) 294. SATATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('80', 163, 2, 3, 258411) WARDHAGANJ, April 8, 1941
('80', 163, 3, 4, 258437) I have seen what purports to be a report 1 by some ‘special correspondent’ of an interview by Shri Mukundlal Sircar and Shri R. S. Ruikar with me.
('80', 163, 3, 5, 258584) I have no hesitation in saying that it is a mischievous distortion of a friendly conversation.
('80', 163, 3, 6, 258679) I rarely give interviews.
('80', 163, 3, 7, 258705) When I do, I insist on seeing the draft before publication.
('80', 163, 3, 8, 258765) So far as I know, there was no one in my cottage who could send any reports.
('80', 163, 3, 9, 258842) I should hope that none of the two friends has become a ‘special correspondent’.
('80', 163, 3, 10, 258923) I repeat my request that Editors will confer a favour on me if, before publishing interviews with me, they will make sure that I have authorized them.
('80', 163, 3, 11, 259074) I would not mind any amount of misrepresentation, if it did not injure a public cause.
('80', 163, 4, 12, 259161) The Bombay Chronicle, 9 4 1941

('80', 172, 1, 2, 269462) 314. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('80', 172, 2, 3, 269494) SEVAGRAM, April 12, 1941
('80', 172, 3, 4, 269519) PREMA, I had your letter written from Saswad.
('80', 172, 3, 5, 269565) Yesterday I got the one written from jail.
('80', 172, 3, 6, 269608) I was delighted to read the account of conditions there.
('80', 172, 3, 7, 269665) I am sure that, if all the women live in harmony and do constructive work with faith, they will bring swaraj nearer.
('80', 172, 3, 8, 269782) On the 6th everybody here, excepting the children and the sick, fasted for twenty four hours.
('80', 172, 3, 9, 269876) Today also we intend to do the same.
('80', 172, 3, 10, 269913) Non stop working of some charkhas, one carding bow and several taklis is in progress.
('80', 172, 3, 11, 269999) Babla and Kanu had a big hand in arranging this.
('80', 172, 3, 12, 270048) All are working with zeal.
('80', 172, 3, 13, 270075) And now for your questions: 1. All that I can say about fasting is that it is part of my life.
('80', 172, 3, 14, 270170) A fast may come any time.
('80', 172, 3, 15, 270196) At the moment, however, I am not thinking of any.
('80', 172, 3, 16, 270246) But my strength comes from the possibility of my undertaking one and from my faith in the method.
('80', 172, 3, 17, 270344) In the last resort a satyagrahi vindicates his honour by laying down his life, as one who believes in violence does by killing.
('80', 172, 3, 18, 270472) What a big difference!
('80', 172, 3, 19, 270495) Let nobody, therefore, look upon the possibility of a fast by me as the sword of Damocles.
('80', 172, 3, 20, 270586) If the fast does come, welcome it and pray that God may grant me the strength to go through it.
('80', 172, 3, 21, 270682) 2. Harijan was stopped because of an unexpected letter 1 from Delhi.
('80', 172, 3, 22, 270751) I could see from it that they were not well disposed towards the paper, and I do not want it to be made an issue in this struggle.
('80', 172, 3, 23, 270882) 3. The current political developments have had no effect on me, for I have realized that nothing is possible just now.
('80', 172, 3, 24, 271001) That is why I have said that this is going to be a long struggle.
('80', 172, 3, 25, 271067) On the whole our good lies in that.
('80', 172, 3, 26, 271103) Mahadev has again gone today to Bombay for a day.
('80', 172, 3, 27, 271153) He has gone leaving Durga ill here.
('80', 172, 3, 28, 271189) Both are courageous.
('80', 172, 3, 29, 271210) They have willingly sacrificed themselves.
('80', 172, 3, 30, 271253) My blessings to all the women.
('80', 172, 4, 31, 271284) 1 Vide “Sir Richard Tottenham’s Letter to Mahadev Desai”, 27 3 1941

('80', 174, 0, 1, 272467) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1940 175
('80', 174, 1, 2, 272515) 317. STATEMENT FOR RAMAKRISHNA BAJAJ 1
('80', 174, 2, 3, 272554) [On or before April 14, 1941] 2
('80', 174, 3, 4, 272586) SIR, Mine is a case somewhat out of the ordinary.
('80', 174, 3, 5, 272636) I am an ex student.
('80', 174, 3, 6, 272656) It is necessary to mention this fact in these days of anarchy that prevails in the student world.
('80', 174, 3, 7, 272754) Though I am under eighteen, I have known enough of the student world and the world outside to realize the necessity of discipline in everything.
('80', 174, 3, 8, 272899) In the step I have taken I have, therefore, obtained the blessings of my parents and other elders.
('80', 174, 3, 9, 272998) Under my parents I have had practical training in non violence in every detail of life.
('80', 174, 3, 10, 273086) I have just finished my matriculation examination.
('80', 174, 3, 11, 273137) I began school work rather late in life.
('80', 174, 3, 12, 273178) My parents had stopped our regular school work during the non co operation days of 1920 when I was not even born.
('80', 174, 3, 13, 273292) My parents have brought us all up in a free atmosphere.
('80', 174, 3, 14, 273348) And so when I was minded to go to school and go through the ordinary training, I was permitted to do so.
('80', 174, 3, 15, 273453) When, however, the present struggle was started, my mind began to waver and I felt that the practical experience I should gain in the pursuit of freedom would be of far greater value than the ordinary schooling which every schoolboy knows is conceived not so much in the interest of the masses as that of the rulers.
('80', 174, 3, 16, 273770) If in spite of that knowledge we go through that course, it is because it is the only one that has been in vogue for so many years and which serves the purpose of providing a status in life.
('80', 174, 3, 17, 273961) Such is the fate to which we have been reduced through foreign domination.
('80', 174, 3, 18, 274036) I have been attracted to the present struggle more for its moral worth than the political.
('80', 174, 3, 19, 274127) I know that if India can present a completed example of non violence, India will have made a unique contribution to human progress.
('80', 174, 3, 20, 274259) It is a vision that holds my youthful mind and I would count no suffering too great to achieve an end so noble and glorious.
('80', 174, 4, 21, 274384) Panchven Putrako Bapuke Ashirvad, pp.
('80', 174, 5, 22, 274422) 1 In the source, D. B. Kalelkar explains that this was drafted by Gandhiji for being read out by Ramakrishna Bajaj in the court.
('80', 174, 5, 23, 274551) Gandhiji had explained the statement to Ramakrishna Bajaj at Sevagram on April 14, a day before he offered civil disobedience; vide “Letter to Deputy Commissioner, Wardha”, 12 4 1941 2 ibid

('80', 181, 4, 10, 283014) 331. STATEMENT TO “THE TIMES OF INDIA” 1
('80', 181, 5, 11, 283055) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, April 19, 1941 I have very carefully listened to the advance Press notes of The Times of India’s leading article which must have appeared this morning in Bombay.
('80', 181, 5, 12, 283235) I acknowledge the friendly tone of the article, and I wish I could have given an encouraging reply; but I cannot.
('80', 181, 5, 13, 283349) I adhere to all that I said at the initiation of the struggle 2. When I launched out, I had no foolish illusion about a sudden miracle happening.
('80', 181, 5, 14, 283495) It was conceived to be, and it remains, a silent declaration of unquenchable faith in the power of non violence even in the midst of circumstances so terrible and so baffling as face the world today.
('80', 181, 5, 15, 283695) I believe more in the efficacy of the incalculable force of inscrutable divinity than in the efficacy of the calculated and calculable forces that the combined powers of destruction can bring into play on this little planet.
('80', 181, 5, 16, 283920) That incalculable force has somehow or the other to act through human agency.
('80', 181, 5, 17, 283998) How and when I cannot say.
('80', 181, 5, 18, 284025) Whether that agency is the Congress or not, I cannot say.
('80', 181, 5, 19, 284083) I proceed upon the faith that today the Congress is the only organization, however imperfect, however wanting in faith as an organization, still the only organization that stands definitely for peaceful measures.
('80', 181, 5, 20, 284296) That being my position, so far as I am concerned, there is no drawing back.
('80', 181, 5, 21, 284372) Whether civil disobedience is offered by one or many is of no moment.
('80', 181, 5, 22, 284442) It must continue against all odds.
('80', 181, 5, 23, 284477) Congressmen can
('80', 181, 6, 24, 284493) 1 This was given to the special correspondent, who met Gandhiji for an answer to the appeal by The Times of India for the withdrawal of the Civil Disobedience Movement.
('80', 181, 6, 25, 284662) 2 In October 1940
('80', 182, 0, 1, 284680) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 183
('80', 182, 1, 2, 284728) certainly repudiate it in more ways than one.
('80', 182, 1, 3, 284774) It will then cease to be an organizational movement, and therefore I will admit it will cease to be effective in any shape or form.
('80', 182, 1, 4, 284906) But I would be content if I still retain the faith to be the solitary witness of the power of non violence.
('80', 182, 1, 5, 285014) I must resolutely deny that this movement, whether in conce ption or in execution, is communal or anti Muslim or anti English.
('80', 182, 1, 6, 285141) There is sufficient evidence for those who want to notice it to show that extraordinary precaution is being taken to keep the movement within limits and absolutely innocuous.
('80', 182, 1, 7, 285316) Many Government people have admitted that it is wholly ineffective according to their conception.
('80', 182, 1, 8, 285414) The writer of the article has said as much from his standpoint.
('80', 182, 1, 9, 285478) And both are right.
('80', 182, 1, 10, 285498) It was never intended that it would create an appreciable impression upon the war effort, but it is a moral, and from that standpoint a grand protest against the conduct of the war in the name of a free people.
('80', 182, 1, 11, 285709) It is a token of the yearning of a political organization to achieve the freedom of 350,000,000 people through purely non violent effort and therefore to affect the future destiny of the world.
('80', 182, 1, 12, 285903) Again an ambitious claim, but it is there.
('80', 182, 1, 13, 285946) If I can help it, the Congress will disdain freedom at the sacrifice of a single legitimate interest that is consistent with the interests of the dumb millions, whether they are Hindus, Muslims or others.
('80', 182, 1, 14, 286151) I must deny that if the Congress had held on to office in the seven provinces the Pakistan cry would have been less loud than it is today; but the giving up of office had an infinitely more moral basis than the avoidance of a tussle with Muslim interests or any other interests.
('80', 182, 1, 15, 286430) The fundamental basis was India’s dissociation from the war effort to which it was never invited to be party.
('80', 182, 1, 16, 286540) This is putting it in its lowest term and in bald political language.
('80', 182, 1, 17, 286610) As you snow, my own basis is still more abstract, still more moral and still more universal, but on that account none the less real or less practical.
('80', 182, 1, 18, 286761) I make bold to say that when the clash of arms has ceased and we have settled down to peace, permanent or impermanent, history will record that the Congress fight in its totality was a supremely moral fight and free from any injury to man’s dignity.
('80', 182, 1, 19, 287011) To conclude this very unsatisfactory reply, as it would appear, to a friendly gesture, I want to plead one thing.
('80', 182, 1, 20, 287125) Would friends ask me at this supreme moment in the life of the world and my own life, to deny a faith that has sustained me for nearly half a century?
('80', 182, 1, 21, 287276) And let me
('80', 183, 0, 1, 287287) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 183, 1, 2, 287329) interpolate one thought, however unwelcome it may be: I am con vinced that if Britain will only be true to India, then, whether the Congress withdraws the struggle or not, everything can be settled satisfactorily.
('80', 183, 1, 3, 287543) But unfortunately British statesmen have chosen the wrong path and have put imaginary obstacles in the way of India’s freedom.
('80', 183, 1, 4, 287670) But that is a chapter on which I have no desire to dilate.
('80', 183, 2, 5, 287729) The Times of India, 20 4 1941
('80', 183, 3, 6, 287759) 332. LETTER TO DUNICHAND
('80', 183, 4, 7, 287784) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, April 19, 1941
('80', 183, 5, 8, 287817) DEAR LALA DUNICHANDJI,
('80', 183, 6, 9, 287840) I arrived here on the 16th evening but was only able to put your questions before Gandhiji yesterday.
('80', 183, 7, 10, 287942) 1. In regard to M.L.A.s who in spite of reminders do not court imprisonment the question had better wait for an answer in view of Mian Iftikhar ud din’s 1 pending early release.
('80', 183, 8, 11, 288120) 2. The same applies to A.I.C.C. members whose date has already been extended to the 30th instant.
('80', 183, 9, 12, 288218) 3. Gandhiji is agreeable to having the spinning and weaving of certified khadi test done by the A.I.S.A. appointees.
('80', 183, 9, 13, 288335) He is, however, in agreement with you that those who cannot afford to or for some equally legitimate reason are unable to present themselves before the appointed examiners and who can get the necessary certificate of bona fides from the President or Secretary of District Congress Committees may be exempted from the A.I.S.A. test.
('80', 183, 10, 14, 288667) 4. In regard to members of local bodies resigning, the matter had better wait till Mian Iftikhar ud din’s release.
('80', 183, 11, 15, 288782) 5. The same as regards Congressmen of all grades who refuse to offer civil disobedience.
('80', 183, 12, 16, 288871) 6. Members of the Provincial Congress Committees are included among the number that is to offer civil disobedience.
('80', 183, 13, 17, 288987) 7. Members of Working Committees of all grades are to offer civil disobedience.
('80', 183, 14, 18, 289067) 8. Gandhiji fears that no undertaking of loyalty to the movement will be worth anything with those who are determined to deceive.

('80', 185, 0, 1, 291087) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 185, 1, 2, 291129) 334. LETTER TO KHWAJA
('80', 185, 2, 3, 291151) SEVAGRAM, April 20, 1941
('80', 185, 3, 4, 291176) MY DEAR KHWAJA, I was much touched by your long letter.
('80', 185, 3, 5, 291232) I had your note too from Delhi.
('80', 185, 3, 6, 291264) I am glad you met Ba.
('80', 185, 3, 7, 291286) You will have no difficulty in believing me that I am the same confirmed believer in unity that you saw in 1919. Let me correct you about dates and facts.
('80', 185, 3, 8, 291441) I presided at the Hindi Sammelan in 1918 1 and that with the deliberate intention of making Hindi inclusive, not exclusive.
('80', 185, 3, 9, 291565) There was no criticism then of my presiding.
('80', 185, 3, 10, 291610) Muslim friends were enthusiastic about my definition of Hindi.
('80', 185, 3, 11, 291673) At that time it was only my definition when I presided.
('80', 185, 3, 12, 291729) Again my definition was accepted by the Sammelan.
('80', 185, 3, 13, 291779) How could there be criticism when I broadened the basis so as to give recognition to Urdu script on a Hindi platform?
('80', 185, 3, 14, 291897) The first note of opposition was sounded when I attempted to use Hindi as a term synonymous with Hindustani.
('80', 185, 3, 15, 292006) Again it was an attempt in the right direction.
('80', 185, 3, 16, 292054) But I had lost caste by then and every act of mine had begun to be suspect.
('80', 185, 3, 17, 292130) Into the causes for this phenomenon I need not go.
('80', 185, 3, 18, 292181) But from the above narrative it is clear that nothing that I have done could possibly be a cause for the Hindi Urdu controversy.
('80', 185, 3, 19, 292310) But the controversy having arisen, I could not escape unscathed.
('80', 185, 3, 20, 292375) I would not call the Sammelan 2 a communal organization any more than I would so call t he Urdu Anjuman 3. Both forms exist and votaries of both also exist.
('80', 185, 3, 21, 292532) There need be no rivalry between the two but the wretched spirit which has nothing to do with the languages pervadesevery department of life.
('80', 185, 3, 22, 292674) When it goes, as it will and must some day, the languages will remain what they are but they will provide us no food for quarrel.
('80', 185, 3, 23, 292804) Meanwhile both are subserving the common cause.
('80', 185, 3, 24, 292852) In the end the extreme forms which have no living reality behind them will disappear or will exist as corruptions of a past age.

('80', 195, 6, 6, 306504) 354. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('80', 195, 7, 7, 306532) WARDHA, April 25, 1941 I have read painfully the long report of the debate in the House of Commons on India.
('80', 195, 7, 8, 306641) Distress has been known to have softened people’s hearts and made them mindful of facts.
('80', 195, 7, 9, 306730) But Britain’s distress has evidently left Mr. Amery absolutely cold and untouched.
('80', 195, 7, 10, 306813) 1 This callousness makes me more than ever confirmed in my opinion that the Congress must abide by its policy of non violence in spite of the heavy odds facing it.
('80', 195, 7, 11, 306977) Mr. Amery has rendered no service to Great Britain by his contemptuous disregard of the situation as it exists in India and thefacts that stare one in the face.
('80', 195, 7, 12, 307138) He talks glibly of British rule having given peace to India.
('80', 195, 7, 13, 307199) Did he not know what was happening in Dacca and Ahmedabad?
('80', 195, 7, 14, 307258) Who was responsible for keeping the peace in these two places?
('80', 195, 7, 15, 307321) I hope he will not throw in my face the fact that Bengal, at any rate, has self government.
('80', 195, 7, 16, 307413) He knows what a mockery that self government is.
('80', 195, 7, 17, 307462) He knows what little power for such emergencies toy Ministers have, whether they wear the Congress label, the League label or any other.
('80', 195, 7, 18, 307599) I ask the very pertinent question: Why has this long spell of British rule left the people so emasculated as to disable them from standing up against a few hundred goondas?
('80', 195, 7, 19, 307772) It is a humiliating spectacle, more for the British than for us, to see thousands of people
('80', 195, 8, 20, 307864) 1 L. S. Amery, Secretary of State for India, moved a resolution in the House of Commons on April 22, 1941, to extend for another year the proclamation under which the Governors of Indian Provinces had assumed the powers of the Provincial Legislators.
('80', 196, 0, 1, 308115) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 197
('80', 196, 1, 2, 308163) running away from their homes through sheer fright, because a few hundred goondas have found a favourable atmosphere for resorting to arson, murder and loot The first act of any government worth the name would be to teach its people the art of self defence, but the foreign British Government had no concern about this fundamental welfare of India’s citizens and so it deprived the people of the use of arms.
('80', 196, 1, 3, 308572) All the handsome tribute that Mr. Amery pays to Indian troops falls flat on Indian soil, because, leaving aside Congress non violence for the time being, if India had been equipped and trained for self defence and if India had become a voluntary ally of Great Britain, I hold that all European Powers combined for destruction would not have touched Great Britain.
('80', 196, 1, 4, 308936) Mr. Amery has insulted Indian intelligence by reiterating ad nauseam that Indian political parties have but to agree among themselves and Great Britain will register the will of a united India.
('80', 196, 1, 5, 309130) I have repeatedly shown that it has been the traditional policy of Great Britain to prevent parties from uniting.
('80', 196, 1, 6, 309244) ‘Divide and rule’ has been Great Britain’s proud and ill conceived motto.
('80', 196, 1, 7, 309318) It is the British statesmen who are responsible for the divisions in India’s ranks, and the divisions will continue so long as the British sword holds India under bondage.
('80', 196, 1, 8, 309490) I admit that there is unfortunately an unbridgeable gulf between the Congress and the Muslim League.
('80', 196, 1, 9, 309591) Why do not British statesmen admit that it is after all a domestic quarrel?
('80', 196, 1, 10, 309667) Let them withdraw from India and I promise that the Gongress and the League and all other parties will find it to their interest to come together and devise a home made solution for the Government of India.
('80', 196, 1, 11, 309874) It may not be scientific; it may not be after any Western pattern; but it will be durable.
('80', 196, 1, 12, 309965) It may be that before we come to that happy state of affairs, we may have to fight amongst ourselves.
('80', 196, 1, 13, 310067) But if we agree not to invite the assistance of any outside power, the trouble will last perhaps a fortnight and it will not mean even one day’s destruction of human heads such as goes on in Europe today, for the simple reason that thanks to the British rule we are wholly unarmed.
('80', 196, 1, 14, 310349) Mr. Amery, in utter disregard of truth, misleads his ignorant audience that the Congress wants “all or nothing”.

('80', 197, 1, 3, 310899) Was that “all or nothing”?
('80', 197, 1, 4, 310926) With Mr. Amery’s state of mind, I suppose it is too much to expect him to have the elementary grace to acknowledge the studied moderation of the Congress in its desire not to embarrass the British Government whilst it is fighting for its very existence.

('80', 198, 1, 2, 313037) 355. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('80', 198, 2, 3, 313065) [April 25, 1941] 2
('80', 198, 3, 4, 313084) 1. In answer I must repeat my former statement that British statesmen and publicists have covered the whole Indian question with unreality.
('80', 198, 3, 5, 313224) The reality about the Times [of India] criticism is that nationalist India, for some reason or other, is against co operating in the war effort.
('80', 198, 3, 6, 313369) 3 But when one understands that the whole of India is a prison and that the jailers are able to make the prisoners do what they Iike, it is small wonder that the British Government is able to impress what money and recruits they like.
('80', 198, 3, 7, 313604) I have shown before now that the modern titled classes, including the ruling princes; are essentially a British creation.
('80', 198, 3, 8, 313726) 2. If the proposals 4 of the Bombay Conference are accepted in toto I shall admit that though the proposals are likely to be unacceptable by the Congress, their acceptance will be some evidence of a desire to part with power.
('80', 198, 3, 9, 313952) 3. To describe me as a dictator is laughable, if only because I have no sanction behind my instructions save the willing and affectionate endorsement thereof by Congressmen.
('80', 198, 3, 10, 314126) I have imposed no views on anybody.
('80', 198, 3, 11, 314162) Imposition of non violent views is a contradiction in terms.
('80', 198, 3, 12, 314223) It is true that I cannot change what is described as my policy because my policy is my creed.
('80', 198, 4, 13, 314317) I am amazed at Mr. Amery’s effrontery in saying that the Congress wants “all or nothing” and “refused even to discuss the matter”.
('80', 198, 4, 14, 314448) He knows that the Congress descended so far as to make the Poona offer and he should know that at Bombay when the Poona offer was withdrawn the Congress realized that the Government could not be expected at the present moment to grant the Congress demand, and therefore the resolution asked for freedom of speech which has been categorically refused.

('80', 199, 1, 2, 315292) Equally false is the description of the Congress as a totalitarian body with totalitarian ambitions.
('80', 199, 1, 3, 315393) The essence of totalitarianism is that it should have violent sanction behind it.
('80', 199, 1, 4, 315475) Mr. Amery knows that the Congress is pledged to non violence and I challenge him to produce a single instance of an authoritative resort to violence by the Congress to impose its will upon its opponents.
('80', 199, 1, 5, 315679) On a par with the foregoing two statements is Mr. Amery’s assertion that “the main constitutional task is inevitably for the moment far more in the hands of Indians themselves than in ours” when he knows that there is nothing in the hands of the Indians themselves, except to perform the almost impossible task of undoing the traditional policy of ‘divide and rule’.
('80', 199, 1, 6, 316046) Imagine a Hitler in occupation of England and successfully dividing Englishmen as Indians are divided in India and then mocking at them by saying, ‘I will ratify an agreement among you.’ I assert that in India we have Hitlerian rule however disguised it may be in softer terms.
('80', 199, 1, 7, 316324) And since he has chosen to disregard truth, I must not wonder at his deliberately misleading an ignorant audience by saying that individual civil disobedience has created a situation naturally embarrassing as it was meant to be.
('80', 199, 1, 8, 316553) The written letter stands, and it is that the Congress by its civil disobedience did not mean to embarrass.
('80', 199, 1, 9, 316661) That it has not proved embarrassing is acknowledged by Mr. Amery himself in his speech when he declared with great gusto that the Congress action has not affected the war effort in any part of India, “generous funds having flowed in from every class for every purpose of war or for mitigation of suffering”.
('80', 199, 1, 10, 316969) Instead of paying a tribute to the exemplary moderation of the Congress, he has gracelessly accused a half century old organization of doing what it has never intended and what, in fact, it has never done.
('80', 199, 1, 11, 317175) It makes me sad to think that the distress through which Great Britain is passing today has not sobered Mr. Amery even to the extent of respecting cold fact.

('80', 206, 1, 2, 325650) 369. LETTER TO EDITOR, “THE TIMES OF INDIA”
('80', 206, 2, 3, 325694) May 1, 1941
('80', 206, 3, 4, 325706) DEAR SIR, You write 1:
('80', 206, 4, 5, 325729) Mr. Amery may well retort that the “discrepancies” with which Mr. Gandhi charges him are also evident in the Congress leader’s statement 2. Certainly the accusation that India has been “emasculated” because of the alleged British policy of keeping her ‘‘wholly unarmed” comes strangely from the arch protagonist of non violence.
('80', 206, 4, 6, 326058) In 1908 3 when I first expounded the life saving and the life giving truth of ahimsa I wrote that disarmament was the blackest page in British history in India.
('80', 206, 4, 7, 326219) I repeated the same thing in 1918 4 when I was collecting recruits for the British army with a zeal that brought me serious illness and a fair measure of unpopularity.
('80', 206, 4, 8, 326387) My statement passed muster then.
('80', 206, 4, 9, 326420) But times have changed and I have become inconsistent for stating an unchallengeable fact.
('80', 206, 4, 10, 326511) I suggest that non violence cannot be imposed upon anyone.
('80', 206, 4, 11, 326570) It has to come from within.
('80', 206, 4, 12, 326598) The British measure was undertaken to make British rule safe, not to make the people non violent.
('80', 206, 4, 13, 326696) It has made them impotent even for mischief.
('80', 206, 4, 14, 326741) Good, impotent persons 5 can never do.
('80', 206, 4, 15, 326780) It is no matter for pride or credit that one representative of the British power can hold in abject subjection, say, a village of 1,000 souls.
('80', 206, 4, 16, 326923) My non violence does admit of people, who cannot or will not be non violent, holding and making effective use of arms.
('80', 206, 4, 17, 327042) Let me repeat for the thousandth time that non violence is of the strongest, not of the weak.
('80', 206, 4, 18, 327136) It is a force mightier than violence, though radically different from it in quality and effect.
('80', 206, 5, 19, 327232) Yours, M. K. GANDHI
('80', 206, 6, 20, 327252) From a facsimile: Mahatma” Vol. VI” between pp.
('80', 206, 6, 21, 327300) 48 and 49
('80', 206, 7, 22, 327310) 1 Under the column “Current Topics” in The Times of India” 28 4 1941 2 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 25 4 1941 3 A slip for “1909”.
('80', 206, 7, 23, 327443) The reference is to Hind Swaraj; 4 Vide “Appeal for Enlistment”, 22 6 1918 5 The source has “Good and impotent persons”.

('80', 207, 2, 3, 327638) May 1, 1941
('80', 207, 3, 4, 327650) MUNNALAL, I got your letter.
('80', 207, 3, 5, 327679) You must appear for the examination.
('80', 207, 3, 6, 327716) You must become proficient in khadi science, in respect of both production and sale.
('80', 207, 3, 7, 327801) After you have done that you are sure to settle down somewhere.
('80', 207, 3, 8, 327865) You must take all necessary measures for preserving your health.
('80', 207, 3, 9, 327930) But asking for everything to be sent from here will not help.
('80', 207, 3, 10, 327992) You will yourself feel embarrassed.
('80', 207, 3, 11, 328028) I had assumed that as per our agreement you would immediately return.
('80', 207, 3, 12, 328098) I still suggest that you do.
('80', 207, 3, 13, 328127) None the less, if you wish to stay on, you may, and see that you make good progress.

('80', 209, 5, 8, 330562) 376. LETTER TO MARGARET JONES
('80', 209, 6, 9, 330592) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, May 3, 1941
('80', 209, 7, 10, 330622) DEAR KAMALA, Yes, I had all your letters.
('80', 209, 7, 11, 330664) 3 I should have written earlier, but I
('80', 209, 8, 12, 330703) 1 This was sent in reply to the addressee’s telegram dated May 2, which read: “Mr. Jinnah, without reference to me, has released for publication my letter to him dated 6th February and his reply to me dated 10th February, 1941. I ask your permission to publish our correspondence beginning with 25th January and ending with 10th March, 1941. Please wire.” In his statement dated May 4, the addressee explained: “After reading day before yesterday the statement of Mr. Jinnah in the newspapers, issued from Mysore, and the correspondence between him and me, which he has released to the Press, I sent day before yesterday evening a telegram to Mahatma Gandhi.
('80', 209, 8, 13, 331362) Last evening, I received the .
('80', 209, 8, 14, 331393) reply from the Mahatma.
('80', 209, 8, 15, 331417) As Mr. Gandhi is agreeable to my releasing the correspondence which has taken place between him and me, I am issuing it to the Press.
('80', 209, 8, 16, 331551) In his statement, Mr. Jinnah says that he showed his willingness ‘to meet Mr. Gandhi or any other Hindu leader to have a heart to heart conversation’.
('80', 209, 8, 17, 331702) He would have been more accurate if he had drawn attention to the following sentence in his own letter to me: ‘I have always been ready and willing to see Mr. Gandhi or any other Hindu leader on behalf of the Hindu community and do all I can to help in the solution of the Hindu Muslim problem.” The words ‘on behalf of the Hindu community’, which he has omitted in his statement, but which are found in his letter, would go to show that he wanted Mr. Gandhi to see him in that professed capacity.
('80', 209, 8, 18, 332200) Mr. Gandhi, as will appear from his letter, was not in a position to agree to this condition.
('80', 209, 8, 19, 332294) There the matter ended, and it was no use my carrying the matter further with Mr. Jinnah.
('80', 209, 8, 20, 332384) .” For Gandhiji’s letters to the addressee 2 ibid 3 Gandhiji had asked the addressee to send him a fortnightly diary while she was under training in midwifery.
('80', 209, 8, 21, 332544) Vide also, ‘‘Letter to F. Mary Barr”, 31 3 1941

('80', 210, 1, 2, 332640) could not do so.
('80', 210, 1, 3, 332657) I was glad you were doing so well, and were keeping to the simple life.
('80', 210, 1, 4, 332729) Do continue to write.

('80', 210, 9, 19, 333413) 378. COMMUNAL RIOTS
('80', 210, 10, 20, 333433) SEVAGRAM, May 4, 1941 Hindu Muslim riots that have broken out in many important places in the country must have saddened all sane people.
('80', 210, 10, 21, 333571) My grief however is special.
('80', 210, 10, 22, 333600) The Congress influence seems to have been practically unfelt during the dark days.
('80', 210, 10, 23, 333683) We have proved ourselves barbarians and cowards in these places.
('80', 210, 10, 24, 333748) Arson, loot and killing of innocent people including children, have been common in almost all the places.
('80', 210, 10, 25, 333854) Thousands have run away
('80', 210, 11, 26, 333878) 1 According to the addressee this statement, dated May 1, was on “his mission to Dacca where a Hindu Muslim riot had broken out”.
('80', 210, 11, 27, 334008) 2 Vide “Letter to Satis Chandra Das Gupta”, 25 4 1941
('80', 211, 0, 1, 334062) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 211, 1, 2, 334104) from their homes for fear of their lives.
('80', 211, 1, 3, 334146) Congress influence was not to be measured by the number of members on the Congress register but by its leavening quality.
('80', 211, 1, 4, 334268) It has been shown clearly that the influence is negligible in riots and the like.
('80', 211, 1, 5, 334350) Individual cases apart, the Congress produced little or no influence over either the Muslims or the Hindus in the affected areas.
('80', 211, 1, 6, 334480) From the accounts received it seems that Muslim fanatics in Dacca and Ahmedabad did their worst in inflicting damage on Hindu property by looting and burning with a deliberation that showed premeditation.
('80', 211, 1, 7, 334685) Hindus, instead of boldly standing up and facing the mischief makers, fled in their thousands from the danger zone.
('80', 211, 1, 8, 334801) And where they did not, they were as barbarous as the assailants.
('80', 211, 1, 9, 334867) These were all untouched by the Congress non violence.
('80', 211, 1, 10, 334922) And yet these are the men who form the bulk of the Congress meetings.
('80', 211, 1, 11, 334992) If the Congress has no control over the masses on such occasions, there is not much value in Congress non violence as a positive force.
('80', 211, 1, 12, 335128) The Congress cannot take charge of the Government if the British suddenly withdraw.
('80', 211, 1, 13, 335212) They are not likely to do so without a desperate effort.
('80', 211, 1, 14, 335269) But British valour cannot make Congressmen brave or fit for shouldering the responsibility of Government.
('80', 211, 1, 15, 335375) At the present moment the British Government is preoccupied.
('80', 211, 1, 16, 335436) It is a marvel how they hold sway over four hundred million people.
('80', 211, 1, 17, 335504) Their amazing self confidence and their skill in the use of destructive weapons enable them to hold India in bondage.
('80', 211, 1, 18, 335622) But they may not be expected to keep the peace even to the extent they do in normal times.
('80', 211, 1, 19, 335713) They will ensure their control anyhow but they willallow us to kill one another and come in only when that control is in danger.
('80', 211, 1, 20, 335842) Congressmen’s course is clear.
('80', 211, 1, 21, 335873) They must examine the contents of their non violence.
('80', 211, 1, 22, 335927) If it does not go as far as the regulation of inter communal and such other relations, it is of no use for the acquisition of independence.
('80', 211, 1, 23, 336067) I prophesy that without pervasive non violence of the brave, when the question of real transfer of power comes, it won’t be the Congress who will have the privilege and the responsibility of delivering the goods.
('80', 211, 1, 24, 336280) The power will descend to those who are able to make effective use of violence.
('80', 211, 1, 25, 336360) In Europe two forces, equally matched in destructive skill and bravery, are ranged against one another.
('80', 211, 1, 26, 336464) The goal before both is domination.
('80', 211, 1, 27, 336500) In spite of all the will in the world, I have found no difference in kind between the two.
('80', 211, 1, 28, 336591) The difference in degree does not
('80', 212, 0, 1, 336625) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 213
('80', 212, 1, 2, 336673) interest me.
('80', 212, 1, 3, 336686) The British heel is bad enough for me.
('80', 212, 1, 4, 336725) As a man wedded to independence and non violence, I must fight Nazism and Fascism equally with the enslaving British Imperialism.
('80', 212, 1, 5, 336855) But has the Congress really the non violent strength even to fight this imperialism which we know through and through?
('80', 212, 1, 6, 336974) Hitherto it was a case of seizing power bit by bit.
('80', 212, 1, 7, 337026) But every Indian politician knows that there never was the slightest move on the part of the British to part with real power.
('80', 212, 1, 8, 337152) And now we have it in its nakedness from Mr. Amery that we may expect no such thing peacefully from British authority.
('80', 212, 1, 9, 337271) We have to fight for it either violently or non violently, whether it is the Congress or the League or the Hindu Mahasabha that fights for it.
('80', 212, 1, 10, 337414) I am satisfied that the two sectional organizations will never win independence for the masses, Hindu, Muslim, Christian, Sikh, Parsi, Jew.
('80', 212, 1, 11, 337554) The Congress is the only organization that has laboured for national solidarity from the beginning.
('80', 212, 1, 12, 337654) But that labour will be vain if the Congress does not prove true to its trust.
('80', 212, 1, 13, 337733) I do not mind Congressmen changing their creed in spite of many leaders being in jail or openly leaving the Congress.
('80', 212, 1, 14, 337851) I can see my way to rebuilding the Congress with five true men with whom there is neither Hindu nor Muslim nor any other.
('80', 212, 1, 15, 337973) Religion is a personal matter.
('80', 212, 1, 16, 338004) It ought not to affect the political field.
('80', 212, 1, 17, 338048) Then what should a Congressman do?
('80', 212, 1, 18, 338083) He must resolutely refuse to take sides and defend with his life and without the use of violence the person who is in distress as did for instance three women in Ahmedabad.
('80', 212, 1, 19, 338256) I have no doubt there are many such individual instances unknown to me.
('80', 212, 1, 20, 338328) Cowards will never bring peace or independence.
('80', 212, 1, 21, 338376) He must therefore tell the masses never to fly from danger and that if they cannot follow his way they must defend themselves in the best way they can.
('80', 212, 1, 22, 338528) What is required is a brave heart—a possession which is in nobody’s giving and which therefore can never be taken away.
('80', 212, 1, 23, 338648) He must instil into his neighbours the lesson that even violence can be both decent and indecent.
('80', 212, 1, 24, 338746) It is no bravery to kill unawares an innocent person because he does not belong to one’s religion or to burn his property.
('80', 212, 1, 25, 338869) Those who do so disgrace their religion and themselves and positively mar the effort for independence.
('80', 212, 1, 26, 338972) Let me give some further illustrations of what a Congressman should do in given circumstances.
('80', 212, 1, 27, 339067) A Congressman has no enemy.
('80', 212, 1, 28, 339095) While he will not seek the protection of the police or the military, he will not interfere with them in the performance of their duty but he will not hesitate to lose his life
('80', 213, 0, 1, 339271) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 213, 1, 2, 339313) if need be in checking them when they are partial or exceeding their authority.
('80', 213, 1, 3, 339393) This will appear a dangerous doctrine.
('80', 213, 1, 4, 339432) But it is not if it is enforced fully.
('80', 213, 1, 5, 339471) For if the Congressman concerned has erred, he will be the sufferer and not the police or the military.
('80', 213, 1, 6, 339575) I know that a young man, because he was brave, by timely interference saved perhaps a hundred lives by simply holding the bridle of an officer’s horse and telling him in firm accents, that he may not give the order to fire and that he—the young man—would reason with the crowd and disperse them.
('80', 213, 1, 7, 339871) Supposing there is a Hindu procession which has a right to pass through a Muslim locality and a Congressman has no influence over either, he will still give his life in begging a passage from the opposing Muslims.
('80', 213, 1, 8, 340085) The immediate result may be zero.
('80', 213, 1, 9, 340119) But the Congressman will have left a legacy of non violent bravery.
('80', 213, 1, 10, 340187) It will be good practice in non violence.
('80', 213, 1, 11, 340229) Let us learn from the British people the art of recklessly losing life and property.
('80', 213, 1, 12, 340314) The same rule applies to a Muslim procession passing through a Hindu locality.
('80', 213, 1, 13, 340393) We shall never learn the art of mutual forbearance and toleration till some of us, though perfectly innocent, have staggered Indian humanity by losing our lives.
('80', 213, 1, 14, 340555) A crowd is bent upon setting on fire the property of one community or another or desecrating a mosque or a temple.
('80', 213, 1, 15, 340670) Congr essmen whether one or many will give their lives to prevent mob fury.
('80', 213, 1, 16, 340746) A stray man attempts to stab a passer by.
('80', 213, 1, 17, 340788) At the risk of his life, a Congressman will pluck the knife out of the hands of the would be miscreant.
('80', 213, 1, 18, 340892) Congressmen may gasp on reading this note and particularly the illustrations and say ‘impossible’.
('80', 213, 1, 19, 340991) Well, attainment of indepen dence is still more impossible whether by violent or non violentmeans.
('80', 213, 1, 20, 341090) But what seems impossible to one lacking faith will become possible to those who have faith.
('80', 213, 1, 21, 341183) And it is said that faith can move mountains.
('80', 213, 1, 22, 341229) I know this, that neither independence nor communal unity is possible without ample sacrifice, bravery and self confidence which is but another name for faith.
('80', 213, 2, 23, 341389) Congress Bulletin, No.
('80', 213, 2, 24, 341412) 6, 1942, File No.

('80', 215, 4, 10, 343447) 382. LETTER TO MANUBEHN S. MASHRUWALA
('80', 215, 5, 11, 343485) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, May 5, 1941
('80', 215, 6, 12, 343515) MANUDI, I had your letter.

('80', 221, 9, 16, 352622) 394. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('80', 221, 10, 17, 352650) SEVAGRAM, May 7, 1941 I have just read an account of the unfortunate riots in Bihar.
('80', 221, 10, 18, 352735) As soon as a wire was received on the 3rd instant by Rajendra Babu from Shri Sachidanand Sinha that a dangerous situation was developing in Bihar, he responded by hastening to Bihar.
('80', 221, 10, 19, 352918) The account of the riots makes painful reading.
('80', 221, 10, 20, 352966) I have studied the various statements regarding them also.
('80', 221, 10, 21, 353025) Rajendra Babu has gone to Bihar to put in the whole of his weight in favour of sanity and peace.
('80', 221, 10, 22, 353122) This is his first wire to me after reaching there:
('80', 221, 11, 23, 353173) Situation improving but still panicky uncertain.
('80', 221, 11, 24, 353222) Mathura Babu 1, Shah Sahib 2
('80', 221, 12, 25, 353251) touring.
('80', 221, 12, 26, 353260) Myself proceeding with volunteers.
('80', 221, 13, 27, 353295) 1 Rajendra Prasad’s Secretary 2 Shah Mohammed Uzair Munimji 3 In his Autobiography Rajendra Prasad writes: “ .
('80', 221, 13, 28, 353406) I decided to go at once to Bihar Sharif.
('80', 221, 13, 29, 353447) Fortunately Abdul Bari arrived in Patna the same day and he consented to accompany me.
('80', 221, 13, 30, 353534) We engaged a couple of motor lorries and with a batch of teachers and students of Bihar Vidyapith and some other workers left for the place.
('80', 222, 0, 1, 353675) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 223
('80', 222, 1, 2, 353723) I know that he will give a good account of himself.
('80', 222, 1, 3, 353775) Peace will somehow be restored if it has not been already by the police and the military.
('80', 222, 1, 4, 353865) But this can only be a superimposed peace.
('80', 222, 1, 5, 353908) Rajendra Babu’s as every Congressman’s and for that matter every sane citizen’s business is to find out the cause of the riots.
('80', 222, 1, 6, 354036) Unless this is done, there is no likelihood of permanent peace.
('80', 222, 1, 7, 354100) I observe that the riots started with the resentment over the observance of Anti Pakistan Day 1. Pakistan and anti Pakistan observances and the like have come to stay.
('80', 222, 1, 8, 354268) As national consciousness grows and ambitions rise high, such observances will multiply.
('80', 222, 1, 9, 354357) But why can we not conduct ourselves decently in spite of these?
('80', 222, 1, 10, 354422) Why should we be so utterly intolerant as not to suffer one another’s views?
('80', 222, 1, 11, 354499) And then why should we show our intolerance as if we were savages?
('80', 222, 1, 12, 354566) I am quite convinced that the chief burden for the voluntary preservation of peace lies on the shoulders of the Congress, the oldest, the best organized and the most popular organization in India.
('80', 222, 1, 13, 354763) It must be admitted that the vast majority of Congress members are Hindus and Bihar is a predominantly Hindu province.
('80', 222, 1, 14, 354882) Therefore it should be comparatively easier for the Congress to ensure peace there without the aid of the police and the military.
('80', 222, 1, 15, 355013) It should be a point of honour for the stronger party to protect the weak against harm to life or property.
('80', 222, 1, 16, 355121) It is a difficult task but it has got to be tackled.
('80', 222, 1, 17, 355174) When I lay this burden on the Congress, I do not mean to suggest that the Congress alone should or can do it.
('80', 222, 1, 18, 355284) The Congress has to invoke the assistance of all parties, the Muslim League, the Hindu Mahasabha and others.
('80', 222, 1, 19, 355393) Each may have its political programme.
('80', 222, 1, 20, 355432) But if we are not intent upon imposing our respective programme on the opponents by force of arms, expressed today through goondaism, surely we may all agree that we shall settle all our differences through negotiation and peaceful effort including arbitration.
('80', 222, 1, 21, 355694) The Congress may fail to produce joint action.
('80', 222, 1, 22, 355741) If so, it will be a noble failure.
('80', 222, 1, 23, 355776) It must, however, continue to work even single handed, if its non violence has any meaning in it.
('80', 222, 1, 24, 355874) At present Bihar is the province that can lead the way and set the example.
('80', 222, 1, 25, 355950) Rajendra Babu has a gentle and unique hold in his province such as no other leader has.
('80', 222, 1, 26, 356038) He is the hero of the earthquake 2 days when the whole of India put its trust in him.
('80', 222, 1, 27, 356124) May he have too the privilege of being the messenger of peace in Bihar and through Bihar

('80', 249, 0, 1, 393580) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 249, 1, 2, 393622) 440. “KHADI JAGAT” 1
('80', 249, 2, 3, 393643) The sphere of Khadi Jagat is co extensive with that of the activities of the All India Spinners’ Association.
('80', 249, 2, 4, 393753) Theoretically speaking, the activities of the A. I. S. A. are unlimited.
('80', 249, 2, 5, 393826) At present it provides employment to 2,24,421 spinners, of whom 1,67,996 are Hindus and 56,425 are Muslims, along with 20,643 other artisans, such as ginners, carders, dyers, weavers and washermen.
('80', 249, 2, 6, 394024) The A. I. S. A. represents all those Hindus, Mussalmans, and others who are engaged in the various processes involved in the production of khadi, as also those who use khadi.
('80', 249, 2, 7, 394199) Although these people are at present a mere drop in the ocean of Indian humanity, they are numerous enough to be scattered throughout the length and breadth of the country.
('80', 249, 2, 8, 394372) The A. I S. A. is entirely a philanthropic institution.
('80', 249, 2, 9, 394428) It is the largest institution of its kind in India and perhaps in the world.
('80', 249, 2, 10, 394505) If the expectations formed about this institution materialize, the A. I. S. A. should represent the whole of the dumb and semi starved millions of India.
('80', 249, 2, 11, 394659) And if that event comes about, it would represent the aspirations of the whole of the submerged world.
('80', 249, 2, 12, 394762) The bloody massacre going on in the present war is probably a demonstration of the fact that industrialism will lead the world to destruction in the end.
('80', 249, 2, 13, 394916) Enlightened revival of handicrafts alone can save it.
('80', 249, 2, 14, 394970) But here I am talking of the future and God alone knows what the future has in store for us.
('80', 249, 2, 15, 395063) All the same there is such a thing in the world as human endeavour, and the endeavour of the A. I. S. A. is to propagate the spirit of khadi throughout India.
('80', 249, 2, 16, 395222) Then alone can we get rid of the grinding pauperism of India’s masses.
('80', 249, 2, 17, 395293) The word ‘khadi’ must be taken in its wider sense here.
('80', 249, 2, 18, 395349) For such extensive work, we require a much greater number of workers than have been hitherto available.
('80', 249, 2, 19, 395453) Those who are already engaged in this work have to cultivate greater capacity for sacrifice.
('80', 249, 2, 20, 395546) They must cultivate the habit of studying in a scientific spirit.
('80', 249, 2, 21, 395612) Their knowledge must be steadily progressive.
('80', 249, 2, 22, 395658) The wheel is the centre of this activity because it alone can give employment and living to the millions of women.
('80', 249, 2, 23, 395773) The wheel includes the takli.
('80', 249, 2, 24, 395803) It is not to be taken merely as the widow’smainstay.
('80', 249, 2, 25, 395856) It has been conceived as a symbol of India’s economic uplift,
('80', 249, 3, 26, 395918) 1 This appeared in the inaugural issue of Khadi Jagat, a Hindi monthly published by the A.I.S.A. from Wardha.
('80', 250, 0, 1, 396028) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 251
('80', 250, 1, 2, 396076) Hindu Muslim unity and therefore even of her independence in terms of her millions.
('80', 250, 1, 3, 396160) Thus the science of khadi is a lofty study.
('80', 250, 1, 4, 396204) Many experts are required to dedicate their energies in an organized manner for the furtherance of the cause.
('80', 250, 1, 5, 396314) These include economists as well as highly skilled mechanics.
('80', 250, 1, 6, 396376) A mason can build a village house, but it requires an engineer to plan and build a big building or a big dam.
('80', 250, 1, 7, 396486) Much more talent, knowledge, application and research are required to improve the village implements than to build a bridge on the Ganga.
('80', 250, 1, 8, 396624) When we are able to attract people of this type by our renunciation and methodical research, we will be able to make rapid far reaching progress, not till then.
('80', 250, 1, 9, 396785) Looking at it from this point of view, Khadi Jagat is not an insignificant venture.
('80', 250, 1, 10, 396869) It was because I regarded it as an ambitious venture that I supported the proposition of undertaking it.
('80', 250, 1, 11, 396974) I hope, therefore, that all the articles published in this magazine will be of the required standard and be earnestly studied by the A. I. S. A. workers and those interested in the uplift of the villages.
('80', 250, 1, 12, 397179) To carry on the activities of the A. I. S. A. we require workers as well as money.
('80', 250, 1, 13, 397262) The responsibility of getting both rests upon the Present khadi workers.
('80', 250, 1, 14, 397335) I think it will be well for me as the President of the A. I. S. A. at this stage to make a confession.
('80', 250, 1, 15, 397438) The Association has suffered a loss of over two lacs because of my and a co worker’s, call it carelessness, or overtrustfulness.
('80', 250, 1, 16, 397567) Thinking him to be a good man, Shankerlal Banker took a certain person on the A. I. S. A. staff.
('80', 250, 1, 17, 397664) He overtrusted this man and did not supervise his work as he ought to have.
('80', 250, 1, 18, 397740) His failing health was partly responsible for this.
('80', 250, 1, 19, 397792) Though the auditing of accounts was done regularly, this man very cunningly succeeded in outwitting everybody and misappropriating over two lacs of rupees.
('80', 250, 1, 20, 397948) This was detected when Shri Jajuji took charge of A. I. S. A. offlce.
('80', 250, 1, 21, 398018) The delinquent has confessed his guilt, though we have not succeeded in getting back the money as yet.
('80', 250, 1, 22, 398121) We are still trying for it.
('80', 250, 1, 23, 398149) The Sangh is following its traditional policy of avoiding the law courts as far as possible, but if it becomes necessary, there will be no hesitation in going to the courts.
('80', 250, 1, 24, 398323) The object of mentioning this incident here is to let the helpers of the A. I. S. A. learn of our carelessness and forgive us if possible.
('80', 250, 1, 25, 398462) I make the confession also in order that we may become more vigilant.
('80', 250, 1, 26, 398532) It is also hoped that as a result of this confession, workers of the A. I. S. A. all over the country will realize their responsibility and know that every pice mis 
('80', 251, 0, 1, 398698) 252 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 251, 1, 2, 398740) appropriated is so much taken out of the mouths of the poor.
('80', 251, 1, 3, 398801) It will be well if it can also awaken the guilty person to a sense of his duty.
('80', 251, 1, 4, 398881) It will comfort Shri Shankerlal Banker who in his simplicity had put too much trust in this man.
('80', 251, 1, 5, 398978) One thing I must not omit.
('80', 251, 1, 6, 399005) The Association has increased the wages of the spinners without any demand from the spinners themselves and completely ignoring the market wages.
('80', 251, 1, 7, 399151) This will be always looked upon as a creditable adventure for the A. I. S. A. The khadi lovers have helped the Association in this philanthropic move.
('80', 251, 1, 8, 399302) The price of khadi was bound to go up, but these friends willingly paid the extra price.
('80', 251, 1, 9, 399391) Consequently, khadi workers have a double duty to discharge.
('80', 251, 1, 10, 399452) They must see that in the first place the spinners get the full wages according to the standard laid down by the A. I. S. A. Secondly the customer buying khadi should be charged the minimum price compatible with the rise in the wages.
('80', 251, 1, 11, 399687) There should be no attempt at making profit.
('80', 251, 1, 12, 399732) If at some place profits have accrued they should be spent with the permission of the A. I. S. A. in lowering the price of khadi or otherwise in the interest of the poor.
('80', 251, 1, 13, 399903) The progress of khadi does not depend upon the ups and downs of the market.
('80', 251, 1, 14, 399979) It depends upon the purity of our transactions.
('80', 251, 1, 15, 400027) If our transactions are pure they must result in at least three things.
('80', 251, 1, 16, 400099) 1. We will attract spinners and artisans.
('80', 251, 1, 17, 400141) 2. The number of khadi wearers will increase and the necessary money will flow in, and 3. Greater number of workers will be attracted.
('80', 251, 1, 18, 400276) I say this on the strength of 55 years of public service.
('80', 251, 1, 19, 400334) It will be the endeavour of the Khadi Jagat to achieve the three ends or in other words Khadi Jagat will strive to induce in the workers an ambition for greater purity, greater dedication and greater knowledge.
('80', 251, 2, 20, 400545) M. K. GANDHI SEVAGRAM, May 15, 1941 [From Hindi] Khadi Jagat, 25 7 1941

('80', 252, 6, 13, 401023) 442. DISCUSSION WITH D. K. GOSAVI 1
('80', 252, 7, 14, 401059) May 15, 1941
('80', 252, 8, 15, 401072) Q. Very few names from the third list of satyagrahis from Maharashtra (193 out of 1,072) are approved and permitted to offer satyagraha.
('80', 252, 8, 16, 401209) This permissionbusiness seems to be unduly delayed, and the satyagrahis are thus put to much inconvenience.
('80', 252, 9, 17, 401317) A. I propose to introduce a change in the technique about the passing of these lists of satyagrahis.
('80', 252, 9, 18, 401418) 2 From the date on which the name of a prospective satyagrahi is forwarded to me for sanction by the Provincial Congress Committee the satyagrahi concerned has to stop his private activities and has to devote himself wholly to the working out of one or more of the items of the thirteenfold constructive programme, which expression is to be understood in the widest sense as explained in my article 3 headed ‘‘Implications of Constructive
('80', 252, 10, 19, 401857) 1 President, Maharashtra Provincial Congress Committee, who was accom panied by Dr. Lagu of Poona.
('80', 252, 10, 20, 401956) According to the source, this was ‘‘revised and corrected by Gandhiji” and was released to the Press with his permission.
('80', 252, 10, 21, 402078) Vide also ‘‘Letter to D. K. Gosavi”, 1 6 1941 and 8 6 1941. 2 For instructions issued by J. B. Kripalani ‘‘for the guidance of satyagrahis and Congress Committees in consultation with Gandhiji”, vide “Instruction to Satyagrahis”, 17 6 1941 3Vide “Inplications of Constructive Programme”
('80', 253, 0, 1, 402365) 254 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 253, 1, 2, 402407) Programme” in the issue of Harijan dated 18th of August 1940. Every prospective satyagrahi is expected to keep a log book (or diary) in which he will daily enter the work done during the course of the day and the log book shall be submitted to me through the P.C.C. concerned at stated intervals, say, fortnightly or monthly.
('80', 253, 1, 3, 402733) After going through the diaries I shall grant permission for satyagraha to deserv ing persons.
('80', 253, 1, 4, 402828) Others will have to follow the said course till they get permission.
('80', 253, 1, 5, 402897) The satyagrahi may not expect any financial help from the Congress.
('80', 253, 1, 6, 402965) I know that on this very strict basis the number of satyagrahis will be reduced to a very large extent but what I am keen on is quality and not quantity.
('80', 253, 1, 7, 403119) I shall not feel sorry if the number is reduced to any extent.
('80', 253, 1, 8, 403182) Moreover, whilst so many satyagrahis are wandering about, I am anxious not to add to the list of wanderers.
('80', 253, 2, 9, 403290) Don”t you feel that you are unfair to the prospective satyagrahis in prescribing such a severe preliminary test to them only, while you allowed their predecessors in on a comparatively simpler test?
('80', 253, 3, 10, 403489) I don’t think I am unfair.
('80', 253, 3, 11, 403516) One thing that you must remember is that the above movement is evolving.
('80', 253, 3, 12, 403589) Exigencies of the situation may demand varying conditions.
('80', 253, 4, 13, 403648) Has the President of the P.C.C. any duty towards the satyagrahis when they come out of jail?
('80', 253, 4, 14, 403741) Yes, he certainly has.
('80', 253, 4, 15, 403764) He has to ask them to repeat satyagraha and find themselves again in jail, say, within about a week from the date of their release.
('80', 253, 4, 16, 403896) The P.C.C.s.
('80', 253, 4, 17, 403909) need only report to me cases demanding special treatment and the instructions that will be issued by me in these cases should be followed and executed by the P.C.C.s.
('80', 253, 5, 18, 404076) How long will this process go on?
('80', 253, 5, 19, 404110) Indefinitely; that is to say, till we achieve our goal.
('80', 253, 5, 20, 404166) Deep down in me there is a feeling that the struggle will become progressively fiercer, and we must pass through all such trials.
('80', 253, 5, 21, 404296) In this respect we must take lesson from the British who, in spite of all the severe losses and heavy odds against them, have maintained fine morale and are determined to carry on.
('80', 253, 5, 22, 404477) We may not do less.
('80', 253, 6, 23, 404497) 1 This and the following three paragraphs are reproduced from Congress Bulletin.
('80', 254, 0, 1, 404578) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 255
('80', 254, 1, 2, 404626) If any satyagrahi who has enrolled himself on the original basis feels unable to accept the new basis, which will be the honourable way out for him ?
('80', 254, 2, 3, 404776) He is free to withdraw his name and there is no disgrace attaching to any such honest withdrawal.
('80', 254, 2, 4, 404874) I must not be deceived.
('80', 254, 2, 5, 404898) To deceive me is to deceive oneself and the nation.
('80', 254, 2, 6, 404950) Every honest person can and should withdraw his name.
('80', 254, 2, 7, 405004) He may continue to render whatever services he can to the country.
('80', 254, 2, 8, 405071) He does remain and does continue a Congressman as before.
('80', 254, 2, 9, 405129) Congress does require and does appreciate his services also.
('80', 254, 2, 10, 405190) But he cannot remain on the satyagrahi list as it is now envisaged.
('80', 254, 3, 11, 405258) Can we start and develop a volunteer organization under the present circumstances ?
('80', 254, 3, 12, 405342) By all means; the only condition is that it shall be organized only on the basis of non violence—unadulterated non violence.
('80', 254, 3, 13, 405467) No trifling with non violence will do and therefore no laxity in that respect can be tolerated.
('80', 254, 3, 14, 405563) One more point.
('80', 254, 3, 15, 405579) The said organization should be pro Congress and yet independent of the Congress.
('80', 254, 3, 16, 405661) It can be an allied institution like A.I.S.A., etc.
('80', 254, 4, 17, 405713) Can decent violence in self defence under emergencies by any member of such volunteer organization be tolerated as an exception?
('80', 254, 4, 18, 405842) No, it cannot be.
('80', 254, 4, 19, 405860) No such exception can be contemplated or provided against in advance, in an organization which is started specifically on the sole basis of non violence.
('80', 254, 4, 20, 406014) Such a person will have to leave the organization.
('80', 254, 5, 21, 406065) Non violent resistance is the best method; failing that, even violent decent resistance is tolerable but cowardice is unthinkable and condemnable”.
('80', 254, 5, 22, 406213) That is what you have been preaching in this respect.
('80', 254, 5, 23, 406267) But what you now say does not square with your above dictum.
('80', 254, 5, 24, 406328) That dictum is meant for those millions that have not yet accepted the creed of the Congress.
('80', 254, 5, 25, 406422) It cannot apply to those organiza tions that are founded on the basic creed of non violence.
('80', 254, 5, 26, 406515) Those who desire to effect a change in the basic creed of non violence must either change their General or go out of the organization.
('80', 254, 6, 27, 406650) The Congress being largely suspended as an organization, what should be our policy this year as regards the annual enrolment of membership?

('80', 266, 4, 10, 424112) 462. LETTER TO BHOGILAL LALA 1
('80', 266, 5, 11, 424143) [On or before May 21, 1941] 2
('80', 266, 6, 12, 424173) For four days, Mridulabehn, Gulzarilal and I have had talks to our hearts’ content.
('80', 266, 6, 13, 424257) If you and Sjt.
('80', 266, 6, 14, 424273) Jivanlal Divan could have been also present, it would have been very helpful to me in arriving at a decision.
('80', 266, 6, 15, 424383) I gather that there are two opinions regarding what the Congress did, failed to do, and should do in future in case of communal disturbances.
('80', 266, 6, 16, 424525) However that may be, everything considered, I am of opinion that, in a crisis like the present, an Advisory Committee (of which the personnel is given below) should be appointed, and everything should be done according to their advice.
('80', 266, 6, 17, 424761) You will see that I have included Shri Mahadev Desai’s name on the Committee.
('80', 266, 6, 18, 424839) He will not be able to be there on all occasions, but he will try to be there whenever you all feel that his presence is essential.
('80', 266, 6, 19, 424971) Your first duty is to find out how many among our Congressmen firmly hold that violent resistance against an opponent in defence of oneself or others is out of the question.
('80', 266, 6, 20, 425145) Those who favour violent resistance must get out of the Congress and shape their conduct just as they think fit and guide others accordingly.
('80', 266, 6, 21, 425287) I am firmly of opinion that, if the Congress does not clearly define its policy in this matter, it will end in proving itself to be a useless organization.
('80', 266, 7, 22, 425443) 1 Secretary, Gujarat Provincial Congress Committee.
('80', 266, 7, 23, 425495) According to the source, this letter was brought to Ahmedabad by Mahadev Desai for the guidance of Congressmen.
('80', 266, 7, 24, 425607) Mahadev Desai left for Ahmedabad on May 21; vide the following item.
('80', 267, 0, 1, 425676) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 267, 1, 2, 425718) If a majority of Congressmen hold that violent resistance against an assailant is a duty, and if they do not regard it ,as inconsistent with the creed of the Congress, they should openly declare their opinion and guide people accordingly.
('80', 267, 1, 3, 425957) The absence of our leaders in jail should not deter anyone from declaring his opinion in this crisis.
('80', 267, 1, 4, 426059) It can be revised in case it is found later to be wrong.
('80', 267, 1, 5, 426116) The point is that no one should be in a state of indecisiveness.
('80', 267, 1, 6, 426181) I am sure that, if all Congressmen had done their duty, we should not have had the goondashahi—the reign of the goonda—that we had recently.
('80', 267, 1, 7, 426322) That people should flee for their lives for fear of the goonda should be intolerable.
('80', 267, 1, 8, 426408) They ought to possess the capacity of resisting goondashahi violently or non violently.
('80', 267, 1, 9, 426496) If my interpretation of the Congress creed is correct, the Congress and Congressmen may offer non violent resistance only, and they are sure to succeed.
('80', 267, 1, 10, 426649) But we should tell the people, in the clearest possible terms, that running away in fear is cowardice.
('80', 267, 1, 11, 426752) It is their duty to offer resistance—even violent, if they are incapable of non violent resistance, which is a worthy way.
('80', 267, 1, 12, 426875) Congressmen will not ask for the help of the Government, the police or the military.
('80', 267, 1, 13, 426960) Those who believe in violent resistance will indeed ask for Government’s help.
('80', 267, 1, 14, 427039) A Congressman may not directly or indirectly associate himself with gymnasia where training in violent resistance is given.
('80', 267, 1, 15, 427163) But he will appeal even to the believer in violent resistance to observe certain rules of restraint.
('80', 267, 1, 16, 427264) Even violent resistance admits of a certain amount of de cency.
('80', 267, 1, 17, 427328) Thus, for instance, murdering an innocent man in cold blood should be taboo.
('80', 267, 1, 18, 427405) The fundamental thing to be borne in mind is that people should, under no circumstances, be cowardly or impotent.
('80', 267, 1, 19, 427519) One need never be a goonda to fight a goonda.
('80', 267, 1, 20, 427565) One who stabs another in the back and takes to his heels will never be counted as brave.
('80', 267, 1, 21, 427654) A Congressman can have no prejudices, and so he would go out of his way to meet members of the Muslim League, the Hindu Maha sabha and other bodies in the interest of peace, and persuade them to combine in ruling out the law of the jungle, no matter how great their political differences.
('80', 267, 1, 22, 427943) That these endeavours may fail should not matter in the least.
('80', 267, 1, 23, 428006) It is their duty to appeal to everyone, and to flatter none.
('80', 267, 1, 24, 428067) The Congress will not claim compensation for losses sustained during the riots.
('80', 267, 1, 25, 428147) That is not its concern.
('80', 267, 1, 26, 428172) The people had to sustain losses as they lacked the capacity to defend themselves; and so they
('80', 268, 0, 1, 428267) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 269
('80', 268, 1, 2, 428315) must bear them.
('80', 268, 1, 3, 428331) I go so far as to believe that Government could not, even if they would, secure adequate compensation to those who have sustained losses.
('80', 268, 1, 4, 428469) I think it is terrible to think of protecting ourselves with the help of the Bhaiyya, the Sikh or the Thakurda.
('80', 268, 1, 5, 428581) To engage an ordinary durwan or gate keeper is a different proposition.
('80', 268, 1, 6, 428653) There should be no young man among the mercantile middle class community who hasnot gone through training for self defence, violent or non violent.
('80', 268, 1, 7, 428801) Engaging these foreign elements for defence, far from putting an end to goondashahi will put a premium on it.
('80', 268, 1, 8, 428911) Hindus staying in Muslim localities must not leave them, but stay on there even at the risk of their lives.
('80', 268, 1, 9, 429019) Muslims living in Hindu localities should be ensured the fullest protection by the Hindus.
('80', 268, 1, 10, 429110) The practice of closing down shops at the slightest rumour of disturbance should be stopped and every shopkeeper should be ready for violent or non violent self defence.
('80', 268, 1, 11, 429280) If they will cultivate this courage, the loss will be reduced to a minimum, and the riots would become a thing of the past.
('80', 268, 1, 12, 429404) Riots such as we have in our country are unknown in the West, though there may be civil wars there.
('80', 268, 1, 13, 429504) The reason is that the contending parties there are equally matched, and do not take to their heels at the sight of one another, nor do they ask for and accept police help.
('80', 268, 1, 14, 429677) The use of the police is entirely for protection against thieves and robbers.
('80', 268, 1, 15, 429755) In this respect we are absolutely barbarous and even impotent.
('80', 268, 1, 16, 429818) MEMBERS OF THE COMMITTEE: Mr. Mahadev Desai—President; Mr. Narahari Parikh—Vice President; Mr. Bhogilal and Mr. Gulzarilal Nanda—Secretaries; Mr. Jivanlal Divan, Mridula Sarabhai, Indumati Chimanlal, Mr. Khandubhai Desai and Raojibhai Patel.

('80', 270, 5, 23, 432492) 467. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU”
('80', 270, 6, 24, 432522) [On or before May 22, 1941] 2
('80', 270, 7, 25, 432552) Replying to a question put by me, in the course of a special interview, whether he felt that the British Government would not come to any understanding with India, that they would prefer to continue the policy of drift, Mahatma Gandhi said: I am afraid, I have to say, ‘Yes’.
('80', 270, 7, 26, 432828) Quite; that has been their traditional policy and it seems that, even whilst they are fighting for their very existence, they do not or they will not revise their traditional policy.
('80', 270, 8, 27, 433011) Asked whether in the present circumstances the Congress should be content with merely recording its moral protest when moral values seemed to be the first victim in the war, Gandhiji replied: The Congress has no other value and no other influence.
('80', 270, 8, 28, 433259) Whilst it is true that moral values are the first victims in war, in the end they will emerge triumphant if there is any body of people ready to represent them.
('80', 270, 8, 29, 433420) And I have every hope that the Congress is at least
('80', 270, 9, 30, 433472) 1 Dr. Nathubhai D. Patel 2 The interview was reported under the date line: “Nagpur, May 22”.
('80', 271, 0, 1, 433565) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 271, 1, 2, 433607) one such body to represent moral values.
('80', 271, 1, 3, 433648) If I am asked for proof, I can’t give it.
('80', 271, 1, 4, 433690) Time alone will show.
('80', 271, 2, 5, 433712) When I drew Gandhiji’s attention to the remark 1 he made in the course of his statement on communal riots that mischief makers and their victims who failed to stand up to them were all untouched by Congress and yet these are the men who form the bulk of Congress meetings, Gandhiji replied: Yes, I have been obliged to say that because Congress has not been able to gain control over rowdy elements.
('80', 271, 2, 6, 434112) It does not matter to me whether these elements are supported by powerful organizations or, as some hint, encouraged by the British authorities.
('80', 271, 2, 7, 434257) I have no manner of doubt that the mass mind has to shed all fear of goondaism.
('80', 271, 2, 8, 434337) Whether that fear is shed violently or non violently, it has to be shed before we can defend ourselves not only against British might but the world.
('80', 271, 2, 9, 434486) The first condition of civilized life is that people are able to deal with goondaism, no matter how fomented.
('80', 271, 3, 10, 434596) Asked whether the report that no further list of satyagrahis is likely to be approved by him is correct, Gandhiji said that satyagraha is temporarily suspended in places where there is tension due to communal riots and where there are a large number of satyagrahis who have not yet been arrested.
('80', 271, 4, 11, 434893) To a question whether satyagrahis returning from jail will be required to offer satyagraha again, Gandhiji replied: Every one of them, I suppose, will go to jail from time to time until the whole question is settled for which civil disobedience is being offered, that is, until the object of civil disobedience is fulfilled.
('80', 271, 5, 12, 435218) The Hindu, 23 5 1941

('80', 273, 6, 25, 438311) 471. LETTER TO PYARELAL
('80', 273, 7, 26, 438335) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, May 22, 1941
('80', 273, 8, 27, 438366) PYARELAL, How is it there is no letter from you at all?

('80', 277, 2, 3, 443709) May 23, 1941
('80', 277, 3, 4, 443722) BHAI PRITHVI SINGH, I got your letter.
('80', 277, 3, 5, 443761) Our training should only be on non violent lines.
('80', 277, 3, 6, 443811) So we cannot teach the use of the sword and other such violent weapons.
('80', 277, 3, 7, 443883) But we should certainly teach non violent defence even through them.
('80', 277, 3, 8, 443952) To use the sword against the sword is a violent defence.
('80', 277, 3, 9, 444009) To snatch the sword from the murderer would he non violent defence.
('80', 277, 3, 10, 444077) The best defence would be to surrender before the murderer and die.
('80', 277, 3, 11, 444145) For such defence we should have unlimited capacity for forgiveness.
('80', 277, 3, 12, 444213) For such people there will be no need of exercise or any other kind of training.
('80', 277, 3, 13, 444294) The training in exercise is for those who have not freed themselves from fear.
('80', 277, 3, 14, 444373) I am writing this with the intention of training those who do not know the difference between violence and non violence, and whom we want to train in non violent exercises.
('80', 277, 3, 15, 444546) I feel I have in brief covered everything.
('80', 277, 3, 16, 444589) Nathji and Kishorelalji may also see this and ask any other questions, if necessary.

('80', 277, 7, 20, 444824) WARDHA, May 23, 1941 It is but natural that nowadays I don’t feel like leaving Sevagram at all.
('80', 277, 7, 21, 444920) If I express a desire to do so I get invitations to various places.
