('80', 277, 7, 24, 445135) But then I thought to myself that so many boys are coming to
('80', 277, 8, 25, 445196) 1This appeared along with a note, which read: “This has been reported by newspapers also, but this is the authentic report of the speech which was delivered by Gandhiji at 8.20 p.m.
('80', 277, 8, 26, 445378) on May 23, 1941, at Wardha.”
('80', 278, 0, 1, 445407) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 279
('80', 278, 1, 2, 445455) Wardha and I wouldn’t like it if I am not able to mix freely with them or crack jokes with them.
('80', 278, 1, 3, 445552) So I myself agreed to come and attend the Camp.
('80', 278, 1, 4, 445600) Today my mind is full of only one thing.
('80', 278, 1, 5, 445641) I cannot think of anything except what has happened at Ahmedabad, Dacca, Bombay and in Bihar.
('80', 278, 1, 6, 445735) Riots have again started in Ahmedabad.
('80', 278, 1, 7, 445774) There are disturbances in Bombay, too.
('80', 278, 1, 8, 445813) I ask you, ‘‘What part are the youths supposed to play in these circumstances?” Every Indian should ask himself this question.
('80', 278, 1, 9, 445940) There are but two ways of facing this situation.
('80', 278, 1, 10, 445989) One is the age old way of the world—meeting violence with violence.
('80', 278, 1, 11, 446057) There is yet another way of defending oneself—that is, to peacefully endure the suffering and not to take revenge.
('80', 278, 1, 12, 446172) The first way is considered universal.
('80', 278, 1, 13, 446211) It is unmanly to run away from danger.
('80', 278, 1, 14, 446250) Dumb animals run away when beaten.
('80', 278, 1, 15, 446285) We should not be like them.
('80', 278, 1, 16, 446313) It only befits us to face the danger like men and sacrifice our lives while doing so if the occasion demands.
('80', 278, 1, 17, 446423) The Congress has shown the path of facing violence through non violence.
('80', 278, 1, 18, 446496) This is the only right way.
('80', 278, 1, 19, 446524) If you are not able to accept this, then it is your duty to fight the enemy as much as you like.
('80', 278, 1, 20, 446621) But do remember this—you have to fight only the assailant; to take revenge on innocent people is a sign of inhumanity and cowardice.
('80', 278, 1, 21, 446754) I wish you to make yourselves worthy of accepting the new and better way—the non violent way—of bravely dying for the cause.
('80', 278, 1, 22, 446879) You should neither give blow for blow nor run away for your life.
('80', 278, 1, 23, 446945) For the last twenty years we have been learning to put this supreme art into practice.
('80', 278, 1, 24, 447032) Today the situation is such that it is a challenge to our faith in the new way of self defence, i.e., non violence.
('80', 278, 1, 25, 447148) I hope you have been taught the art of facing such difficult situations.
('80', 278, 1, 26, 447221) At the moment every Congressman is put to a severe test.
('80', 278, 1, 27, 447278) If the Congress does not stand this test it will not have a right to exist as a national institution.
('80', 278, 1, 28, 447380) What counts most is that we should be true to ourselves.

('80', 291, 3, 4, 462529) KRISHNACHANDRA, If you have understood my letter 1, then the other two [questions] need no reply.

('80', 291, 3, 7, 462720) Duty or right?
('80', 291, 3, 8, 462735) Duty cannot be given up and there is no right.
('80', 291, 3, 9, 462782) You cannot give up what forms a part of duty, what is left is only a burden.
('80', 291, 3, 10, 462859) This applies to both you and Chimanlal.
('80', 291, 3, 11, 462899) If Chimanlal does not enjoy the privilege of a manager, then he is free, but what remains as part of duty has got to be done.
('80', 291, 3, 12, 463025) For example, if Surendra steals, then power has to be exercised to stop him from doing so.
('80', 291, 3, 13, 463116) But if he insults anyone, the use of power should be shunned.
('80', 291, 3, 14, 463178) Both of you should read this.
('80', 291, 3, 15, 463208) Perhaps many things will then get solved by themselves.

('80', 305, 7, 9, 482687) 529. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('80', 305, 8, 10, 482715) SEVAGRAM, June 9, 1941
('80', 305, 9, 11, 482738) I have read and re read with shame and sorrow an official account of the cool, calculated and unprovoked murder of a Muslim family including an infant girl, three years old.
('80', 305, 9, 12, 482912) Though Rajendra Babu is doing glorious work on behalf of communal peace in Bihar, it is impossible for me to suppress my own opinion on this cruel crime.
('80', 305, 9, 13, 483066) The perpetrators, whoever they may be, have done no good either to themselves or their religion, if they have any, or to this country.
('80', 305, 9, 14, 483201) This I say apart from my views on ahimsa.
('80', 305, 9, 15, 483243) I suggest that on no ground, even of violence, can such murders be defended.
('80', 305, 9, 16, 483320) Repeated on a wide scale they must reduce our fair land to savagery and make the country’s freedom an impossibility.
('80', 305, 9, 17, 483437) No government can cope with such crimes.
('80', 305, 9, 18, 483478) They can only punish the miscreants after the event and that only if they are found.
('80', 305, 9, 19, 483563) In the latter case, the punishment is likely to be as indiscriminate and savage as the crime itself.
('80', 305, 9, 20, 483664) I, therefore, advise the perpetrators with all the force my words may possess to deliver themselves up unconditionally to the authorities for such punishment as the latter may think fit to award.
('80', 305, 9, 21, 483860) This act of repentance, tardy though it will be, will somewhat recompense for the grievous crime committed.
('80', 305, 9, 22, 483968) They will thereby purge themselves, their religion andtheir country to some extent of the disgrace that attaches to the crime.
('80', 305, 10, 23, 484095) 1 The addressee, who was sentenced to one and a half years’ imprisonment for offering satyagraha, had sought Gandhiji’s advice regarding the suspension of his licence of Pleadership under the Defence of India Rules.

('80', 310, 4, 9, 490104) 539. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('80', 310, 5, 10, 490132) SEVAGRAM, June 15, 1941 Shri K. M. Munshi wrote to me the enclosed 1 from Nainital to which I sent a reply 2 in Gujarati of which the original and translation are herewith enclosed.
('80', 310, 5, 11, 490314) In pursuance of the correspondence, Shri K. M. Munshi came to me 3 as soon as it was possible after his return to Bombay.
('80', 310, 5, 12, 490436) In the course of the discussion, I discovered that whilst he accepted in the abstract the principle of ahimsa with all its implications, he felt the greatest difficulty in acting upon it, the more so as with his intimate knowledge of Bombay he was sure that he could not carry the Hindus with him, much less the Muslims.
('80', 310, 5, 13, 490757) He knew that the numerous Hindus who were under his influence would look to him for guidance and would seek his advice.
('80', 310, 5, 14, 490877) He saw no way of convincing them that they could defend themselves through ahimsa.
('80', 310, 5, 15, 490960) As a political weapon and therefore of immediate use in the midst of the riots which looked more like a miniature civil war, he could not make any effective use of ahimsa.
('80', 310, 5, 16, 491132) With him the question was not one of interpretation of Congress resolutions but of being truthful to himself and to the country.
('80', 310, 5, 17, 491261) In view, therefore, of the following resolution 4 by the A.I.C.C. explaining the Wardha statement, I advised that the only dignified and brave course for him was to resign from the Congress and attain freedom of action unhampered by restrictions entailed by the Congress non violence.
('80', 310, 6, 18, 491546) 1 Vide “Letter to K. M. Munshi”, 26 5 1941 2 Vide”Letter to K. M. Munshi”, 29 5 1941 3 On June 12, 1941; vide “Discussion with K. M. Munshiu and Others”, 12 6 1941 4 Passed at Poona on July 28, 1940.
('80', 311, 0, 1, 491746) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 311, 1, 2, 491788) The A.I.C.C. has considered the statement issued by the Working Committee from Wardha on June 21, 1940, and confirmed it.
('80', 311, 1, 3, 491910) The A.I.C.C. is of opinion that as explained therein, while the Congress must continue to adhere strictly to the principle of non violence in the struggle for independence, it is unable, in the present circumstances, to declare that the principle should be extended to free India’s national defence.
('80', 311, 1, 4, 492210) The A.I.C.C. desires to affirm that the Congress organization should continue to be conducted on the principle of non violence and all Congress volunteers are bound by their pledge to remain non violent in the discharge of their duty and no Congress volunteers’ organization can be formed or maintained except on that basis.
('80', 311, 1, 5, 492535) Any other volunteers’ organization for the purpose of self defence with which Congressmen are associated must likewise adhere to non violence.
('80', 311, 1, 6, 492678) I told him that there came a time in every Congressman’s life when being a Congressman dragged him down; that was when there was conflict between thought and action.
('80', 311, 1, 7, 492844) For the spring of non violent action was non violent thought.
('80', 311, 1, 8, 492906) If the latter was absent, the former had subjectively little or no value.
('80', 311, 1, 9, 492980) Therefore it was good for him, the Congress and the country that he should resign and mould hisaction from moment to moment as he thought proper.
('80', 311, 1, 10, 493126) And by his action he would open the door for those Congressmen to resign whose practice could not accord with their thought.
('80', 311, 1, 11, 493251) The Congress was conceived to be a non violent and truthful organization in which there should be no place for those who could not honestly conform to these two conditions.
('80', 311, 1, 12, 493424) Strange as it might appear, the practice of non violence seemed more difficult than of truth.
('80', 311, 1, 13, 493518) For the fruits of untruth were more indetectable than those of violence.
('80', 311, 1, 14, 493591) My advice appealed to Shri Munshi.
('80', 311, 1, 15, 493626) And he has decided to accept it.
('80', 311, 1, 16, 493659) 1 He will go because he could not be disloyal to the Congress he has so long served.
('80', 311, 1, 17, 493744) And it does not at all follow that his resignation means that from being a meek and mild man he suddenly becomes a fierce man, vowing vengeance on those whom he may consider to be opponents, or that he becomes a communal anti nationalist.
('80', 311, 1, 18, 493983) I have no doubt that for him every non Hindu whose only home is India is as much Indian as a Hindu, born and bred in India.
('80', 311, 1, 19, 494107) I congratulate him upon taking the step he will and I have every hope that his resignation from the Congress will enable him to utilize his faculties so as to make a decisive contribution towards the establishment of lasting peace in Bombay.
('80', 311, 2, 20, 494349) The Bombay Chronicle, 27 6 1941; also Pilgrimage to Freedom, pp.
('80', 311, 3, 21, 494414) 1 For K. M. Munshi’s statement, vide “K. M. Munshi’s Statement”
('80', 312, 0, 1, 494478) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 313
('80', 312, 1, 2, 494526) 540. REPLY TO BRITISH WOMEN’S APPEAL 1
('80', 312, 2, 3, 494565) SEVAGRAM, June 15, 1941
('80', 312, 3, 4, 494589) DEAR SISTERS, We have very carefully studied your message addressed to India’s women.
('80', 312, 3, 5, 494675) We write this in our individual capacity, as also that of representative members of the A.I.W.C. which, as you know, is an organization of fifteen years’ standing.
('80', 312, 3, 6, 494839) We mention this to show that what we state here is not only our deep personal conviction, but also, as far as we can judge, the conviction of a large body of India’s women.
('80', 312, 3, 7, 495012) It is scarcely necessary to tell you that we appreciate the sincerity of your appeal.
('80', 312, 3, 8, 495098) But we are amazed at the ignorance betrayed in it of the realities.
('80', 312, 3, 9, 495166) Indeed your Prime Minister 2 by contrast shows a grasp of realities which is refreshing, however painful it may be.
('80', 312, 3, 10, 495282) He has no misgivings about the status that India occupies in the British mind.
('80', 312, 3, 11, 495361) It is a dependency which can and is being utilized at the British will.
('80', 312, 3, 12, 495433) He knows that he does not need the consent or co operation of India’s thinking sons and daughters in anything that Britain wants for fighting her war.
('80', 312, 3, 13, 495584) He takes care to pay tribute to the valour of the Indian soldiers who are part of the army of occupation in India.
('80', 312, 3, 14, 495699) These soldiers you should know are wholly unconnected with the national life and activities.
('80', 312, 3, 15, 495792) They may not freely see any nationalist without incurring heavy penalties, nor has your Prime Minister any difficulty in raising either by taxation or so called voluntary contributions the money he wants.
('80', 312, 3, 16, 495997) We cannot complain of this helplessness but we must not be blind to the facts.
('80', 312, 3, 17, 496076) How can there be the association, in such a situation, of the India that is impatient of the foreign yoke with the forcible aid we have adverted to?
('80', 312, 3, 18, 496225) The fact is that you are wholly wrong in your estimate of things.
('80', 312, 3, 19, 496291) We are surprised at your quoting the untruth contained in President Roosevelt’s pronouncement.
('80', 312, 3, 20, 496386) You quote: “Today the whole world is
('80', 312, 4, 21, 496423) 1 Drafted by Gandhiji, this was signed by Sarojini Naidu, Rameshwari Nehru, Vijayalakshmi Pandit, Amrit Kaur, Rani Lakshmibai Rajwade, Ammu Swaminathan and Radha Subbaroyan on behalf of the All India Women’s Conference and sent on June 21, 1941. 2 Winston Churchill
('80', 313, 0, 1, 496689) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 313, 1, 2, 496731) divided between human slavery and human freedom.” 1 The fact is that there is no such thing as human freedom for Asiatic races, certainly not for India, nor is there for the virile Africans.
('80', 313, 1, 3, 496922) The result, whatever it may be, of the war will not alter their condition for the better, save through their own efforts.
('80', 313, 1, 4, 497044) As we see the reality, it is this.
('80', 313, 1, 5, 497079) It is a war between the British Empire and Nazis and Fascists for world domination, meaning in effect exploitation of the non European races.
('80', 313, 1, 6, 497221) We cannot be in love with Nazism and Fascism.
('80', 313, 1, 7, 497267) But we may not be expected to be in love with British Imperialism.
('80', 313, 1, 8, 497334) Now perhaps you will understand why we as women are against all war.
('80', 313, 1, 9, 497403) Women’s part is just now to stand up for truth and non violence as against the untruth and violence which surround us.
('80', 313, 1, 10, 497522) We admire the self sacrifice of the British women of which you write with just pride.
('80', 313, 1, 11, 497608) Here we wish you could have taken a braver andprouder part by telling your men to wash their hands clean of human blood.
('80', 313, 1, 12, 497729) You might not have succeeded all at once.
('80', 313, 1, 13, 497771) But you would have led the way to the establishment of permanent peace.
('80', 313, 1, 14, 497843) We take leave to doubt the wisdom of women aping men in the black art of human slaughter on a scale hitherto unknown.
('80', 313, 1, 15, 497961) Lastly, let us point out the anomaly of British women asking India, though a slave nation, to help the slave owner in distress instead of asking the slave owner to undo the wrong and cure himself of the initial sin and thus ensure the moral justness of his position.
('80', 313, 1, 16, 498228) This presentation of the picture may appear unpleasant to you but it is none the less sincere.
('80', 313, 1, 17, 498323) And we could not answer your sincerity except by being equally sincere.
('80', 313, 2, 18, 498395) From a photostat: C.W. 10360

('80', 315, 8, 11, 501033) June 16, 1941
('80', 315, 9, 12, 501047) VIDYA, A great calamity has indeed befallen you.

('80', 326, 1, 5, 514068) He gave his money for the spread of the charkha among the poor of Orissa.

('80', 326, 1, 7, 514276) Shri Ishwarlal describes his last days thus:
('80', 326, 2, 8, 514321) He suffered from diarrhoea for nearly three months.
('80', 326, 2, 9, 514373) He stopped taking medicines from the 18th June, 1941. He said: “I have been taking medicines for the last three months and there is no improvement.
('80', 326, 2, 10, 514521) So now let it be as God wills.” He was using mud packs.
('80', 326, 2, 11, 514577) He had completely given up food.
('80', 326, 2, 12, 514610) He took mosambi juice which also he gave up later.
('80', 326, 2, 13, 514661) Since the morning of the 23rd he did not take even water.
('80', 326, 2, 14, 514719) He used to rinse his mouth when his throat went dry.
('80', 326, 2, 15, 514772) I told him: “Please take some water”.
('80', 326, 2, 16, 514810) He replied: “Don’t you see I am losing my breath?” This he said in the morning and till ten minutes to three he was fully conscious.
('80', 326, 2, 17, 514943) Within ten minutes all of a sudden he was unconscious and lay stiff.
('80', 326, 2, 18, 515012) Without any movement, slowly the breathing stopped.
('80', 326, 2, 19, 515064) Let us all become like him.
('80', 326, 2, 20, 515092) May God grant us such a noble death.

('80', 335, 1, 2, 527960) 585. DRAFT STATEMENT FOR AMRITA LAL CHATTERJEE
('80', 335, 2, 3, 528007) [July 2, 1941] 1
('80', 335, 3, 4, 528024) For domestic reasons in which the public is not interested I had to come back to Bengal leaving my two elder sons under Gandhiji’s care.
('80', 335, 3, 5, 528161) On arrival in Bengal I proceeded at once to Dacca as I had thought under Gandhiji’s instructions.
('80', 335, 3, 6, 528259) And I made a long statement about my going to Dacca.
('80', 335, 3, 7, 528312) On seeing the statementGandhiji in a telegram 2 repudiated it and said that he had never given me any instructions but that he had said that if I felt like it I could go to Dacca on my own responsibility and without fuss immolate myself there whilst trying to serve both the communities.
('80', 335, 3, 8, 528600) I am sorry I misunderstood his instructions.
('80', 335, 3, 9, 528645) I well recall his repeatedly saying to me as to all workers that we had to work silently and selflessly.
('80', 335, 3, 10, 528750) But in the impulse of the moment I forgot myself and was betrayed into making a long statement up to which I could not live.
('80', 335, 3, 11, 528875) In Dacca I was in need of directions without which I could not do work.
('80', 335, 3, 12, 528947) I wired to Gandhiji for them and he wired 3saying he could issue none and that I should come away and work for my living which I am trying to do.
('80', 335, 4, 13, 529093) From a photostat: C.W. 10361. Courtesy: Amrita Lal Chatterjee

('80', 347, 1, 2, 545363) 606. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('80', 347, 2, 3, 545391) SEVAGRAM, July 6, 1941 When Mian Saheb Iftikhar ud Din, President of the Punjab Provincial Congress Committee, and Dr. Gopichand were with me the other day, Mian Saheb told me that there was some misunderstanding among some Congressmen about certain things which required clearing.
('80', 347, 2, 4, 545673) I should have dealt with them earlier.
('80', 347, 2, 5, 545712) But pressure of work and my limited capacity for disposal are responsible for the delay.
('80', 347, 2, 6, 545801) I take them up now.
('80', 347, 2, 7, 545821) When the Punjab Bar patriotically took up the honourable role of amicus curiae and decided to bring before their High Court for revision the cases of satyagrahis in which, in their opinion, obvious injustice was done, I was delighted, not for the sake of the relief such revision might bring, but for the sake of the Punjab Bar and of purity of justice.
('80', 347, 2, 8, 546175) Whilst satyagrahis must be indifferent to the sentences pronounced against them, they must welcome exposure of injustice especially when it is brought about at the instance of disinterested parties.
('80', 347, 2, 9, 546374) When, therefore, Ismet Begum wired and wrote to me that her husband was much displeased and disturbed over the prospect of revision, I urged her not to interfere and asked her to tell her husband that there was nothing wrong about the revision and that if he was discharged it would be open to him to offer civil disobedience again.
('80', 347, 2, 10, 546707) Of course the matter wears a different and ugly aspect when satyagrahi prisoners request the amicus curiae that they should take up their (prisoners’) cases.
('80', 347, 2, 11, 546865) Such conduct would be quite contrary to the satyagraha code.
('80', 347, 2, 12, 546926) Complaints are being made in several parts as in the Punjab that the new lists of satyagrahis are not being passed as fast as they are sent.
('80', 347, 2, 13, 547067) There is no lack of despatch in the Punjab or any other province as to the lists.
('80', 347, 2, 14, 547149) But I am in no hurry to pass them.
('80', 347, 2, 15, 547184) I repeat for the thousandth time that the present civil disobedience is not only not designed to embarrass authority but care is being taken as far as possible to avoid all embarrassment.
('80', 347, 2, 16, 547372) The merit as also the strength of the struggle consists in reducing embarrassment to the minimum whilst the British are engaged in a deadly life and death war.
('80', 347, 2, 17, 547532) Moreover, since our struggle is going to be indefinitely prolonged —I
('80', 348, 0, 1, 547602) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 349
('80', 348, 1, 2, 547650) give no less than five years—there need be no hurry to fill the jails.
('80', 348, 1, 3, 547721) Mere filling of jails can bring us no nearer our freedom than we are now.
('80', 348, 1, 4, 547795) The virtue lies in the people learning through the restricted civil disobedience the necessity of discipline, suffering and self sacrifice.
('80', 348, 1, 5, 547935) Every true example of satyagraha acts as a leaven working itself in the mass mind.
('80', 348, 1, 6, 548018) During the initial stages I was purposely lax in scanning the lists.
('80', 348, 1, 7, 548087) The result was that many crept in who had done no constructive work.
('80', 348, 1, 8, 548156) Some had even no faith in it.
('80', 348, 1, 9, 548186) These are a burden on the organization and positively hinder the march to freedom.
('80', 348, 1, 10, 548269) I have said repeatedly that constructive work is the foundation for civil disobedience.
('80', 348, 1, 11, 548357) It promotes discipline and conduces to the growth of non violence in the worker.
('80', 348, 1, 12, 548438) As time advances Congressmen must therefore expect increasing stiffness on my part.
('80', 348, 1, 13, 548522) The conditions will be the same.
('80', 348, 1, 14, 548555) Strictness will be confined to the enforcement.
('80', 348, 1, 15, 548603) This is but natural if we are to grow from strength to strength and if we are to make the struggle increasingly purer.
('80', 348, 1, 16, 548722) I can conduct it on no other terms.
('80', 348, 1, 17, 548758) Then Mian Saheb mentioned to me that some Congressmen had adversely criticized his move for achieving among all parties in the Punjab agreement about eschewing goondaism in the pursuit of their respective programmes.
('80', 348, 1, 18, 548975) When the Mian Saheb told me that there was just a possibility of such an effort succeeding, I at once told him to make it and suspend for the time being his own civil disobedience and of those whose assistance he might consider necessary for the arduous task.
('80', 348, 1, 19, 549235) Some Congressmen seem to have taken exception that Mian Saheb had invited to his meeting non Congressmen and even communal leaders.
('80', 348, 1, 20, 549367) The objectors forget that it is the essence of Mian Saheb’s move to bring together all the opposite elements and see whether they could agree to eschew goondaism for the achievement of their respective purposes.
('80', 348, 1, 21, 549579) Nor could there be in such a meeting decisions by counting heads.
('80', 348, 1, 22, 549645) The end contemplated could only be achieved by the willing consent of the parties.
('80', 348, 1, 23, 549728) In any event Congressmen should know that Mian Saheb has undertaken this difficult mission in consultation with me and with my whole hearted consent.
('80', 348, 1, 24, 549878) I hope that he will receive the closest co operation of all Congressmen.
('80', 348, 1, 25, 549951) He is impatient to offer civil disobedience.
('80', 348, 1, 26, 549996) As the head of the Congress in the Punjab, he thinks that his primary duty is to offer civil disobedience.
('80', 348, 1, 27, 550103) I have told him that there is no such universal
('80', 349, 0, 1, 550151) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 349, 1, 2, 550193) On the contrary it is his clear duty, and of those whom he mayselect, to refrain so long as he and they feel that they can contribute their mite to the attempt to eradicate goondaism.
('80', 349, 1, 3, 550377) There remains the question of those who were prematurely released owing to the Punjab High Court decision about the insufficiency for the purpose of conviction of mere notices to offer civil disobedience.
('80', 349, 1, 4, 550582) When I learnt about the decision, I had informed Mian Saheb that he should not be in a hurry to send them to jail and that when he paid his contemplated visit to Sevagram I should discuss the question with him and decide.
('80', 349, 1, 5, 550804) He came and I advised that those who were not wanted for the peace move should re offer civil disobedience.
('80', 349, 2, 6, 550912) Congress Bulletin, No.
('80', 349, 2, 7, 550935) 6, 1942, File No.
('80', 349, 2, 8, 550953) 3/42/41 Home Department, Pol.
('80', 349, 2, 9, 550983) Courtesy: National Archives of India

('80', 349, 5, 23, 551530) Jamnalal may be coming tomorrow or Wednesday for certain.

('80', 349, 5, 25, 551632) Raja 1 has been released for the sake of the child.
('80', 349, 5, 26, 551684) I had a note from him.

('80', 349, 5, 29, 551830) How do you know that in your millions of previous births you were
('80', 349, 6, 30, 551896) 1 Gunottam Hutheesing
('80', 350, 0, 1, 551918) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 351

('80', 350, 1, 4, 552115) And I had told you that I would not feel at ease using that paper.
('80', 350, 1, 5, 552182) His bill, as it was, was a true bill.
('80', 350, 1, 6, 552220) He would exact that price from any other customer.
('80', 350, 1, 7, 552271) But there is no hurry about a final decision.
('80', 350, 1, 8, 552317) You will appeal to my reason and if you satisfy it, I would gladly use the pads.
('80', 350, 1, 9, 552398) The rains have been violent everywhere.
('80', 350, 1, 10, 552438) Let us hope that it does not mean dry season hereafter.

('80', 353, 3, 11, 556244) I do not want to rush him.

('80', 353, 3, 14, 556359) It is a hint that you must not expect anything now that you have openly come over to me.
('80', 353, 3, 15, 556448) From their standpoint I would justify their conduct.

('80', 353, 3, 17, 556531) All this would be sound argument from their standpoint.
('80', 353, 3, 18, 556587) They can have no other.

('80', 353, 6, 26, 557010) 615. A NOTE
('80', 353, 7, 27, 557022) July 9, 1941 I have read both the letters.
('80', 353, 7, 28, 557065) Cariappa’s fault is clear.
('80', 353, 7, 29, 557092) It is also proper that Munnalal has begged for pardon.
('80', 353, 7, 30, 557147) But Munnalal’s views are wrong on many things.
('80', 353, 7, 31, 557194) No one can be unworthy of living in an institution.
('80', 353, 7, 32, 557246) The world itself is an institution.
('80', 353, 7, 33, 557282) Can anybody stay outside it?
('80', 353, 7, 34, 557311) The family is also an institution.
('80', 353, 7, 35, 557346) It is a sub institution; and in between the world and the family are institutions like ours.
('80', 353, 7, 36, 557439) All are imperfect.
('80', 353, 7, 37, 557458) The world is also imperfect.
('80', 353, 7, 38, 557487) There is no such thing as a perfect institution because every institution is made up of imperfect
('80', 353, 8, 39, 557585) 1 Khurshedbehn Naoroji.

('80', 354, 1, 2, 557702) human beings.
('80', 354, 1, 3, 557716) Only God is perfect.
('80', 354, 1, 4, 557737) Hence Munnalal cannot run away from an institution; he has to live in one or another.

('80', 355, 1, 2, 559199) 618. LETTER TO MUNNALAL G. SHAH
('80', 355, 2, 3, 559231) July 11, 1941
('80', 355, 3, 4, 559245) MUNNALAL, Even a person who becomes perfect as a man does not become God.
('80', 355, 3, 5, 559319) Even Krishna the man died a miserable death.
('80', 355, 3, 6, 559364) 1 He may have been the best among men but was not God.
('80', 355, 3, 7, 559419) Just as a frog may become the highest among frogs, so a man may be the highest among men.
('80', 355, 3, 8, 559509) Any institution, therefore, created by man is bound to be imperfect.
('80', 355, 3, 9, 559578) If, however, you feel unhappy in this institution, you must leave it.
('80', 355, 3, 10, 559648) I merely wanted to say that what you had stated about all institutions was based on ignorance.
('80', 355, 4, 11, 559743) I would certainly welcome your staying in another institution, namely, the family.
('80', 355, 4, 12, 559826) That is what poor Kanchan wants.
('80', 355, 4, 13, 559859) She has not known the joys of family life.
('80', 355, 4, 14, 559902) Make her happy and let her feel satisfied.
('80', 355, 4, 15, 559945) Here we do have freedom.
('80', 355, 4, 16, 559970) I am certain that you will enjoy nowhere else the freedom that you do here.
('80', 355, 4, 17, 560046) If you reflect over the matter, you will see that you cannot tolerate in others the freedom that you want for yourself.
('80', 355, 4, 18, 560166) Cariappa was certainly at fault in refusing to do anything, but you should have respected his freedom to do that.
('80', 355, 4, 19, 560280) Likewise, you should respect Chimanlal’s freedom not to keep Nimbarkar, just as he should respect your freedom to express your opinion.
('80', 355, 4, 20, 560416) Whether justice or injustice is being done to Nimbarkar is for me to see.
('80', 355, 4, 21, 560490) I shall look into the matter.
('80', 355, 5, 22, 560520) Blessings from BAPU

('80', 356, 4, 15, 561551) 620. LETTER TO MRIDULA SARABHAI
('80', 356, 5, 16, 561583) SEVAGRAM, July 11, 1941

('80', 381, 4, 7, 597945) 666. LETTER TO DILKHUSH B. DIWANJI
('80', 381, 5, 8, 597980) July 21, 1941
('80', 381, 6, 9, 597994) BHAI DILKHUSH, I have carefully gone through Kantan Praveshika 1. The title is not appropriate.
('80', 381, 6, 10, 598090) The book is not a praveshika.
('80', 381, 6, 11, 598120) It offers useful suggestions to those who have become acquainted with the subject.
('80', 381, 6, 12, 598203) I would, therefore, call it Kantanarne Upayogi Soochano 2 or simply Kantanarne.
('80', 381, 6, 13, 598283) Your instructions are incomplete in some ways.
('80', 381, 6, 14, 598330) You have assumed that the spinner can tell when a spindle is bent or can judge about the point.
('80', 381, 6, 15, 598426) My experience is that 95 spinners out of a hundred cannot do that.
('80', 381, 6, 16, 598493) You should, therefore, explain what a bent spindle and a good point are.
('80', 381, 6, 17, 598566) You should similarly explain about slivers, etc.
('80', 381, 6, 18, 598615) The third and easiest method of determining the count of yarn is not what you have suggested.
('80', 381, 6, 19, 598709) The count is equal to the number of rounds in one anna weight of yarn.
('80', 381, 6, 20, 598780) The method you have explained does of course include this, but a beginner will not be able to see this.
('80', 381, 6, 21, 598884) I found from experience that the method suggested by me was the best.
('80', 381, 6, 22, 598954) I hit upon it while trying, day after day, to determine the count of my yarn in Yeravda.
('80', 381, 7, 23, 599043) You have suggested the use of cocoanut oil.
('80', 381, 7, 24, 599087) My experience is that it smells and also attracts ants.
('80', 381, 7, 25, 599143) I used to mix with cocoanut oil one fourth or a little more of kerosene.
('80', 381, 7, 26, 599216) This keeps away ants and less of dirt gets mixed with the oil.
('80', 381, 7, 27, 599279) From the above you will be able to think for yourself about other revisions.
('80', 381, 7, 28, 599356) I had noted other points in my mind, but I don’t
('80', 381, 8, 29, 599405) 1 Introduction to Spinning 2 Useful Suggestions for Spinners
('80', 382, 0, 1, 599466) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 383
('80', 382, 1, 2, 599514) remember them now.
('80', 382, 1, 3, 599533) After saying all this, I do hold the booklet to be a fine one.
('80', 382, 1, 4, 599596) I have made the above suggestions because I wish to see it perfect.
('80', 382, 2, 5, 599664) Blessings from BAPU

('80', 385, 4, 10, 604208) 672. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA 3
('80', 385, 5, 11, 604237) SEVAGRAM, July 22, 1941
('80', 385, 6, 12, 604261) BHAI GHANSHYAMDAS,
('80', 385, 7, 13, 604280) I finished reading Bapu Just now.
('80', 385, 7, 14, 604314) At two or three places the facts are wrong though they do not detract from the views expressed.
('80', 385, 7, 15, 604410) I have marked the passages.
('80', 385, 7, 16, 604438) Of course you can always put forward your own arguments about the calf incident 4. But I findsome fundamental defect in it.
('80', 385, 7, 17, 604562) The killing of the calf has no similarity with the killing of Ravana and so on.
('80', 385, 7, 18, 604642) I had no self interest in killing the calf, the only motive was to free it from pain.
('80', 385, 7, 19, 604728) Primarily there was self interest in the killing of Ravana and so on.
('80', 385, 7, 20, 604798) There was burden on the earth and it had to be lightened.
('80', 385, 7, 21, 604856) His destroyer was God in the form of Rama.
('80', 385, 7, 22, 604899) Here the destroyer was no supposed incarnation.
('80', 385, 7, 23, 604947) I hold that everyone in my situation can do what I did.
('80', 385, 7, 24, 605003) Inspired and encouraged by me, Ambalal killed forty dogs.

('80', 386, 5, 8, 605907) July 22, 1941
('80', 386, 6, 9, 605921) When I asked Gandhiji, who was at work on his charkha when I called on him, whether he had read the communique 1, he said he had not and asked me to read it.
('80', 386, 6, 10, 606079) With his hands busy operating his charkha, stopping only now and then to wind the thread, Gandhiji listened as I read the communique including the personnel of the National Defence Council.
('80', 386, 6, 11, 606269) When I concluded reading, Gandhiji looked up and, laughing loudly, asked whether I had finished.
('80', 386, 6, 12, 606366) I said I had, and asked him whether he wished to say anything.
('80', 386, 6, 13, 606429) Gandhiji said that he had no statement to make and added: I would rather observe silence, Monday silence, whatever it may mean and you can say so in the papers.
('80', 386, 7, 14, 606590) When I asked him whether it could be taken that he was not interested in the announcement, he said: I can’t say so.
('80', 386, 7, 15, 606706) That will be pedantic.
('80', 386, 8, 16, 606729) Then I handed him a sheet of paper containing a few questions drafted by me earlier.
('80', 386, 8, 17, 606814) Gandhiji read the questions and remarked: I can answer some of these questions.
('80', 386, 8, 18, 606894) But I don’t know what purpose it will serve.
('80', 386, 9, 19, 606939) Pressed further to say whatever he wished, Gandhiji replied to my first question, whether the Government of India’s announcement affected the stand taken by the Congress and whether it met the Congress demand to any extent.
('80', 386, 9, 20, 607163) The announcement does not affect the stand taken by the Congress; nor does it meet the Congress demand to any extent.
('80', 386, 10, 21, 607281) To my next question whether the members of the A.I.C.C., if released from jail, will be permitted to consider the present situation in the light of recent
('80', 386, 11, 22, 607436) 1 Issued by the Government of India on July 21 from Simla announcing the expansion of the Viceroy’s Executive Council and the formation of a National Defence Council.
('80', 387, 0, 1, 607603) 388 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('80', 391, 1, 2, 614415) 679. LETTER TO H. R. STIMSON 1
('80', 391, 2, 3, 614446) SEVAGRAM, July 24, 1941
('80', 391, 3, 4, 614470) DEAR MR. STIMSON, Here are my answers : 1. No modification necessary.
('80', 391, 3, 5, 614540) My advice to the Russians would be precisely the same as to the British.
('80', 391, 3, 6, 614613) It is a cruel misrepresentation of my advice to the British to say that it was one of non resistance.
('80', 391, 3, 7, 614715) I suggested non violent resistance which is any day superior to violent, blood thirsty resistance.
('80', 391, 3, 8, 614814) 2. I am entirely satisfied with the progress and achievements of my limited non cooperation campaign as you call it and which I describe as civil disobedience.
('80', 391, 3, 9, 614974) 3. It is a difficult question to answer definitely.
('80', 391, 3, 10, 615026) But I do not mind it being said that the majority are non violent only out of policy.
('80', 391, 3, 11, 615112) That is the weakest part of my campaign but it is inevitable.
('80', 391, 3, 12, 615174) In spite of the appearances to the contrary it is my belief that true non violence is growing among the people.
('80', 391, 3, 13, 615286) 4. I have no doubt whatsoever that in spite of the riots, etc.
('80', 391, 3, 14, 615349) India will have the moral strength and unity to forge her own destiny in her own way.
('80', 391, 3, 15, 615435) Twenty years of solid work cannot be a waste.
('80', 391, 3, 16, 615481) I hope you can decipher my writing and that if you publish my reply, it will be published as it is, in toto.
('80', 391, 4, 17, 615590) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('80', 391, 5, 18, 615620) From a photostat : Jayaprakash Narayan Papers.
('80', 391, 5, 19, 615667) Courtesy : Nehru Memorial Museum and Library.
('80', 391, 6, 20, 615713) 1 An Associated Press correspondent had sought Gandhiji’s views on the following points : (i) whether Gandhiji’s policy of non violence advocated to the British would apply to Russians also, or would it need any modification; (ii) whether Gandhiji was satisfied with the progress of non cooperation; (iii) how many of his followers really believed in non violence; (iv) whether in view of the widespread rioting in the country, India could still have the unity and strength to forge her own destiny.

('80', 408, 6, 24, 639047) 712. LETTER TO “THE TIMES OF INDIA”
('80', 408, 7, 25, 639083) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, July 31, 1941
('80', 408, 8, 26, 639115) DEAR SIR, This is the concluding portion of your leaderette 2 in The Times of India, [of the] 29th instant:
('80', 408, 9, 27, 639223) Either he has been lax in interpreting his own rules of satyagraha or he has been deceived by the majority of those whose names were submitted.
('80', 408, 9, 28, 639367) Mr. Gandhi can best say which of these alternatives is the right one.
('80', 408, 10, 29, 639437) 1 The source here adds “in Ajmer”; vide “Letter to Kotwal”, 7 8 1941 2 Vide “Letter from Subhas Chandra Bose”, 23 12 1940.
('80', 409, 0, 1, 639560) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 409, 1, 2, 639602) I suggest a third alternative.
('80', 409, 1, 3, 639633) I have neither been lax in the interpretation of my rules of satyagraha nor have I been deceived by anybody.
('80', 409, 1, 4, 639742) You have omitted to read one sentence in my admissions: “It is inevitable.” From the very inception of the movement in 1920 non violence has been a policy and not a creed.
('80', 409, 1, 5, 639914) I said 1 in Bombay speaking at the A.I.C.C. meeting on the reversal of the Poona resolution that with the majority non violence was a policy.
('80', 409, 1, 6, 640056) The weak ness was therefore inherent in the movement.
('80', 409, 1, 7, 640110) It should not be for gotten that I am trying the great experiment of using non violence for the political freedom of the country.
('80', 409, 1, 8, 640240) With me no doubt non violence is an end in itself, though it is also a means for the attainment of the freedom of the country.
('80', 409, 1, 9, 640367) With the vast majority of Congressmen it is and must remain a means.
('80', 409, 1, 10, 640436) The weakness is thus inherent though none the less regrettable.
('80', 409, 1, 11, 640500) The marvel is that in spite of the weakness, twenty years’ experience has not weaned Congressmen from the non violent policy, though it is open to it to change it any time.
('80', 409, 1, 12, 640673) In the light of the information I have provided, you will perhaps admit that the case you have made up against the Congress and me falls to the ground.
('80', 409, 3, 13, 640825) Yours sincerely,
('80', 409, 4, 14, 640842) Congress Bulletin, No.
('80', 409, 4, 15, 640865) 6, 1942, File No.
('80', 409, 4, 16, 640883) 3/42/41 Home Department, Pol.

('80', 415, 0, 1, 648004) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 415, 1, 2, 648046) 722. SPEECH AT INAUGURATION OF KHADI VIDYALAYA
('80', 415, 2, 3, 648093) WARDHA, August 1, 1941 We want to achieve the welfare of the world by truth and non violence.
('80', 415, 2, 4, 648187) I want you, students of this Vidyalaya, to devote yourselves to a scientific study of the charkha and khadi and make improvements by new inventions and serve the villagers.
('80', 415, 2, 5, 648360) Just as the sun is the centre of the planetary system, so is the charkha of our economic or village structure.
('80', 415, 2, 6, 648471) Without the sun, the world will perish; so without the charkha, which is our saviour and bread giver, we shall lose.
('80', 415, 2, 7, 648588) If khadi comes to stay, everything will be all right; for the progress and improvement of khadi utilize both your intellect and hand power.
('80', 415, 2, 8, 648728) This khadi mantra manifested itself in 1908 when I was in South Africa along with the late Maganlal Gandhi who had made experiments for improving its technique.
('80', 415, 2, 9, 648889) We are not opposed to machinery, but we must meet it by new inventions in our khadi science and by providing work and food for the villagers.
('80', 415, 2, 10, 649031) Make your mind and intellect scientific, so that you students will always search for new things for the betterment of your country.
('80', 415, 2, 11, 649163) Our prayer should be for serving all, Hindus, Muslims and other communities.
('80', 415, 2, 12, 649240) By serving India, we can serve the world, as our object is non exploitation, non suppression and non hatred.
('80', 415, 2, 13, 649349) This requires penance which will add to our knowledge.
('80', 415, 2, 14, 649404) We have to exert ourselves more for passing the test of service to Indians and later to humanity.
('80', 415, 2, 15, 649502) The Charkha Sangh is the central force or the centre of the All India Village Industries’ Association and the Talimi Sangh just as the sun is the guiding force on the solar system (suryamandal).
('80', 415, 2, 16, 649697) Our small beginning with this Vidyalaya may attain or produce better results and our dreams will be realized if you systematically and scientifically study khadishastra (science) for serving the poor villagers, for giving them food and clothing by your sacrifice, suffering, penance and purity of character; by this we shall not only serve India, but also the world.
('80', 415, 3, 17, 650064) The Bombay Chronicle, 2 8 1941
('80', 416, 0, 1, 650095) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 417
('80', 416, 1, 2, 650143) 723. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR

('80', 416, 3, 4, 650206) MY DEAR IDIOT, Your letter is bad!

('80', 421, 1, 2, 656919) 732. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('80', 421, 2, 3, 656947) SEVAGRAM, August 4, 1941 1
('80', 421, 3, 4, 656974) Khurshedbehn Naoroji is the youngest grand daughter of the late G.O.M. 2 of India.
('80', 421, 3, 5, 657057) In common with her other sisters, she has dedicated herself to the service of India, in truth, of humanity.
('80', 421, 3, 6, 657165) She felt the call some years ago to go to the Frontier Province.
('80', 421, 3, 7, 657230) and workamong the Pathans there and spread the gospel of non violence.
('80', 421, 3, 8, 657301) She took part also in the last civil disobedience campaign.
('80', 421, 3, 9, 657361) The last time she was in the Frontier was in connection with dacoities and kidnappings.
('80', 421, 3, 10, 657449) She is a brave and fearless woman, and so she had planned to work, if she could, even in the tribal area, and come in contact with the dacoits, and wean them from their error.
('80', 421, 3, 11, 657625) For months she worked within the Province and was trying to cross the border with the permission of the Government.
('80', 421, 3, 12, 657741) But she did not get the permission, though the authorities with whom she came into contact recognized her worth, transparent honesty, and utter absence of secrecy about her movements in the Frontier Province.
('80', 421, 3, 13, 657950) This is clear from the letters she holds from the officials.
('80', 421, 3, 14, 658011) Being tired of waiting she notified the Frontier Government of her intention to cross the border.
('80', 421, 3, 15, 658109) But she was arrested, tried and sentenced to a fine of Rs. 100 or imprisonment for three months in default thereof.
('80', 421, 3, 16, 658225) She preferred the latter and on her finishing the term of imprisonment she was externed from the Frontier Province, and interned in the Island of Bombay.
('80', 421, 3, 17, 658379) She protested against the order and corresponded with the authorities.
('80', 421, 3, 18, 658450) I give below her letters:
('80', 421, 4, 19, 658476) 78 NAPEAN SEA ROAD, BOMBAY, March 31, 1941
('80', 421, 5, 20, 658519) SIR RICHARD TOTTENHAM,
('80', 421, 6, 21, 658542) ADDITIONAL SECRETARY TO THE GOVERNMENT OF INDIA
('80', 421, 7, 22, 658590) HOME DEPARTMENT, POLITICAL (I)
('80', 421, 8, 23, 658621) NEW DELHI
('80', 421, 9, 24, 658631) 1 The draft version available in the A.I.C. C. File No.
('80', 421, 9, 25, 658687) 1363, 1941, is dated August 3, 1941, and The Bombay Chronicle reports the statement under “Wardha, August 5”.
('80', 421, 9, 26, 658797) 2 Dadabhai Naoroji, who was known as the “Grand Old Man of India”.
('80', 422, 0, 1, 658864) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 423
('80', 422, 1, 2, 658912) dated 18th February, 1941, which was served on me just before my release
('80', 422, 2, 3, 658985) from the Peshawar Central Prison on 4th March 1941, I have to state as
('80', 422, 3, 4, 659056) follows:
('80', 422, 4, 5, 659065) I consider the language of the order vague and the restrictions
('80', 422, 5, 6, 659129) unjustifiable, in view of the activities in which I was engaged.
('80', 422, 5, 7, 659194) I place these
('80', 422, 6, 8, 659208) few facts before you.
('80', 422, 7, 9, 659230) For nine months prior to my arrest on 4th December, 1940, I had been
('80', 422, 8, 10, 659299) working in the Bannu District of the North West Frontier Province, trying to
('80', 422, 9, 11, 659376) instil into the minds of the people the ideal of non violence.
('80', 422, 9, 12, 659439) I went about
('80', 422, 10, 13, 659452) from village to village meeting Pirs, Maliks, Khans, as well as dacoits—all
('80', 422, 11, 14, 659528) honour to many of them—who gave a patient hearing to my talks.
('80', 422, 11, 15, 659591) I spoke to
('80', 422, 12, 16, 659602) them on the cowardice and cruelty of carrying away or killing defenceless men,
('80', 422, 13, 17, 659681) women and children.
('80', 422, 13, 18, 659701) I argued with dacoits and tribesmen on the inhumanity of
('80', 422, 14, 19, 659758) killing one’s fellow beings.
('80', 422, 14, 20, 659787) I strove to make villagers responsible for the
('80', 422, 15, 21, 659834) collective security of the villages.
('80', 422, 15, 22, 659871) I asked the Hindus to show more courage,
('80', 422, 16, 23, 659912) and try and create a living bond of sympathy between themselves and their
('80', 422, 17, 24, 659986) Pathan neighbours.
('80', 422, 17, 25, 660005) I begged of the Pathans to live up to their traditions of
('80', 422, 18, 26, 660063) protecting the weak and opposing brute force even from their own kinsmen.
('80', 422, 19, 27, 660137) The above mentioned facts may be verified through Government officials in
('80', 422, 20, 28, 660211) the district concerned, in the North West Frontier Province.
('80', 422, 21, 29, 660272) After due intimation to the authorities, I was proceeding to Walo Tangi in
('80', 422, 22, 30, 660347) Tribal Territory on 4th Dec.
('80', 422, 22, 31, 660376) 1940, to try and obtain the release of some Hindu
('80', 422, 23, 32, 660426) kidnappees, among whom was a woman, when I was arrested.
('80', 422, 23, 33, 660483) I had intended to
('80', 422, 24, 34, 660501) spend some time there, if necessary, until I had accomplished my object.
('80', 422, 25, 35, 660574) During all my talks, private or public, to the Frontier villagers as stated
('80', 422, 26, 36, 660650) above, at least one C.I.D. officer was always present and heard what I said, and
('80', 422, 27, 37, 660731) which in all probability was reported to the Government department
('80', 422, 28, 38, 660798) concerned.
('80', 422, 29, 39, 660809) I, therefore, take the liberty to ask if my conduct or speech in the N.W.F.
('80', 422, 30, 40, 660885) Province, such as I have described, could by any stretch of imagination be
('80', 422, 31, 41, 660960) considered to be prejudicial to the efficient prosecution of the war, to the
('80', 422, 32, 42, 661037) defence of British India, or to the public order.
('80', 422, 33, 43, 661087) I regard my work in the Frontier Province to have been essentially humanitarian.
('80', 422, 33, 44, 661168) I feel sure that I could not have been banished from the N.W.F.P. for the activities described by me.
('80', 422, 33, 45, 661270) If the Government have information to the contrary, they have been entirely misled.
('80', 422, 33, 46, 661354) I should be given
('80', 423, 0, 1, 661372) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 423, 1, 2, 661414) an opportunity of rebutting evidence which has led to the passing of the order against me.
('80', 423, 2, 3, 661505) May I expect an early reply?
('80', 423, 3, 4, 661534) Yours truly, Sd/ K. A. D. NAOROJI The authorities turned a deaf ear to her protest.
('80', 423, 3, 5, 661618) So she decided to break the order of internment if she could not get relief and consequently gave the following notice to the authorities:
('80', 423, 4, 6, 661757) DEAR SIR,
('80', 423, 5, 7, 661767) With reference to your last letter after careful consideration I have
('80', 423, 6, 8, 661837) failed to find the slightest justification for restricting me to the Island of
('80', 423, 7, 9, 661916) Bombay.
('80', 423, 8, 10, 661924) I am prepared to understand in these times of stress for the British Government the prevention of my entry, for the time being, into the Frontier Province.
('80', 423, 8, 11, 662080) But I find it hard to reconcile myself to being cooped up in the Island of Bombay.
('80', 423, 8, 12, 662163) My whole soul rebels against what I hold to bemanifestly unjust and wholly unnecessary.
('80', 423, 8, 13, 662251) It insults my intelligence.
('80', 423, 8, 14, 662279) Unless, therefore, the restriction order is confined only to the Frontier Province and my freedom of movement is left otherwise undisturbed and unless I receive an answer amending the order as requested by June 30, I propose to disobey it.
('80', 423, 9, 15, 662519) Yours truly, Sd/ K. A. D. NAOROJI For very shame, 1 I suppose, and probably also because they felt that they could not justify their high handed action in confining the internment to Bombay they relaxed the order so as to cover the whole of the Bombay Presidency.
('80', 423, 9, 16, 662783) That brought her no relief.
('80', 423, 9, 17, 662811) She resented the underlying distrust.
('80', 423, 9, 18, 662849) As will be seen from the correspondence I have reproduced, she was quite willing to accommodate the authorities by not going to the Frontier Province.
('80', 423, 9, 19, 663000) But she could not possibly tolerate the idea of being confined to the Bombay Presidency.
('80', 423, 9, 20, 663089) There was no reason whatsoever why she should not be allowed to go to Wardha to confer with me, or to go to Allahabad to see the Kamala Nehru Hospital of which she was till the other day one of the active trustees and
('80', 423, 10, 21, 663307) 1 Vide “Letter to Devdas Gandhi”, 13 8 1941.
('80', 424, 0, 1, 663352) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 425
('80', 424, 1, 2, 663400) secretaries, or to travel to any other part of India, where she has many friends, and where she could be of great service in many of the constructive activities going on in the country.
('80', 424, 1, 3, 663586) At last being utterly dissatisfied with the inexplicable treatment meted out to her she gave notice to the Commissioner of Police, Bombay, on 31st July, 1941, of her intention to proceed to Wardha on the 1st of August if she was left free.
('80', 424, 1, 4, 663826) So on the morning of the 1st she was without trial, shall I say, kidnapped, to the Yeravda Central Jail.
('80', 424, 1, 5, 663931) This action of the Government baffles me, and is a significant and searching commentary on the so called expansion of the Viceregal Council and what not.
('80', 424, 1, 6, 664085) The public should understand that Khurshedbehn’s action is no part of the war resistance.
('80', 424, 1, 7, 664175) But the public is hardly aware of the fact that many persons have been arrested and detained without trial although so far as I am aware there is no charge against them of having offered war resistance either as part of the Congress campaign or outside it.
('80', 424, 1, 8, 664432) They are being detained for reasons of which neither they nor the public have any knowledge.
('80', 424, 1, 9, 664525) Is Khurshedbehn’s case an index of what has been done in these other cases?

('80', 428, 1, 2, 669294) 739. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('80', 428, 2, 3, 669322) WARDHAGANJ, August 5, 1941 I have read a Press summary of a letter said to have been written to me by 48 persons from the Gujrat Jail (Punjab).
('80', 428, 2, 4, 669466) The question asked in the message is: “Would it be possible for any member of the Congress to use violent means against a violent dacoit under grave and provocative conditions, and yet remain in the Congress fold?” Of course it is possible, it is even possible for people to remain in the Congress although they deliberately break every Congress rule.
('80', 428, 2, 5, 669818) But if I am asked whether such persons should remain in the Congress, my answer would be an emphatic ‘No’.
('80', 428, 2, 6, 669925) That is for public conduct.
('80', 428, 2, 7, 669953) No law has been laid down by the Congress as to private conduct.
('80', 428, 2, 8, 670018) The Congress will refuse, as it should, to judge the conduct of a person who resists by force a robber robbing his property, or an assailant molesting his daughter.
('80', 428, 2, 9, 670183) However, the Congress Resolution passed at Poona clearly lays down that volunteer organizations for the purpose of self defence organized by the Congress or with which Congressmen are associated, must adhere to non violence.
('80', 428, 2, 10, 670408) Whether persons who break the rule or even preach the use of violence by Congressmen in such cases should be turned out of the Congress is a different question.
('80', 428, 2, 11, 670569) My personal attitude is clear.
('80', 428, 2, 12, 670600) I would not necessarily turn out such persons from the Congress.
('80', 428, 2, 13, 670665) My letter to the Delhi President of the Congress Committee has been misquoted or misunderstood.
('80', 428, 2, 14, 670761) 1 I deliberately advised against expulsion from the Congress.
('80', 428, 2, 15, 670823) I have always held that it is an action to be adopted in rare case.
('80', 428, 2, 16, 670891) I know some persons have interpreted my advice 2 to Shri Munshi as expulsion.
('80', 428, 2, 17, 670969) I regard the step taken by him as that of a high souled man.
('80', 428, 2, 18, 671030) He had taken no overt action.
('80', 428, 2, 19, 671060) He had conscientious scruples.
('80', 428, 2, 20, 671091) He referred to me for advice and, in his own interest and that of the Congress, I advised him to go out of the Congress.
('80', 428, 2, 21, 671212) There was no coercion, even remote or indirect.
('80', 428, 2, 22, 671260) His retirement was wholly
('80', 428, 3, 23, 671286) 1 The Hindu, 4 7 1941, had quoted the letter as follows: “If any four anna Congress member, directly or indirectly, participates in the war effort, he should be expelled from the Congress membership.” Vide also “Letter to Raghunandan Saran”, Before 16 7 1941. 2 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 15 6 1941
('80', 429, 0, 1, 671589) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 429, 1, 2, 671631) voluntary and dictated by purely moral scruples.
('80', 429, 1, 3, 671680) I have no reason whatsoever for repenting of my advice, which I should unhesitatingly repeat in every such case.
('80', 429, 1, 4, 671793) The rest of the message does not call for any notice.

('80', 453, 5, 18, 707258) 785. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('80', 453, 6, 19, 707286) WARDHA, August 12, 1941 The seventeenth instant is the shraddha day of Gurudev.
('80', 453, 6, 20, 707366) Those who attach religious significance to the shraddha ceremony will no doubt fast for the day by abstaining from food altogether or confining themselves only to fruits, and devote themselves to prayer.
('80', 453, 6, 21, 707570) The prayer may be individual or congregational.
('80', 453, 6, 22, 707618) Every city and every village which has partaken of Gurudev’s uplifting message delivered through his writings and lived in his life will meet at an hour best suited to them and contemplate the noble life and dedicate themselves for the country’s service.
('80', 453, 6, 23, 707873) Gurudev stood for peace and goodwill.
('80', 453, 6, 24, 707911) He knew no communal barriers.
('80', 453, 6, 25, 707941) I, therefore, hope that all sections will join together in observing the solemn day and promote communal harmony.
('80', 453, 6, 26, 708055) I would like all further to remember that the bulk of the Deenabandhu Memorial still remains to be collected.
('80', 453, 6, 27, 708165) Sad to say, it has also become Gurudev’s Memorial, for the simple reason that collections of the Memorial are to be solely devoted to the upkeep and expansion of Santiniketan, which includes the Visvabharati and
('80', 454, 0, 1, 708377) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 455
('80', 454, 1, 2, 708425) Sriniketan.
('80', 454, 1, 3, 708437) This does not exclude a separate and special memorial for Gurudev, but it would be a mockery even to think of one before the memorial conceived by Gurudev himself has been fulfilled.
('80', 454, 1, 4, 708620) It would be a fitting finish to the solemn day if the workers and organizers make it a point to collect for the memorial and send them to Messrs Bachraj and Company, 51 Mahatma Gandhi Road, Bombay.
('80', 454, 2, 5, 708818) The Bombay Chronicle, 14 8 1941

('80', 468, 3, 4, 726303) LETTER FROM SUBHAS CHANDRA BOSE1
('80', 468, 4, 5, 726336) CALCUTTA, December 23, 1940
('80', 468, 5, 6, 726364) When Mahadevbhai saw me in the Presidency Jail, I took the opportunity of conveying a message to you.
('80', 468, 5, 7, 726466) I requested him to tell you that, if you launched a movement, then our services would be entirely at your disposal, for what they were worth.
('80', 468, 5, 8, 726608) I also waned him to request you to take the initiative in settling the dispute in Bengal, so that the Province could throw its whole weight into the movement.
('80', 468, 5, 9, 726767) Since you have been appointed Dictator, you could easily take up this matter on behalf of the Congress.
('80', 468, 5, 10, 726871) So, I thought.
('80', 468, 6, 11, 726886) At the time, my fond expectation was that you would launch a mass movement, as you had done in 1921, 1930 and 1932, though Mahadevbhai told me that you had been thinking of individual civil disobedience.
('80', 468, 6, 12, 727090) Today it is clear that the movement launched by you is not on the issue of our national demand for independence.
('80', 468, 6, 13, 727203) Nor is this movement a mass struggle.
('80', 468, 6, 14, 727241) If the Government were to permit anti war speeches, it appears to me, the movement would come to an end.
('80', 468, 6, 15, 727346) Nevertheless we would like to co operate with such a movement, despite its restricted scope and form, so far as it lies in our power consistently with our political stand.
('80', 468, 6, 16, 727518) We would like to know if you would accept our co operation for what it is worth—and if so, what you would like us to do in pursuance of this offer of co operation.
('80', 468, 6, 17, 727682) This proffered co operation is unconditional in the sense that whatever grievances we may have against the Congress High Command will not stand in our way.
('80', 468, 6, 18, 727838) If and when the High Command deal with us unfairly and unjustly, we shall have to react accordingly.
('80', 468, 6, 19, 727939) We may have to fight the arbitrary and high handed action of Maulana Abul Kalam Azad at the present time.
('80', 468, 6, 20, 728045) But this can never blind us to the larger issues before the country, and there you can have our fullest co operation, consistently with our political stand.
('80', 468, 6, 21, 728202) I beg you to accept our offer of co operation.
('80', 468, 7, 22, 728249) Regarding the Bengal situation, I had told Mahadevbhai that if you desired unity, you could have it for the mere asking, and all that was necessary was a talk between you and my brother, Sarat Babu.
('80', 468, 7, 23, 728448) Since then the situation has deteriorated.
('80', 468, 7, 24, 728491) You have chosen to remain silent and indifferent.
('80', 468, 7, 25, 728541) The Maulana has been rushing
('80', 468, 8, 26, 728570) 1 Vide “Letter to Subhas Chandra Bose”, 29 12 1940
('80', 469, 0, 1, 728621) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 469, 1, 2, 728663) headlong along the mad path of what he calls disciplinary action.
('80', 469, 1, 3, 728729) I am not bothered about it, because if he wills it and seeks it, we are ready to meet him on his own ground.
('80', 469, 1, 4, 728838) He cannot affect our public position in the least, and he has only been making himself ridiculous before the public of this province and thereby dragging the name of the Congress to the dust.

('80', 470, 7, 9, 731671) LETTER FROM SIR J. C. LAITHWAITE1
('80', 470, 8, 10, 731705) THE VICEROY’S HOUSE, NEW DELHI, January 28, 1941
('80', 470, 9, 11, 731754) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('80', 470, 10, 12, 731771) Thank you very much for your letter of the 16th January which I have laid before His Excellency.
('80', 470, 10, 13, 731868) He is very glad to note your decision, and he asks me to say that he much appreciates the emphasis you have laid in your letter on your attitude towards the embarrassing of authority.
('80', 470, 11, 14, 732052) I see that you are under some misapprehension as to the manner in which the statements enclosed with your letter failed to appear in the Press.
('80', 470, 11, 15, 732196) There is no such thing as the censorship of matter intended for publication in the Indian Press nor has any prohibition been issued in respect of your two statements.
('80', 470, 11, 16, 732363) In view, however, of the provisions of the Defence of India Rules regarding the publication of prejudicial reports, Press agencies and editors have the option of voluntarily submitting for advice messages in regard to which they feel any doubt.
('80', 470, 11, 17, 732608) In giving advice on such references the Press Advisers have regard only to the question whether the matter submitted contains any prejudicial report, the publication of which would render the person concerned liable to prosecution under the Defence of India Rules.
('80', 470, 11, 18, 732873) You will see, for instance, that both the Congress Pledge and your own statement 2 about Independence Day, although similarly referred for Press advice, were passed for publication, because they had no direct connection with movement intended to
('80', 470, 12, 19, 733119) 1 Vide “Letter to Agatha Harrison”, 17 1 1941 2 Vide “Instructions For Independence Day”, 11 1 1941
('80', 471, 0, 1, 733219) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 471, 1, 2, 733261) interfere with the prosecution of the war.
('80', 471, 1, 3, 733304) On the other hand, both the statements 1
('80', 471, 2, 4, 733345) enclosed with your letter were, I regret to say, of this nature.
('80', 471, 2, 5, 733410) Although considerable portions of them could have been published without objection, at least from the point of view of the war, each of them contained numerous passages which were clearly intended or likely to encourage and instruct persons engaged in your civil disobedience movement.
('80', 471, 2, 6, 733696) This movement in its present form consists of the uttering in public of slogans purporting to dissuade the public from participation in the war effort and thus in the words of the Defence of India Rules “to influence the conduct or attitude of the public or any section of the public in a manner likely to be prejudicial to the defence of British India or to the efficient prosecution of the war”.
('80', 471, 2, 7, 734094) In so far as they contained such passages, the statements in question could not have been published without exposing the editor or Press agency concerned to the risk of prosecution and the Press Advisers were only performing their clear duty in advising the Press against their publication.
('80', 471, 2, 8, 734385) The Press were of course not obliged to take this advice, but you would not expect them, I think, to take a risk of which they were warned and you will see the dilemma in which they are placed when they receive such statements from you for publication.
('80', 471, 2, 9, 734638) His Excellency feels sure that you will appreciate that the liberty of the Press does not and cannot in any country mean the right to publish anything without prosecution, more especially at a time of grave emergency such as this, and that without any interference with such liberty the Press Advisers were fully justified in giving the advice they did and the Press in accepting it.
('80', 471, 3, 10, 735022) Yours sincerely,
('80', 471, 4, 11, 735039) J. G. LAITHWAITE

('80', 471, 9, 17, 735194) DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('80', 471, 10, 18, 735210) I thank you for your letter of the 25th of January, which I received yesterday.
('80', 471, 10, 19, 735290) I am glad to know that my article in the Twentieth Century had attracted your notice.
('80', 471, 11, 20, 735376) 1 Vide “Instructions to Satyagrahis”, 10 1 1941 and “Instruction to Satyag rahis”, 12 1 1941 2 Vide “Letter to T. B. Sapru”, 25 1 1941 and “Letter to T. B. Sapru”, 1 2 1941
('80', 472, 0, 1, 735549) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 473
('80', 472, 1, 2, 735597) I read in the papers that you had gone to Bombay to see Mr. Jinnah but I do not know what exactly passed between you and him there.
('80', 472, 1, 3, 735729) I met Mr. Jinnah by the merest accident at Dr. Berger’s Clinic in Bombay on the 6th or the 7th of August last.
('80', 472, 1, 4, 735840) He came up to me and asked me to have tea with him.
('80', 472, 1, 5, 735892) Accordingly I went to him the next day and I had a conversation with him lasting for about one hour and a half.
('80', 472, 1, 6, 736004) He told me what had transpired between you and him at Delhi and of the differences which arose between you and him in the presence of the Viceroy.
('80', 472, 1, 7, 736151) My impression was that though there was a general conversation between you and him on some of the political demands of the Congress, the communal question did not specifically form the subject of discussion.
('80', 472, 2, 8, 736359) You are, if I may say so, quite right in saying that we have to settle our domestic troubles ourselves and that without thinking whether the British will accept our joint demands or not.
('80', 472, 2, 9, 736546) That has always been my view.
('80', 472, 2, 10, 736576) I am afraid, the communal situation has been allowed too long to deteriorate from bad to worse and I very strongly feel that that is the one question to which every one of us (and particularly you with your influence) have to address ourselves.
('80', 472, 2, 11, 736821) For so long as these differences last among ourselves, I am afraid, real self government is difficult to achieve and still more difficult to maintain.
('80', 472, 3, 12, 736972) During the Christmas Week Nawab Mohammad Ismail and Nawab Liaquat Ali Khan were here in connection with the session of the Provincial Muslim league.
('80', 472, 3, 13, 737121) The former, who is an old friend of mine, came to see me and I met the latter at the house of a common friend.
('80', 472, 3, 14, 737232) We talked freely and pleasantly and the impression left on my mind was that though the task of settlement would present great difficulties, it was by no means hopeless.
('80', 472, 3, 15, 737401) I had no talk with Mr. Jinnah on the question of Pakistan.
('80', 472, 3, 16, 737460) I believe the word ‘Pakistan’ is a convenient phrase which has been adopted by the Muslim League to cover a multitude of political and constitutional ideas.
('80', 472, 3, 17, 737617) If it means a partition of India then I do not mind saying that I am very strongly opposed to it.
('80', 472, 3, 18, 737715) If it means a reconsideration of certain political ideas and readjustment of some constitutional provisions then I should not rule out their discussion.
('80', 472, 3, 19, 737868) In any case, however, for the purpose of conversations intended to achieve a communal settlement, it would not be right for any party to impose on the other any kind of conditions precedent.
('80', 472, 3, 20, 738059) I can see no reason why Mr. Jinnah should decline to meet you.
('80', 472, 3, 21, 738122) Not only would it be rude on his part to decline to meet you but it would also put him positively in the wrong, if he were to adopt that sort of attitude.
('80', 472, 4, 22, 738277) You say in your letter that “he does not want a settlement till he has so consolidated the League position that he can dictate his terms to all the parties concerned including the rulers” and that you “often feel like writing to him but lose courage when it comes to the point of taking up my pen”.
('80', 472, 4, 23, 738576) You are, however, a man of infinite courage and you are big enough to rise superior to petty considerations of a
('80', 473, 0, 1, 738689) 474 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('80', 473, 1, 2, 738731) conventional character.
('80', 473, 1, 3, 738755) I see no reason why you should not write to him a perfectly courteous letter—as you always do—telling him that in the interest of the country you should like to have an opportunity of meeting him and discussing the whole situation so as to see whether an honourable settlement, which will be satisfactory to all the parties concerned, is possible.
('80', 473, 1, 4, 739103) If he makes a satisfactory response, I think, you should take the step forward.
('80', 473, 1, 5, 739183) That will heighten and strengthen your position and the position of the Congress and of the Hindus at large.
('80', 473, 1, 6, 739292) If he makes no response to your request or adopts a truculent attitude that is bound to recoil on his head and on the party which he represents.
('80', 473, 1, 7, 739437) My own belief is that the farther away the parties can be from each other, the greater is the misunderstanding and the more difficult the task of reconciliation.
('80', 473, 2, 8, 739599) You then say in your letter: “But if you have faith why don’t you see him without being asked by anybody?” As a private individual I should have no objection at all to meeting him or anybody else but the real difficulty that I feel about my position is that I cannot pretend to represent the Congress or the Hindus.
('80', 473, 2, 9, 739915) I can write to him (and am quite willing to do so) suggesting that he should meet you or that if you write to him saying that you want to meet him, he should receive you and talk to you.
('80', 473, 2, 10, 740102) I should not, however, write to him without your permission.
('80', 473, 2, 11, 740163) If you will permit me, I can also write to Nawab Mohammad Ismail, who, I know, is a very good man and who, I feel, will sincerely welcome peace and harmony.
('80', 473, 2, 12, 740320) You may be sure that whether I write to Mr. Jinnah or to Nawab Ismail or to anyone, I am not going to commit you or anyone to any position.
('80', 473, 2, 13, 740460) I can only throw out a suggestion for the initiation of conversations.
('80', 473, 2, 14, 740531) Hitherto I have written no kind of letter on the subject to Mr. Jinnah or any other Muslim friend and I have scrupulously avoided during the last one year and a half writing to the Viceroy or any British official at Delhi or Simla.
('80', 473, 2, 15, 740763) Last time that I saw the Viceroy was in September 1939. Holding the views that I do, I feel verystrongly that it is no use my seeing him or writing to him in the midst of these differences, which divide one party from another and one set of politicians from another.
('80', 473, 2, 16, 741030) It is because of this feeling that both in the statement that I issued last month to the Press and in my article in the Twentieth Century I have laid emphasis on the desirability of a communal settlement and of your meeting Mr. Jinnah.
('80', 473, 2, 17, 741266) Speaking for myself I do not attach much importance to the general criticism of British policy that the Secretary of State and the Viceroy have given a veto to the minorities.
('80', 473, 2, 18, 741442) Whether they have done so or not, it is up to us to set our house in order and once we have done that, I think, we shall have gained the strength which it will be impossible on political grounds for anyone at Delhi, Simla or Whitehall to resist.
('80', 473, 3, 19, 741688) It is my misfortune that on some political questions I differ from many of my countrymen and have very strong convictions but I should do everything that lay in my power to pave the way for the communal settlement to which I attach far greater
('80', 474, 0, 1, 741932) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 475
('80', 474, 1, 2, 741980) importance than I do to mere academic discussions of this political theory or that.
('80', 474, 1, 3, 742064) In short, if you permit me, I am quite willing to write to Mr. Jinnah and some other Muslim friends.
('80', 474, 1, 4, 742165) I would much rather that you took the lead at a suitable opportunity of calling a conference than that any outsider or common friends howsoever well intentioned assumed responsibility for such a conference.
('80', 474, 1, 5, 742372) Some friends have written to me about it but I am not yet convinced that it would do any good for any private individuals to call such a conference or to wait on the Viceroy.
('80', 474, 1, 6, 742547) This must be left to you and Mr. Jinnah and I feel very strongly that if you take the lead in this matter, good may result.
('80', 474, 2, 7, 742671) With my best regards,
('80', 474, 3, 8, 742693) Yours sincerely,
('80', 474, 4, 9, 742710) MAHATMA M. K. GANDHI

('80', 475, 11, 18, 746449) From a copy: C.W. 10283. Courte sy: Nation al Librar y
('80', 476, 0, 1, 746504) VOL. 80 : 28 DECEMBER, 1940 17 AUGUST, 1941 477
('80', 476, 1, 2, 746552) APPENDIX VI
('80', 476, 2, 3, 746564) EXTRACTS FROM “PARTING OF THE WAYS”1
('80', 476, 3, 4, 746601) In the mind and heart of India there was a conflict.
('80', 476, 3, 5, 746654) There was an intense dislike of Fascism and Nazism and no desire to see them win.
('80', 476, 3, 6, 746736) If India could but be convinced that this war was being fought for a new world order, for real freedom, then indeed India would throw all her weight and strength into it.
('80', 476, 3, 7, 746907) But imperialism and we were old acquaintances, very old, with many generations of contact.
('80', 476, 3, 8, 746998) We knew each other, suspected each other, and disliked each other thoroughly.
('80', 476, 3, 9, 747076) There was this background of one hundred and eighty years of hostility, of exploitation, of bitterness, of promises unfulfilled, of disruptive and reactionary movements encouraged, and attempts to break up the national unity of India.
('80', 476, 3, 10, 747311) It was no easy matter for us to get over these tremendous hurdles, or remove the complexes that had grown up.
('80', 476, 3, 11, 747421) Yet we said we would do it, but we could not even attempt it unless a great psychological shock was given to the people, a pleasant shock, which would suddenly change the air of India and get rid of fears and complexes.
('80', 476, 3, 12, 747641) That pleasant shock could only come by an unequivocal declaration of independence and immediate steps to give effect to the popular will in the carrying on of the administration.
('80', 476, 3, 13, 747820) Unless this was done, no man in India, nor group, could make the people move in the direction of willing association with the war.
('80', 476, 3, 14, 747951) Wars today required mass support and even authoritarian countries have to whip up their people by ceaseless propaganda.
('80', 476, 3, 15, 748071) No war can be fought effectively by a professional army in an atmosphere of public ill will or indifference.
('80', 476, 3, 16, 748180) So even from the narrower point of view of organizing India’s defence or India’s participation in the war effort, a popular representative government was essential.
('80', 476, 3, 17, 748345) Imperialism can coerce; it cannot win public approval and goodwill.
('80', 476, 4, 18, 748413) I repeat that it is incorrect to say that there is any new parting of the ways, for our ways never lay together.
('80', 476, 4, 19, 748526) But this declaration of the British Government means the final breaking of such slender bonds as held our minds together, it means the ending of all hope that we shall ever march together.
('80', 476, 4, 20, 748715) I am sorry, for in spite of my hostility to British imperialism and all imperialisms, I have loved much that was England, and I should have liked to keep the silken bonds of the spirit between India and England.
('80', 476, 4, 21, 748927) Those bonds can only exist in freedom.
